studies.title: Patterns of brain activation when mothers view their own child and dog: an fMRI study.
studies.abstract: Neural substrates underlying the human-pet relationship are largely unknown. We examined fMRI brain activation patterns as mothers viewed images of their own child and dog and an unfamiliar child and dog. There was a common network of brain regions involved in emotion, reward, affiliation, visual processing and social cognition when mothers viewed images of both their child and dog. Viewing images of their child resulted in brain activity in the midbrain (ventral tegmental area/substantia nigra involved in reward/affiliation), while a more posterior cortical brain activation pattern involving fusiform gyrus (visual processing of faces and social cognition) characterized a mother's response to her dog. Mothers also rated images of their child and dog as eliciting similar levels of excitement (arousal) and pleasantness (valence), although the difference in the own vs. unfamiliar child comparison was larger than the own vs. unfamiliar dog comparison for arousal. Valence ratings of their dog were also positively correlated with ratings of the attachment to their dog. Although there are similarities in the perceived emotional experience and brain function associated with the mother-child and mother-dog bond, there are also key differences that may reflect variance in the evolutionary course and function of these relationships.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI was used while healthy adult mothers viewed images of their own vs unfamiliar child and dog, addressing affiliation/attachment and social processing. Participants are adults; task is social-related. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical task-fMRI study of social/attachment processing (mother–child and mother–dog affiliation). Sample consists of healthy adult participants (women aged 22–45); results are reported for this healthy group. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise univariate task contrasts (e.g., own child vs. fixation, own dog vs. fixation, own child vs. own dog) with MNI coordinates, statistical maps/figures, and cluster-level inference (even though small-volume correction/ROI masks were used for many hypotheses). It is not limited to connectivity or resting-state analyses and is not a non-empirical paper. Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults. Note: sample is a specific subgroup (mothers who own dogs), but the healthy adult group-level task activations are reported and thus eligible for inclusion.

studies.title: A neuroimaging investigation of attribute framing and individual differences.
studies.abstract: Functional magnetic resonance imaging was used to evaluate the neural basis of framing effects. We tested the reflexive and reflective systems model of social cognition as it relates to framing. We also examined the relationships among frame susceptibility, intelligence and personality measures. Participants evaluated whether personal attributes applied to themselves from multiple perspectives and in positive and negative frames. Participants rated whether each statement was descriptive or not and endorsed positive frames more than negative frames. Individual differences on frame decisions enabled us to form high and low frame susceptibility groups. Endorsement of frame-consistent attributes was associated with personality factors, cognitive reflection and intelligence. Reflexive brain regions were associated with positive frames while reflective areas were associated with negative frames. Region of Interest analyses showed that frame-inconsistent responses were associated with increased activation within reflective cognitive control regions including the left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (PFC), dorsomedial PFC and left ventrolateral PFC. Frame-consistent responses were associated with increased activation in the right orbitofrontal cortex. These results demonstrate that individual differences in frame susceptibility influence personal attribute evaluations. Overall, this study clarifies the neural correlates of the reflective and reflexive systems of social cognition as applied to decisions about social attributions.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI was used while participants performed a social-related task (self-attribute evaluations; perception/understanding of self). Abstract reports neural results in healthy-sounding samples and no clinical groups are mentioned. Age range not specified in abstract — include for full-text review to confirm participant age/health details.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (attribute framing, self and reflected perspectives). Sample comprises healthy adults within the target age range (19–41 years; group results reported after excluding 2 participants). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., task vs control, positive vs negative frame, frame-inconsistent vs frame-consistent) with stereotactic coordinates, statistical thresholds and cluster sizes described in the text and figures. It is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, nor a non-empirical paper. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

studies.title: Reduced embodied simulation in psychopathy.
studies.abstract: Psychopathy is characterized by severe deficits in emotion processing and empathy. These emotional deficits might not only affect the feeling of own emotions, but also the understanding of others' emotional and mental states. The present study aims on identifying the neurobiological correlates of social-cognitive related alterations in psychopathy.
studies.journal: The world journal of biological psychiatry : the official journal of the World Federation of Societies of Biological Psychiatry
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract does not specify that an fMRI task was used or whether healthy adult participants (age 17–65) were included. The study concerns neurobiological correlates of social-cognitive processes in psychopathy, which aligns with the review objective. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone — include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: The study reports task-based fMRI using a social-cognitive paradigm (face processing, emotion recognition, affective Theory of Mind) that directly addresses social-related processing. The sample includes a healthy adult control group (n=18) reported separately from the psychopathy group. The paper conducts whole-brain second-level random-effects analyses (thresholds for whole-brain results given, and supplementary tables referenced) and explicitly reports task-associated activation in the healthy controls (bilateral STS, inferior prefrontal gyrus and other cortical activations), satisfying the requirement for a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked map from healthy adults. The study is empirical and within the 17–65 adult range. It does not rely solely on ROIs or connectivity. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

studies.title: Differential response in the human amygdala to racial outgroup vs ingroup face stimuli.
studies.abstract: Here we describe response in the human amygdala to the presentation of racial outgroup vs ingroup faces. Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) measures of brain activity were acquired while subjects who identified themselves as White or Black viewed photographs of both White and Black faces. Across all subjects, we observed significantly greater blood oxygen-level-dependent (BOLD) signal in the amygdala to outgroup vs ingroup faces, but only during later stimulus presentations. A region of interest (ROI)-based analysis of these voxels revealed a significant interaction between amygdala response to outgroup and ingroup faces over time. Specifically, the greater amygdala activation to outgroup faces during later stimulus presentations was the result of amygdala response habituation to repeated presentations of ingroup faces with sustained responses to outgroup faces. The present results suggest that amygdala responses to human face stimuli are affected by the relationship between the perceived race of the stimulus face and that of the subject. Results are discussed as consistent with a role for the amygdala in encoding socially and/or biologically relevant information. We conclude that researchers seeking to study brain responses to face stimuli in human subjects should consider the relationship between the race of subjects and stimuli as a significant potential source of variance. Moreover, these data provide a foundation for future related studies in the neuroscience of social cognition and race.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study in healthy adult participants using face-viewing task comparing racial ingroup vs outgroup faces — a social-cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Participants appear to be healthy adults; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study in healthy adult subjects examining neural responses to racial ingroup vs outgroup faces — a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). The reported results describe significant BOLD signal differences in the amygdala for outgroup vs ingroup faces across subjects (a within-group contrast), and the authors subsequently conducted an ROI analysis on voxels identified from that effect, implying an initial voxelwise group-level task activation. No clinical or special groups are reported, and the contrast is a group-level, task-evoked effect generalizable to healthy adults. Although the excerpt does not explicitly list whole-brain statistical maps or coordinate tables, the description of identified voxels and group-level BOLD effects supports inclusion. Age range is not specified but participants are described as adult subjects. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: An oxytocin-induced facilitation of neural and emotional responses to social touch correlates inversely with autism traits.
studies.abstract: Social communication through touch and mutual grooming can convey highly salient socio-emotional signals and has been shown to involve the neuropeptide oxytocin (OXT) in several species. Less is known about the modulatory influence of OXT on the neural and emotional responses to human interpersonal touch. The present randomized placebo (PLC)-controlled within-subject pharmaco-functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) study was designed to test the hypothesis that a single intranasal dose of synthetic OXT (24 IU) would facilitate both neural and emotional responses to interpersonal touch in a context- (female vs male touch) and trait- (autistic trait load) specific manner. Specifically, the experimental rationale was to manipulate the reward value of interpersonal touch independent of the intensity and type of actual cutaneous stimulation administered. Thus, 40 heterosexual males believed that they were touched by either a man or a woman, although in fact an identical pattern of touch was always given by the same female experimenter blind to condition type. Our results show that OXT increased the perceived pleasantness of female, but not male touch, and associated neural responses in insula, precuneus, orbitofrontal, and pregenual anterior cingulate cortex. Moreover, the behavioral and neural effects of OXT were negatively correlated with autistic-like traits. Taken together, this is the first study to show that the perceived hedonic value of human heterosexual interpersonal touch is facilitated by OXT in men, but that its behavioral and neural effects in this context are blunted in individuals with autistic traits.
studies.journal: Neuropsychopharmacology : official publication of the American College of Neuropsychopharmacology
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Randomized within-subject pharmaco-fMRI in 40 healthy adult males assessing neural and emotional responses to interpersonal touch (social communication/affiliation). Fits inclusion: fMRI, social-related task, healthy adults 17–65. Not a review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI task study of social-related processing (social interpersonal touch/affiliation). Sample comprises 40 healthy adult males (mean age 25.8), meeting the age and healthy-sample criteria. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked activation maps and statistical results (whole-brain contrasts, coordinate tables, PFWE-corrected clusters, figures) for the healthy/control group. Analyses are not restricted to ROI-only or resting-state/connectivity-only approaches. Results are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated.

studies.title: Common and distinct neural mechanisms of the fundamental dimensions of social cognition.
studies.abstract: In the present study, we used a valence classification task to investigate the common and distinct neural basis of the two fundamental dimensions of social cognition (agency and communion) using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). The results showed that several brain areas associated with mentalizing, along with the inferior parietal gyrus in the mirror system, showed overlap in response to both agentic and communal words. These findings suggest that both content categories are related to the neural basis of social cognition; further, several areas in the default mode network (DMN) showed similar deactivations between agency and communion, reflecting task-induced deactivation (TID). In terms of distinct activations, the findings indicated greater deactivations for communal than agentic content in the ventral anterior cingulate (vACC) and medial orbitofrontal cortex (mOFC). Communion also showed greater activation in some visual areas compared to agentic content, including occipital gyrus, lingual gyrus, and fusiform gyrus. These activations may reflect greater allocation of attentional resources to visual areas when processing communal content, or inhibition of cognitive activity irrelevant to task performance. If so, this suggests greater attention and engagement with communion-related content. The present research thus suggests common and differential activations for agency- versus communion-related content.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study examining social cognition (agency and communion) using a valence classification task in humans. Abstract indicates social-related processing; however participant demographics/health status and ages are not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is a task-based fMRI study of social cognition (agency vs. communion) in healthy adults (n=42, ages 18–25). It reports group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise contrasts (agency vs. fixation/implicit baseline, communion vs. fixation/implicit baseline, conjunctions, and direct contrasts) analyzed in SPM8 with AlphaSim correction and tables/figures of activations. The sample is within the 17–65 range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity/resting analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusions.

studies.title: Abnormal cortical voice processing in autism.
studies.abstract: Impairments in social interaction are a key feature of autism and are associated with atypical social information processing. Here we report functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) results showing that individuals with autism failed to activate superior temporal sulcus (STS) voice-selective regions in response to vocal sounds, whereas they showed a normal activation pattern in response to nonvocal sounds. These findings suggest abnormal cortical processing of socially relevant auditory information in autism.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study on voice processing (social auditory information), relevant to social communication. Abstract implies comparison to normal activation patterns, suggesting healthy control data, but does not explicitly state controls or ages. Because inclusion hinges on presence of healthy adults and abstract is not fully explicit, include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (voice perception—a social-perceptual task). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=8 males, mean age 27.1) reported separately from the autism group. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, task-evoked univariate analyses for the control group (random-effects analysis, P < 0.001 corrected) with figures and supplementary tables of activation peaks (voice > non-voice). No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, healthy adults within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: Human fronto-mesolimbic networks guide decisions about charitable donation.
studies.abstract: Humans often sacrifice material benefits to endorse or to oppose societal causes based on moral beliefs. Charitable donation behavior, which has been the target of recent experimental economics studies, is an outstanding contemporary manifestation of this ability. Yet the neural bases of this unique aspect of human altruism, which extends beyond interpersonal interactions, remain obscure. In this article, we use functional magnetic resonance imaging while participants anonymously donated to or opposed real charitable organizations related to major societal causes. We show that the mesolimbic reward system is engaged by donations in the same way as when monetary rewards are obtained. Furthermore, medial orbitofrontal-subgenual and lateral orbitofrontal areas, which also play key roles in more primitive mechanisms of social attachment and aversion, specifically mediate decisions to donate or to oppose societal causes. Remarkably, more anterior sectors of the prefrontal cortex are distinctively recruited when altruistic choices prevail over selfish material interests.
studies.journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of charitable donation decisions (social decision-making/altruism), implicating affiliation/attachment and perception/understanding of others. Conducted in human participants (healthy adults likely within 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of charitable donation and altruistic decisions—socially relevant constructs (affiliation/attachment, moral/social judgment). Sample: 19 healthy adult participants (mean age 28.2), within the 17–65 range. Analyses: group-level, random-effects, univariate whole-brain contrasts are reported (GLM contrasts, conjunctions, tables of activations/coordinates and cluster thresholds are described), not limited to ROI or connectivity-only results. The task is a social-related, decision-making paradigm (donate/oppose causes) and results are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not a non-empirical paper, and healthy adults reported separately). Therefore the paper meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: Reading a suspenseful literary text activates brain areas related to social cognition and predictive inference.
studies.abstract: Stories can elicit powerful emotions. A key emotional response to narrative plots (e.g., novels, movies, etc.) is suspense. Suspense appears to build on basic aspects of human cognition such as processes of expectation, anticipation, and prediction. However, the neural processes underlying emotional experiences of suspense have not been previously investigated. We acquired functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) data while participants read a suspenseful literary text (E.T.A. Hoffmann's "The Sandman") subdivided into short text passages. Individual ratings of experienced suspense obtained after each text passage were found to be related to activation in the medial frontal cortex, bilateral frontal regions (along the inferior frontal sulcus), lateral premotor cortex, as well as posterior temporal and temporo-parietal areas. The results indicate that the emotional experience of suspense depends on brain areas associated with social cognition and predictive inference.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study in which participants read a narrative; reported activations are in brain regions associated with social cognition and predictive inference, indicating a social-related task (perception/understanding of others). Abstract does not report participant ages or explicit health status, so include for full-text review to confirm sample meets age and health criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task involves social-related processing—reading suspenseful text engages mentalizing/theory-of-mind (authors interpret suspense-related activations in medial frontal cortex and TPJ as social-cognitive/mentalizing processes). (2) Sample: healthy adult participants (N=23; ages 19–32). (3) Whole-brain evidence: group-level, voxelwise random-effects GLM results reported for the parametric suspense regressor (cluster-level FWE-corrected maps and tables of peak coordinates). Not excluded by any criterion: analyses include whole-brain univariate task activations (not ROI-only), and results are reported for the healthy group. Therefore the study is eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis of social-related fMRI processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: Hyperintentionality during automatic perception of naturalistic cooperative behavior in patients with schizophrenia.
studies.abstract: Social cognition and the corresponding functionality of involved brain networks are essential for effortless social interaction. Patients with schizophrenia exhibit impaired social functioning. In this study, we focused on the neural networks involved in the automatic perception of cooperative behavior and their alterations in schizophrenia. We performed a functional magnetic resonance imaging study of 19 schizophrenia patients and 19 healthy matched controls. Participants watched a set of short videos with two actors manipulating objects, either with (C+) or without cooperation (C-). Additionally, we assessed delusional symptoms in patients using the Scales for the Assessment of Positive Symptoms and psychosis proneness in healthy controls using the brief schizotypal personality questionnaire. The observed group-by-condition interaction revealed a contrasting activation pattern for patients versus healthy controls in the medial and lateral prefrontal cortex, the middle cingulate cortex, and the left angular gyrus. Furthermore, increased activation of the middle prefrontal areas, left angular gyrus, and the posterior sulcus temporalis superior in response to the noncooperative condition (C-) was positively correlated with delusional symptoms in patients. Our findings suggest an overactivated "theory of mind" network in patients for the processing of noncooperative behavior. Thus, "overmentalizing" might be based on delusions and altered processing of cooperative behavior in patients with schizophrenia.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of social cognition (automatic perception of cooperative behavior) with a healthy matched control group (19 controls) and patient group; task is social-related and meets inclusion. Although ages aren’t specified, 'matched controls' implies adult participants; include for full-text review to confirm age range.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social perception (automatic perception of cooperative vs noncooperative behavior), with a healthy control group of adults (n=19) reported separately alongside a clinical group. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts for the healthy control group (e.g., C+ > C–) with voxelwise statistical results (FDR/FWE-corrected), coordinates, figures, and text description. It is not ROI-only and not limited to connectivity or resting-state analyses. Participant ages are described as adults and groups were matched; healthy-group whole-brain maps are clearly presented and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

studies.title: Dissecting social interaction: dual-fMRI reveals patterns of interpersonal brain-behavior relationships that dissociate among dimensions of social exchange.
studies.abstract: During social interactions, each individual's actions are simultaneously a consequence of and an antecedent to their interaction partner's behavior. Capturing online the brain processes underlying such mutual dependency requires simultaneous measurements of all interactants' brains during real-world exchange ('hyperscanning'). This demands a precise characterization of the type of interaction under investigation, however, and analytical techniques capable of capturing interpersonal dependencies. We adapted an interactive task capable of dissociating between two dimensions of interdependent social exchange: goal structure (cooperation vs competition) and interaction structure [concurrent (CN) vs turn-based]. Performing dual-functional magnetic resonance imaging hyperscanning on pairs of individuals interacting on this task, and modeling brain responses in both interactants as systematic reactions to their partner's behavior, we investigated interpersonal brain-behavior dependencies (iBBDs) during each dimension. This revealed patterns of iBBDs that differentiated among exchanges; in players supporting the actions of another, greater brain responses to the co-player's actions were expressed in regions implicated in social cognition, such as the medial prefrontal cortex, precuneus and temporal cortices. Stronger iBBD during CN competitive exchanges was observed in brain systems involved in movement planning and updating, however, such as the supplementary motor area. This demonstrates the potential for hyperscanning to elucidate neural processes underlying different forms of social exchange.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Study used fMRI hyperscanning during an interactive social-exchange task probing social cognition (cooperation/competition), which aligns with the review objective. The abstract does not state participant ages or health status; per screening rules, if information is insufficient for exclusion, include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI hyperscanning study of healthy adult participants (N=44; mean age 22.4) performing an interactive social task (pattern game) manipulating cooperation/competition and interaction structure — clearly a social-processing paradigm. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate GLM analyses (FEAT/FLAME) with non-parametric permutation correction (randomize/TFCE), provides clusterwise results and coordinate tables/thresholded maps, and describes group effects generalizable to healthy adults. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and participants fall within the 17–65 range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

studies.title: Common and distinct networks for self-referential and social stimulus processing in the human brain.
studies.abstract: Self-referential processing is a complex cognitive function, involving a set of implicit and explicit processes, complicating investigation of its distinct neural signature. The present study explores the functional overlap and dissociability of self-referential and social stimulus processing. We combined an established paradigm for explicit self-referential processing with an implicit social stimulus processing paradigm in one fMRI experiment to determine the neural effects of self-relatedness and social processing within one study. Overlapping activations were found in the orbitofrontal cortex and in the intermediate part of the precuneus. Stimuli judged as self-referential specifically activated the posterior cingulate cortex, the ventral medial prefrontal cortex, extending into anterior cingulate cortex and orbitofrontal cortex, the dorsal medial prefrontal cortex, the ventral and dorsal lateral prefrontal cortex, the left inferior temporal gyrus, and occipital cortex. Social processing specifically involved the posterior precuneus and bilateral temporo-parietal junction. Taken together, our data show, not only, first, common networks for both processes in the medial prefrontal and the medial parietal cortex, but also, second, functional differentiations for self-referential processing versus social processing: an anterior-posterior gradient for social processing and self-referential processing within the medial parietal cortex and specific activations for self-referential processing in the medial and lateral prefrontal cortex and for social processing in the temporo-parietal junction.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study explicitly examining self-referential and social stimulus processing (social-related constructs). Abstract does not state participant ages or explicit healthy status, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=28, age 30–50) that explicitly investigates self-referential and social stimulus processing. The task includes social-related stimuli (pictures depicting humans) and a self-referential judgment; analyses report group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (main effects, conjunctions, direct contrasts and interactions) with FDR correction and coordinate tables/figures. Results for the healthy sample are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The paper is not limited to ROI, connectivity-only, patient-only, or non-empirical analyses. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

studies.title: The role of the fusiform face area in social cognition: implications for the pathobiology of autism.
studies.abstract: A region in the lateral aspect of the fusiform gyrus (FG) is more engaged by human faces than any other category of image. It has come to be known as the 'fusiform face area' (FFA). The origin and extent of this specialization is currently a topic of great interest and debate. This is of special relevance to autism, because recent studies have shown that the FFA is hypoactive to faces in this disorder. In two linked functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) studies of healthy young adults, we show here that the FFA is engaged by a social attribution task (SAT) involving perception of human-like interactions among three simple geometric shapes. The amygdala, temporal pole, medial prefrontal cortex, inferolateral frontal cortex and superior temporal sulci were also significantly engaged. Activation of the FFA to a task without faces challenges the received view that the FFA is restricted in its activities to the perception of faces. We speculate that abstract semantic information associated with faces is encoded in the FG region and retrieved for social computations. From this perspective, the literature on hypoactivation of the FFA in autism may be interpreted as a reflection of a core social cognitive mechanism underlying the disorder.
studies.journal: Philosophical transactions of the Royal Society of London. Series B, Biological sciences
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI was performed in healthy young adults during a social attribution task (perception/interpretation of human-like interactions). This directly matches the review objective and inclusion criteria (social-related processing in healthy adults). Not a review/meta-analysis, so include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy young adults using a social attribution task (perception/understanding of others), directly addressing the review objective. The abstract reports group-level activations in multiple brain regions (FFA, amygdala, temporal pole, medial PFC, STS), indicating whole-brain, task-evoked univariate results rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. The sample is healthy adults, and the reported effects are described at the group level and are generalizable to healthy participants. No exclusion criteria are met (not a review, not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, and participants are within the 17–65 age range). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria and should be INCLUDED.

studies.title: Neural responses to visually observed social interactions.
studies.abstract: Success in the social world requires the ability to perceive not just individuals and their actions, but pairs of people and the interactions between them. Despite the complexity of social interactions, humans are adept at interpreting those interactions they observe. Although the brain basis of this remarkable ability has remained relatively unexplored, converging functional MRI evidence suggests the posterior superior temporal sulcus (pSTS) is centrally involved. Here, we sought to determine whether this region is sensitive to both the presence of interactive information, as well as to the content of qualitatively different interactions (i.e. competition vs. cooperation). Using point-light human figure stimuli, we demonstrate that the right pSTS is maximally activated when contrasting dyadic interactions vs. dyads performing independent, non-interactive actions. We then used this task to localize the same pSTS region in an independent participant group, and tested responses to non-human moving shape stimuli (i.e. two circles' movements conveying either interactive or non-interactive behaviour). We observed significant support vector machine classification for both the presence and type of interaction (i.e. interaction vs. non-interaction, and competition vs. cooperation, respectively) in the pSTS, as well as neighbouring temporo-parietal junction (TPJ). These findings demonstrate the important role that these regions play in perceiving and understanding social interactions, and lay the foundations for further research to fully characterize interaction responses in these areas.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Task-based fMRI study investigating perception/understanding of social interactions (interaction presence and type). Abstract describes neural responses to social interaction stimuli and classifiers in pSTS/TPJ—directly relevant. Participant health status and ages are not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm at least one healthy adult group (17–65).
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social interaction perception in healthy adults (experiments: N=49, ages 19–34; and N=23, ages 18–30). Tasks probe perception and understanding of others (observed social interactions vs independent actions; cooperation vs competition). The paper reports group-level whole-brain univariate analyses (e.g., group contrast interaction > independent actions with FDR-corrected clusters in pSTS; whole-brain thresholds and maps described) and provides voxelwise contrast results/generalizable healthy-group findings. Analyses include whole-brain random-effects group analysis and reported corrected results; results for healthy adult participants are reported separately. No exclusion criteria apply (not only ROI/FC/resting, not only between-group contrasts, participants within 17–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: What's in a smile? Neural correlates of facial embodiment during social interaction.
studies.abstract: Previous investigations have shown that the perception of socially relevant facial expressions, indicating someone else's intention to communicate (e.g., smiling), correlate with increased activity in zygomaticus major muscle regardless of whether the facial expressions seen are directed towards the human observer or toward someone else (Mojzisch et al., 2006). These spontaneous, involuntary reactions have been described as facial mimicry and seem to be of considerable importance for successful interpersonal communication. We investigated whether specific neural substrates underlie these responses by performing a finite impulse response (FIR) analysis of an experiment using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to investigate the perception of socially relevant facial expressions (Schilbach et al., 2006). This analysis demonstrates that differential neural activity can be detected relative to the FIR time window in which facial mimicry occurs. The neural network found includes but extends beyond classical motor regions (face motor area) recruiting brain regions known to be involved in social cognition. This network is proposed to subserve the integration of emotional and action-related processes as part of a pre-reflective, embodied reaction to the perception of socially relevant facial expressions as well as a reflective representation of self and other.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of perception of socially relevant facial expressions and neural correlates of facial mimicry, addressing social communication and perception/understanding of others. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not state participant ages explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult (17–65) sample.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social processing: participants passively viewed socially relevant vs. arbitrary facial expressions in a social-interaction paradigm. Sample: 17 healthy adults (right-handed males, mean age 25.9) within the 17–65 range. Whole-brain, voxelwise, group-level univariate analyses were reported (SPM5 random-effects ANOVA; FIR model; whole-brain coverage) with thresholding and coordinates presented (figures/tables and MNI peak coordinates for the main effect of SOC/time-bin 5). The reported effects are task-evoked, generalizable to the healthy group, and not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only results. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the paper meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Neural dynamics of social tie formation in economic decision-making.
studies.abstract: The disposition for prosocial conduct, which contributes to cooperation as arising during social interaction, requires cortical network dynamics responsive to the development of social ties, or care about the interests of specific interaction partners. Here, we formulate a dynamic computational model that accurately predicted how tie formation, driven by the interaction history, influences decisions to contribute in a public good game. We used model-driven functional MRI to test the hypothesis that brain regions key to social interactions keep track of dynamics in tie strength. Activation in the medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC) and posterior cingulate cortex tracked the individual's public good contributions. Activation in the bilateral posterior superior temporal sulcus (pSTS), and temporo-parietal junction was modulated parametrically by the dynamically developing social tie-as estimated by our model-supporting a role of these regions in social tie formation. Activity in these two regions further reflected inter-individual differences in tie persistence and sensitivity to behavior of the interaction partner. Functional connectivity between pSTS and mPFC activations indicated that the representation of social ties is integrated in the decision process. These data reveal the brain mechanisms underlying the integration of interaction dynamics into a social tie representation which in turn influenced the individual's prosocial decisions.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract describes an fMRI study of social tie formation during a public good game—a social-related task involving understanding others and prosocial decisions. The abstract does not state participant ages or health status, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (25 scanned participants, ages ~22) using a social-interaction task (repeated pairwise public good game) that probes affiliation/other-regarding preferences. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked results (parametric modulation of tie, impulse, contribution magnitude) with MNI coordinates, cluster-wise FWE correction and figures/tables of activation maps. Analyses include voxelwise GLM contrasts and parametric modulators; results are clearly reported for the healthy/control group. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and participants fall within the target age range. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

studies.title: The neural basis of event simulation: an FMRI study.
studies.abstract: Event simulation (ES) is the situational inference process in which perceived event features such as objects, agents, and actions are associated in the brain to represent the whole situation. ES provides a common basis for various cognitive processes, such as perceptual prediction, situational understanding/prediction, and social cognition (such as mentalizing/trait inference). Here, functional magnetic resonance imaging was used to elucidate the neural substrates underlying important subdivisions within ES. First, the study investigated whether ES depends on different neural substrates when it is conducted explicitly and implicitly. Second, the existence of neural substrates specific to the future-prediction component of ES was assessed. Subjects were shown contextually related object pictures implying a situation and performed several picture-word-matching tasks. By varying task goals, subjects were made to infer the implied situation implicitly/explicitly or predict the future consequence of that situation. The results indicate that, whereas implicit ES activated the lateral prefrontal cortex and medial/lateral parietal cortex, explicit ES activated the medial prefrontal cortex, posterior cingulate cortex, and medial/lateral temporal cortex. Additionally, the left temporoparietal junction plays an important role in the future-prediction component of ES. These findings enrich our understanding of the neural substrates of the implicit/explicit/predictive aspects of ES-related cognitive processes.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study examining event simulation with tasks involving situational inference and future prediction; authors explicitly link ES to social cognition (mentalizing/trait inference). Abstract confirms fMRI and social-related processing but does not report participant ages/health; include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample (17–65).
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is a task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (n=20, mean age 20.65 within 17–65). The paper investigates event simulation tied to situational understanding and social cognition (references to theory-of-mind, trait inference; separate analyses for social vs non-social trials). The authors report group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (e.g., Imp–Con, Exp–Imp, Ftr–Exp) with cluster-level multiple-comparison correction and peak coordinates, and random-effects second-level inference — satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, not non-empirical). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for healthy adult whole-brain social-related fMRI task studies.

studies.title: Classification of social anhedonia using temporal and spatial network features from a social cognition fMRI task.
studies.abstract: Previous studies have suggested that the degree of social anhedonia reflects the vulnerability for developing schizophrenia. However, only few studies have investigated how functional network changes are related to social anhedonia. The aim of this fMRI study was to classify subjects according to their degree of social anhedonia using supervised machine learning. More specifically, we extracted both spatial and temporal network features during a social cognition task from 70 subjects, and used support vector machines for classification. Since impairment in social cognition is well established in schizophrenia-spectrum disorders, the subjects performed a comic strip task designed to specifically probe theory of mind (ToM) and empathy processing. Features representing both temporal (time series) and network dynamics were extracted using task activation maps, seed region analysis, independent component analysis (ICA), and a newly developed multi-subject archetypal analysis (MSAA), which here aimed to further bridge aspects of both seed region analysis and decomposition by incorporating a spotlight approach.We found significant classification of subjects with elevated levels of social anhedonia when using the times series extracted using MSAA, indicating that temporal dynamics carry important information for classification of social anhedonia. Interestingly, we found that the same time series yielded the highest classification performance in a task classification of the ToM condition. Finally, the spatial network corresponding to that time series included both prefrontal and temporal-parietal regions as well as insula activity, which previously have been related schizotypy and the development of schizophrenia.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study using a social cognition task (theory of mind/empathy) with 70 human subjects; addresses social-related processing. Not a review. Abstract implies healthy participants (classification across levels of social anhedonia) and fits the review objective.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-cognition task (Theory of Mind and empathy comic-strip task) in a healthy adult sample (76 college students, ages 17–21). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain SPM activation maps (ToM vs control, Empathy vs control, pooled condition) with random-field-theory correction and uses these maps in analyses; thus whole-brain task-evoked results for the healthy group are available. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, and participants fall within the 17–65 range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: Abnormal Social Reward Responses in Anorexia Nervosa: An fMRI Study.
studies.abstract: Patients with anorexia nervosa (AN) display impaired social interactions, implicated in the development and prognosis of the disorder. Importantly, social behavior is modulated by reward-based processes, and dysfunctional at-brain-level reward responses have been involved in AN neurobiological models. However, no prior evidence exists of whether these neural alterations would be equally present in social contexts. In this study, we conducted a cross-sectional social-judgment functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) study of 20 restrictive-subtype AN patients and 20 matched healthy controls. Brain activity during acceptance and rejection was investigated and correlated with severity measures (Eating Disorder Inventory -EDI-2) and with personality traits of interest known to modulate social behavior (The Sensitivity to Punishment and Sensitivity to Reward Questionnaire). Patients showed hypoactivation of the dorsomedial prefrontal cortex (DMPFC) during social acceptance and hyperactivation of visual areas during social rejection. Ventral striatum activation during rejection was positively correlated in patients with clinical severity scores. During acceptance, activation of the frontal opercula-anterior insula and dorsomedial/dorsolateral prefrontal cortices was differentially associated with reward sensitivity between groups. These results suggest an abnormal motivational drive for social stimuli, and involve overlapping social cognition and reward systems leading to a disruption of adaptive responses in the processing of social reward. The specific association of reward-related regions with clinical and psychometric measures suggests the putative involvement of reward structures in the maintenance of pathological behaviors in AN.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Cross-sectional fMRI study using a social-judgment task (acceptance/rejection), directly assessing social-related processing. Includes a matched healthy control group (20 adults) within the target age range. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: The study includes a healthy adult control group (20 females, mean age 28.15) and uses task-based fMRI of social processing (social judgment/feedback). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise within-group task contrasts for controls (acceptance>control and rejection>control) with cluster correction and lists activations (e.g., ventral striatum, anterior insula, medial prefrontal cortex). Results for the healthy group are reported separately and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, or absent healthy-group whole-brain maps) are violated.

studies.title: Epigenetic modification of OXT and human sociability.
studies.abstract: Across many mammalian species there exist genetic and biological systems that facilitate the tendency to be social. Oxytocin is a neuropeptide involved in social-approach behaviors in humans and others mammals. Although there exists a large, mounting body of evidence showing that oxytocin signaling genes are associated with human sociability, very little is currently known regarding the way the structural gene for oxytocin (OXT) confers individual differences in human sociability. In this study, we undertook a comprehensive approach to investigate the association between epigenetic modification of OXT via DNA methylation, and overt measures of social processing, including self-report, behavior, and brain function and structure. Genetic data were collected via saliva samples and analyzed to target and quantify DNA methylation across the promoter region of OXT We observed a consistent pattern of results across sociability measures. People that exhibit lower OXT DNA methylation (presumably linked to higher OXT expression) display more secure attachment styles, improved ability to recognize emotional facial expressions, greater superior temporal sulcus activity during two social-cognitive functional MRI tasks, and larger fusiform gyrus gray matter volume than people that exhibit higher OXT DNA methylation. These findings provide empirical evidence that epigenetic modification of OXT is linked to several overt measures of sociability in humans and serve to advance progress in translational social neuroscience research toward a better understanding of the evolutionary and genetic basis of normal and abnormal human sociability.
studies.journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract reports participants completed two social-cognitive functional MRI tasks (showing superior temporal sulcus activity) and assesses social processing measures; no indication participants had psychiatric/neurological disorders. Meets criteria for fMRI social-related task in healthy adults.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Uses task-based fMRI with two social-cognitive tasks (emotional perspective-taking and emotion attribution) that probe perception/understanding of others (social-related processing). (2) Sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=121 for fMRI tasks; overall n=129; age 18–35), within the 17–65 range. (3) Reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts (emotion perspective-taking > shape match; emotion attribution > gender match) with family-wise error correction and subsequent whole-brain regression analyses; results are described and localized (STS, fusiform, IFG) and thus generalizable to the healthy group. Not excluded by any exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not resting-state/ connectivity only). Therefore include for meta-analysis of healthy adult task fMRI social processing.
studies.full_text_path: /home/zorro/repos/autonima-results/social-processing/ace_scrape/articles/html/Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America/27325757.html

studies.title: The neural basis of understanding the expression of the emotions in man and animals.
studies.abstract: Humans cannot help but attribute human emotions to non-human animals. Although such attributions are often regarded as gratuitous anthropomorphisms and held apart from the attributions humans make about each other's internal states, they may be the product of a general mechanism for flexibly interpreting adaptive behavior. To examine this, we used functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) in humans to compare the neural mechanisms associated with attributing emotions to humans and non-human animal behavior. Although undergoing fMRI, participants first passively observed the facial displays of human, non-human primate and domestic dogs, and subsequently judged the acceptability of emotional (e.g. 'annoyed') and facial descriptions (e.g. 'baring teeth') for the same images. For all targets, emotion attributions selectively activated regions in prefrontal and anterior temporal cortices associated with causal explanation in prior studies. These regions were similarly activated by both human and non-human targets even during the passive observation task; moreover, the degree of neural similarity was dependent on participants' self-reported beliefs in the mental capacities of non-human animals. These results encourage a non-anthropocentric view of emotion understanding, one that treats the idea that animals have emotions as no more gratuitous than the idea that humans other than ourselves do.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Human fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing social-cognitive tasks (passive observation and emotion attribution judgments about human and non-human faces). Examines perception/understanding of others, fitting the review objective and inclusion criteria; not a review article.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (attribution of emotions/understanding others) using healthy adult participants (final samples: Explicit Task n=16, Implicit Task n=17; ages 21–46). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., Emotion > Expression; Face > Scramble) with whole-brain cluster-level FWE correction and conjunction analyses, not limited to ROI-only results. Healthy-group within-subject contrasts are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, patient-only, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: The Neural Responses to Social Cooperation in Gain and Loss Context.
studies.abstract: Cooperation is pervasive and constitutes the core behavioral principle of human social life. Previous studies have revealed that mutual cooperation was reliably correlated with two reward-related brain regions, the ventral striatum and the orbitofrontal cortex. Using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), this study sought to investigate how the loss and gain contexts modulated the neural responses to mutual cooperation. Twenty-five female participants were scanned when they played a series of one-shot prisoner's dilemma games in the loss and gain contexts. Specifically, participants and partners independently chose to either cooperate with each other or not, and each was awarded or deprived of (in the gain context or the loss context, respectively) a sum of money which depended upon the interaction of their choices. Behavioral results indicated that participants cooperated in nearly half of the experiment trials and reported higher level of positive emotions for mutual cooperation in both contexts, but they cooperated more in the gain than in the loss context. At the neural level, stronger activities in the orbitofrontal cortex were observed for mutual cooperation compared with the other three outcomes in both contexts, while stronger activation in ventral striatum associated with mutual cooperation was observed in the gain context only. Together, our data indicated that, even in the one-shot interaction under loss context, participants still exhibited preference for cooperation and the rewarding experience from a mutually cooperative social interaction activated the ventral striatum and the orbitofrontal cortex, but the loss context weakened the association between the ventral striatum activation and mutual cooperation.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study where healthy adult participants performed a social task (one-shot prisoner's dilemma). Reports neural responses to social cooperation; meets inclusion criteria. Age range not stated but participants appear to be healthy adults—include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study used task-based fMRI during a social interaction task (a one-shot Prisoner’s Dilemma) directly addressing social cooperation. The sample comprises healthy adult participants (final imaging N=18; mean age ~21, within 17–65). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked activation results (contrasts such as CC vs. other outcomes), including MNI coordinates, cluster statistics, and FWE-corrected thresholds, not ROI-only analyses. Results are presented clearly for the healthy control group and are generalizable to healthy adults (although sampled from young adult females only). No exclusion criteria are violated (not resting-state/connectivity-only, not a methods/review paper, and healthy adults are within age range). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Neural correlates of enhanced visual short-term memory for angry faces: an FMRI study.
studies.abstract: Fluid and effective social communication requires that both face identity and emotional expression information are encoded and maintained in visual short-term memory (VSTM) to enable a coherent, ongoing picture of the world and its players. This appears to be of particular evolutionary importance when confronted with potentially threatening displays of emotion - previous research has shown better VSTM for angry versus happy or neutral face identities.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: FMRI study examining visual short-term memory for emotional (angry) faces — a social perception/communication task. Abstract indicates task-based fMRI and likely healthy adult participants; no exclusion criteria met. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: The study is an fMRI task-based investigation of face identity and emotional-expression processing (social perception of others) in healthy adult participants (N=35, mean age 29). It reports whole-brain, group-level random-effects voxelwise analyses (ANCOVA) with FDR-corrected maps, specific voxel coordinates, contrasts (e.g., angry vs neutral), and reported correlations with behavior — meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, or non-empirical) are violated.

studies.title: The selectivity and functional connectivity of the anterior temporal lobes.
studies.abstract: One influential account asserts that the anterior temporal lobe (ATL) is a domain-general hub for semantic memory. Other evidence indicates it is part of a domain-specific social cognition system. Arbitrating these accounts using functional magnetic resonance imaging has previously been difficult because of magnetic susceptibility artifacts in the region. The present study used parameters optimized for imaging the ATL, and had subjects encode facts about unfamiliar people, buildings, and hammers. Using both conjunction and region of interest analyses, person-selective responses were observed in both the left and right ATL. Neither building-selective, hammer-selective nor domain-general responses were observed in the ATLs, although they were observed in other brain regions. These findings were supported by "resting-state" functional connectivity analyses using independent datasets from the same subjects. Person-selective ATL clusters were functionally connected with the brain's wider social cognition network. Rather than serving as a domain-general semantic hub, the ATLs work in unison with the social cognition system to support learning facts about others.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study where subjects encoded facts about unfamiliar people, showing person-selective ATL responses and connectivity with social cognition network—addresses perception/understanding of others. Abstract lacks explicit participant ages/health; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task is social-related—learning facts about persons and contrasts person > building/hammer targeting social/person knowledge; (2) Sample comprises healthy adults (12 right-handed, age 20–32); (3) Reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked analyses (conjunctions, voxelwise contrasts, cluster-corrected maps and ROI-corrected thresholds) with results described in text, figures, and supplementary material; (4) Not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

Reporting the t-statistic associated with this average t score would be misleading, as this value would underestimate the true differences between the 2 conditions, even though it would itself clear the threshold for statistical significance. studies.title: Deciphering human motion to discriminate social interactions: a developmental neuroimaging study.
studies.abstract: Non-verbal communication plays a major role in social interaction understanding. Using functional magnetic resonance imaging, we explored the development of the neural networks involved in social interaction recognition based on human motion in children (8-11), adolescents (13-17), and adults (20-41). Participants watched point-light videos depicting two actors interacting or moving independently and were asked whether these agents were interacting or not. All groups successfully performed the discrimination task, but children had a lower performance and longer response times than the older groups. In all three groups, the posterior parts of the superior temporal sulci and middle temporal gyri, the inferior frontal gyri and the anterior temporal lobes showed greater activation when observing social interactions. In addition, adolescents and adults recruited the caudate nucleus and some frontal regions that are part of the mirror system. Adults showed greater activations in parietal and frontal regions (part of them belonging to the social brain) than adolescents.An increased number of regions that are part of the mirror system network or the social brain, as well as the caudate nucleus, were recruited with age. In conclusion, a shared set of brain regions enabling the discrimination of social interactions from neutral movements through human motion is already present in 8-year-old children. Developmental processes such as refinements in the social brain and mirror system would help grasping subtle cues in non-verbal aspects of social interactions.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study where healthy adult participants (ages 20–41) performed a social interaction discrimination task (point-light displays). Meets inclusion: social-related task, healthy adults 17–65 present. Not a review/meta-analysis.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study reports task-based fMRI of social interaction (SI) recognition using point-light displays — a social-related task. It includes a healthy adult group (n=16, mean age 28.8) within the 17–65 range and reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (SI > NM) analyzed with SPM8, including thresholding and FWE cluster/peak information for the adult group. Healthy adult results are presented separately from child/adolescent groups. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, or lacking healthy adult whole-brain task maps) apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Observing social interactions: the effect of gaze.
studies.abstract: Our social abilities depend on specialized brain systems that allow us to perform crucial operations such as interpreting the actions of others. This functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) study investigated whether human brain activity evoked by the observation of social interactions is modulated by gaze. During scanning participants observed social or individual actions performed by agents whose gaze could be either available or masked. Results demonstrated that the observation of social interactions evoked activity within a dorsal sector of the medial prefrontal cortex (MPFC), an area classically involved in social cognition. Importantly, activity within this area was modulated by whether the gaze of the agents performing the observed action was or was not available. The implications of these findings for a role played by the dorsal medial prefrontal cortex (dMPFC) in terms of inferential processes concerned with social interactions are considered.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study examining observation of social interactions and gaze—clearly a social-related task targeting social cognition. Abstract does not specify participant ages/health; include for full-text review to confirm that participants are healthy adults (17–65).
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (N=17, mean age 26). The task probes social-related constructs (observation of social vs. individual actions; gaze manipulation). They conducted whole-brain, voxelwise random-effects analyses using SPM and report group-level univariate contrasts, activation maps, and tables of coordinates for main effects and interactions (dMPFC, pSTS, amygdala, IFG, etc.). The paper is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and reports healthy-group whole-brain task effects generalizable to healthy adults. All inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are violated.

studies.title: Functional MRI reveals expert-novice differences during sport-related anticipation.
studies.abstract: We examined the effect of expertise on cortical activation during sports anticipation using functional MRI. In experiment 1, recreational players predicted badminton stroke direction and the pattern of active clusters was consistent with a proposed perception-of-action network. This pattern was not replicated in a stimulus-matched, action-unrelated control task. In experiment 2, players of three different skill levels anticipated stroke direction from clips occluded either 160 ms before or 80 ms after racquet-shuttle contact. Early-occluded sequences produced more activation than late-occluded sequences overall, in most cortical regions of interest, but experts showed an additional enhancement in medial, dorsolateral and ventrolateral frontal cortex. Anticipation in open-skill sports engages cortical areas integral to observing and understanding others' actions; such activity is enhanced in experts.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI was conducted while healthy adult participants performed anticipation of others' actions in a sport context, which targets perception and understanding of others (a social processing construct). Participants appear to be healthy adults; study is original research, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient evidence to meet inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: The study uses task-based fMRI of action observation/anticipation, which fits the review construct 'Perception and Understanding of Others' (social-related processing). Participants are healthy adult badminton players (novices to international), and group-level whole-brain, univariate random-effects analyses are reported (shots–mctrl contrasts; maps/peak coordinates and figures reported; FWE-corrected thresholds). Although ROI analyses are also performed, whole-brain results are explicitly presented, satisfying the whole-brain evidence criterion. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state-only, participants are within adult range). Therefore the paper meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: The brain functional networks associated to human and animal suffering differ among omnivores, vegetarians and vegans.
studies.abstract: Empathy and affective appraisals for conspecifics are among the hallmarks of social interaction. Using functional MRI, we hypothesized that vegetarians and vegans, who made their feeding choice for ethical reasons, might show brain responses to conditions of suffering involving humans or animals different from omnivores. We recruited 20 omnivore subjects, 19 vegetarians, and 21 vegans. The groups were matched for sex and age. Brain activation was investigated using fMRI and an event-related design during observation of negative affective pictures of human beings and animals (showing mutilations, murdered people, human/animal threat, tortures, wounds, etc.). Participants saw negative-valence scenes related to humans and animals, alternating with natural landscapes. During human negative valence scenes, compared with omnivores, vegetarians and vegans had an increased recruitment of the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) and inferior frontal gyrus (IFG). More critically, during animal negative valence scenes, they had decreased amygdala activation and increased activation of the lingual gyri, the left cuneus, the posterior cingulate cortex and several areas mainly located in the frontal lobes, including the ACC, the IFG and the middle frontal gyrus. Nonetheless, also substantial differences between vegetarians and vegans have been found responding to negative scenes. Vegetarians showed a selective recruitment of the right inferior parietal lobule during human negative scenes, and a prevailing activation of the ACC during animal negative scenes. Conversely, during animal negative scenes an increased activation of the inferior prefrontal cortex was observed in vegans. These results suggest that empathy toward non conspecifics has different neural representation among individuals with different feeding habits, perhaps reflecting different motivational factors and beliefs.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study in healthy adult participants examining empathy/affective responses to human and animal suffering (social-related processing: perception/understanding of others). Groups are healthy omnivores, vegetarians, vegans. Meets inclusion (task-based fMRI of social processing); not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is a task-based fMRI study of social-related processing (empathy/social cognition: viewing human and animal suffering). Sample includes 60 healthy adults (ages 18–60) meeting the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked analyses (first-level contrasts and second-level random-effects ANOVA; one-sample and paired t-tests; coordinates in MNI space; results reported at p<0.05 FWE and in tables/figures). Analyses are not limited to ROIs, connectivity, or clinical subgroups. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.
