studies.title: The busy social brain: evidence for automaticity and control in the neural systems supporting social cognition and action understanding.
studies.abstract: Much social-cognitive processing is believed to occur automatically; however, the relative automaticity of the brain systems underlying social cognition remains largely undetermined. We used functional MRI to test for automaticity in the functioning of two brain systems that research has indicated are important for understanding other people's behavior: the mirror neuron system and the mentalizing system. Participants remembered either easy phone numbers (low cognitive load) or difficult phone numbers (high cognitive load) while observing actions after adopting one of four comprehension goals. For all four goals, mirror neuron system activation showed relatively little evidence of modulation by load; in contrast, the association of mentalizing system activation with the goal of inferring the actor's mental state was extinguished by increased cognitive load. These results support a dual-process model of the brain systems underlying action understanding and social cognition; the mirror neuron system supports automatic behavior identification, and the mentalizing system supports controlled social causal attribution.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study examining social cognition (mirror neuron and mentalizing systems) during social-related tasks. Likely uses healthy adult participants; ages not specified in abstract. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: Meets all inclusion criteria: task is an fMRI study of social cognition (action understanding/mentalizing), sample comprises healthy adults (N=19, ages 18–32) with group-level random-effects analyses reported. The paper reports univariate voxelwise task contrasts with coordinates and cluster results (Table 1) within an a priori mask and indicates whole-brain results are provided in the Supplemental Material, satisfying the requirement for group-level whole-brain task-evoked maps generalizable to healthy adults. It is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only contrasts, nor non-empirical work. Therefore it should be included in the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Brain imaging investigation of the neural correlates of observing virtual social interactions.
studies.abstract: The ability to gauge social interactions is crucial in the assessment of others' intentions. Factors such as facial expressions and body language affect our decisions in personal and professional life alike (1). These "friend or foe" judgements are often based on first impressions, which in turn may affect our decisions to "approach or avoid". Previous studies investigating the neural correlates of social cognition tended to use static facial stimuli (2). Here, we illustrate an experimental design in which whole-body animated characters were used in conjunction with functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) recordings. Fifteen participants were presented with short movie-clips of guest-host interactions in a business setting, while fMRI data were recorded; at the end of each movie, participants also provided ratings of the host behaviour. This design mimics more closely real-life situations, and hence may contribute to better understanding of the neural mechanisms of social interactions in healthy behaviour, and to gaining insight into possible causes of deficits in social behaviour in such clinical conditions as social anxiety and autism (3).
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI data were collected while healthy adult participants (n=15) viewed and rated animated social interactions—this is a social-processing task involving perception/understanding of others. Study is empirical (not a review) and fits age/healthy participant criteria. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study reports an fMRI task specifically probing social processing (observing virtual social interactions). Participants are described as typical/healthy volunteers with informed consent, and group-level results are reported from 15 participants. Data acquisition provided whole-brain coverage and preprocessing/analysis used SPM, and the paper presents group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked activation maps (figures showing STS, mPFC, amygdala activations) reflecting healthy-group effects. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, and participants appear to be healthy adults within the target age range). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: Functional neuroanatomy of body checking in people with anorexia nervosa.
studies.abstract: The neural correlates of body checking perceptions in eating disorders have not yet been identified. This functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging study examined the neuroanatomy involved in altered perception and identification with body checking in female with anorexia nervosa (AN).
studies.journal: The International journal of eating disorders
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract reports fMRI of body-checking in anorexia nervosa patients and does not specify inclusion of a healthy control group or participant ages. Task may relate to self-perception (a social-related construct), but information is insufficient to confirm criteria — include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This fMRI study uses a task that probes social-related processing (participants imagine performing/relating to body-checking actions of others, engaging self-referential and social cognition/mirroring processes). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=15, ages 17–34) with results reported separately. The paper reports univariate, whole-brain group activation maps for the healthy control group (figures/tables and cluster-corrected voxelwise results), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked evidence. The study is empirical, task-based, and not limited to ROI/connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

studies.title: Impaired social brain network for processing dynamic facial expressions in autism spectrum disorders.
studies.abstract: Impairment of social interaction via facial expressions represents a core clinical feature of autism spectrum disorders (ASD). However, the neural correlates of this dysfunction remain unidentified. Because this dysfunction is manifested in real-life situations, we hypothesized that the observation of dynamic, compared with static, facial expressions would reveal abnormal brain functioning in individuals with ASD.We presented dynamic and static facial expressions of fear and happiness to individuals with high-functioning ASD and to age- and sex-matched typically developing controls and recorded their brain activities using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI).
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI conducted during a social-related task (processing dynamic and static facial expressions). Study includes age- and sex-matched typically developing control group (healthy participants). Abstract does not specify participant ages (17–65), so include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: Meets all inclusion criteria: study used task-based fMRI of social processing (dynamic vs. static facial-expression perception — social communication/perception of others). Includes a healthy adult control group (n=13, mean age 24.3, within 17–65). Reports group-level, univariate whole-brain contrasts for the control group (simple main effect dynamic>static), with corrected whole-brain results and coordinates shown in tables/figures and described in text. Although the paper also includes clinical (ASD) participants, healthy-group results are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met (whole-brain results are provided; not ROI-only or connectivity-only). Therefore the paper should be INCLUDED in the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Dissociation of Brain Activation in Autism and Schizotypal Personality Disorder During Social Judgments.
studies.abstract: There are overlaps between autism and schizophrenia but these are particularly pronounced, especially in social domains, for higher functioning individuals with autism spectrum disorders (ASD) or schizotypal personality disorder (SPD). It is not known whether these overlapping social deficits result from shared or distinct brain mechanisms. We therefore compared social cognition in ASD and SPD using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI).
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract describes an fMRI study of social cognition/social judgments, meeting the imaging and task relevance criteria. The abstract does not clearly report inclusion of a healthy control group aged 17–65, so full-text review is needed to confirm eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: Study employed task-based fMRI of social judgments (approachability), including healthy adult control participants. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain analyses (social vs gender and social vs baseline contrasts) with cluster- and voxel-wise FWE correction, and within-group analyses are described (supplementary tables s3–s6, figures s1–s5), providing univariate whole-brain task activation maps attributable to the healthy/control group. Analyses are not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only methods, and healthy controls’ results are reported separately from clinical groups. Thus all inclusion criteria are met.

studies.title: Seeing is believing: neural mechanisms of action-perception are biased by team membership.
studies.abstract: Group identification can lead to a biased view of the world in favor of "in-group" members. Studying the brain processes that underlie such in-group biases is important for a wider understanding of the potential influence of social factors on basic perceptual processes. In this study, we used functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to investigate how people perceive the actions of in-group and out-group members, and how their biased view in favor of own team members manifests itself in the brain. We divided participants into two teams and had them judge the relative speeds of hand actions performed by an in-group and an out-group member in a competitive situation. Participants judged hand actions performed by in-group members as being faster than those of out-group members, even when the two actions were performed at physically identical speeds. In an additional fMRI experiment, we showed that, contrary to common belief, such skewed impressions arise from a subtle bias in perception and associated brain activity rather than decision-making processes, and that this bias develops rapidly and involuntarily as a consequence of group affiliation. Our findings suggest that the neural mechanisms that underlie human perception are shaped by social context.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract reports an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (perception of in-group vs out-group actions). It investigates social perception/neural mechanisms, fits inclusion criteria and is not a review. Sufficient detail in abstract to include for full-text data extraction.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (ages 17–43) using a social/group-related task (minimal-group in-group/out-group action perception and judgments). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts (single-video and paired-video trials) with cluster-level FWE correction and provides coordinates and statistical maps/results. Sample and analyses are reported for the healthy control group separately. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-only, not a non-empirical paper). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

studies.title: Is the Medial Prefrontal Cortex Necessary for Theory of Mind?
studies.abstract: Successful social interaction relies on the ability to attribute mental states to other people. Previous functional neuroimaging studies have shown that this process, described as Theory of Mind (ToM) or mentalization, is reliably associated with activation of the medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC). However, this study presents a novel and surprising finding that provides new insight into the role of the mPFC in mentalization tasks.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract addresses Theory of Mind/mentalization and refers to functional neuroimaging but does not explicitly state that an fMRI was conducted or report participant/sample details. Inclusion requires fMRI in healthy adults performing a social task; abstract information is insufficient, so include for full-text review to confirm methods and sample.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social processing (Theory of Mind using validated Heider–Simmel animations). The sample comprises healthy adults (n=20; age range 24–64), within the 17–65 inclusion range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task contrasts (e.g., ToM > Random, ToM > Baseline) with voxelwise thresholds and identified activations (coordinates/regions and cluster-level correction), not limited to ROI analyses. Results for the healthy control group are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, not outside age range). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: What Makes Eye Contact Special? Neural Substrates of On-Line Mutual Eye-Gaze: A Hyperscanning fMRI Study.
studies.abstract: Automatic mimicry is a critical element of social interaction. A salient type of automatic mimicry is eye contact characterized by sharing of affective and mental states among individuals. We conducted a hyperscanning functional magnetic resonance imaging study involving on-line (LIVE) and delayed off-line (REPLAY) conditions to test our hypothesis that recurrent interaction through eye contact activates the limbic mirror system, including the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) and anterior insular cortex (AIC), both of which are critical for self-awareness. Sixteen pairs of human adults participated in the experiment. Given that an eye-blink represents an individual's attentional window toward the partner, we analyzed pairwise time-series data for eye-blinks. We used multivariate autoregression analysis to calculate the noise contribution ratio (NCR) as an index of how a participant's directional attention was influenced by that of their partner. NCR was greater in the LIVE than in the REPLAY condition, indicating mutual perceptual-motor interaction during real-time eye contact. Relative to the REPLAY condition, the LIVE condition was associated with greater activation in the left cerebellar hemisphere, vermis, and ACC, accompanied by enhanced functional connectivity between ACC and right AIC. Given the roles of the cerebellum in sensorimotor prediction and ACC in movement initiation, ACC-cerebellar activation may represent their involvement in modulating visual input related to the partner's movement, which may, in turn, involve the limbic mirror system. Our findings indicate that mutual interaction during eye contact is mediated by the cerebellum and limbic mirror system.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI hyperscanning study of live vs replay eye contact in adult pairs (healthy adults implied) investigating neural substrates of social interaction (eye contact). Meets criterion: functional MRI during a social-related task in healthy adults; not a review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social processing (real-time mutual eye contact/social communication) in healthy adults (N=32–34; mean age ~21.8 years, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (LIVE > REPLAY) analyzed with random-effects GLM and cluster-level FWE correction, with detailed clusters/coordinates and figures. Although additional connectivity and interbrain analyses are present, the manuscript clearly provides whole-brain task-evoked activation maps for the healthy sample. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, and participants are healthy adults). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

studies.title: Recruitment of both the mirror and the mentalizing networks when observing social interactions depicted by point-lights: a neuroimaging study.
studies.abstract: Understanding social interactions requires the ability to accurately interpret conspecifics' actions, sometimes only on the basis of subtle body language analysis. Here we address an important issue that has not yet received much attention in social neuroscience, that of an interaction between two agents. We attempted to isolate brain responses to two individuals interacting compared to two individuals acting independently.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Neuroimaging study investigating brain responses to observed social interactions; addresses social perception/understanding. Abstract implies healthy adult participants and an experimental task. Abstract lacks full methods detail, so include for full-text confirmation.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception/understanding of others via point-light social interactions). Sample: 14 healthy adults (mean age 29.4), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (SI vs NSI contrast) using random-effects one-sample t-tests with FDR correction (p<0.05) and cluster reporting; activations are described in text, figures and tables. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and reports healthy-group whole-brain results generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: An evaluation of traffic-awareness campaign videos: empathy induction is associated with brain function within superior temporal sulcus.
studies.abstract: Acting appropriately within social contexts requires an ability to appreciate others' mental and emotional states. Indeed, some campaign programs designed to reduce anti-social behaviour seek to elicit empathy for the victims. The effectiveness of these campaigns can be evaluated according to the degree to which they induce such responses, but by applying neuroscientific techniques this can be done at the behavioural and neurophysiological level. Neuroimaging studies aimed at identifying the neural mechanisms behind such socio-cognitive and -emotional processes frequently reveal the role of the superior temporal sulcus (STS). We applied this knowledge to assess the effectiveness of traffic-awareness campaign adverts to induce empathic expression. Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) data were acquired from 20 healthy male volunteers as they watched these campaign videos consisting of a dramatic sequence of events and catastrophic endings, and control videos without such dramatic endings. Among other structures, a significantly greater neural response was observed within bilateral STS, particularly within the right hemisphere, during the observation of campaign relative to control videos. Furthermore, activation in these brain regions correlated with the subjects' empathic expression. Our results develop our understanding of the role of STS in social cognition. Moreover, our data demonstrate the utility of neuroscientific methods when evaluating the effectiveness of campaign videos in terms of their ability to elicit empathic responses. Our study also demonstrates the utility of these specific stimuli for future neuroscientific research.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI was performed while healthy adult participants (20 male volunteers) viewed campaign videos designed to elicit empathy — a social-cognitive task involving perception/understanding of others. Participants are healthy adults and the study is primary research (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study with healthy adult participants (n=20, ages 20–28). The task involves social-related processing (empathy, socio-cognitive evaluation of others) using campaign videos designed to elicit empathy—clearly within the review’s constructs (perception/understanding of others, social communication). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (CV > NV), thresholded at p<0.05 FWE corrected, with peak coordinates and cluster information provided and used as ROIs; these are clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. The study is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or clinical groups. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Mindfulness training increases cooperative decision making in economic exchanges: Evidence from fMRI.
studies.abstract: Emotions have been shown to exert influences on decision making during economic exchanges. Here we investigate the underlying neural mechanisms of a training regimen which is hypothesized to promote emotional awareness, specifically mindfulness training (MT). We test the hypothesis that MT increases cooperative economic decision making using fMRI in a randomized longitudinal design involving 8weeks of either MT or active control training (CT). We find that MT results in an increased willingness to cooperate indexed by higher acceptance rates to unfair monetary offers in the Ultimatum Game. While controlling for acceptance rates of monetary offers between intervention groups, subjects in the MT and CT groups show differential brain activation patterns. Specifically, a subset of more cooperative MT subjects displays increased activation in the septal region, an area linked to social attachment, which may drive the increased willingness to express cooperative behavior in the MT cohort. Furthermore, MT resulted in attenuated activity in anterior insula compared with the CT group in response to unfair monetary offers post-training, which may suggest that MT enables greater ability to effectively regulate the anterior insula and thereby promotes social cooperation. Finally, functional connectivity analyses show a coupling between the septal region and posterior insula in the MT group, suggesting an integration of interoceptive inputs. Together, these results highlight that MT may be employed in contexts where emotional regulation is required to promote social cooperation.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI was conducted while participants performed the Ultimatum Game, a social decision-making task assessing cooperation/response to others (social processing). The study involves healthy adult participants in a randomized longitudinal design (mindfulness vs control). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study using the Ultimatum Game, a social-exchange task probing social decision-making (perception/understanding of others, affiliation/cooperation). Sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=51 initially; final analyses on healthy adults with mean age ~31, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (parametric regressors, conjunctions, interaction contrasts) with voxelwise results and MNI coordinates, cluster- and FDR-corrected significance thresholds, and tables/figures of activations. Although ROI and PPI analyses are included, whole-brain healthy-group activation maps are clearly reported. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

studies.title: Creating buzz: the neural correlates of effective message propagation.
studies.abstract: Social interaction promotes the spread of values, attitudes, and behaviors. Here, we report on neural responses to ideas that are destined to spread. We scanned message communicators using functional MRI during their initial exposure to the to-be-communicated ideas. These message communicators then had the opportunity to spread the messages and their corresponding subjective evaluations to message recipients outside the scanner. Successful ideas were associated with neural responses in the communicators' mentalizing systems and reward systems when they first heard the messages, prior to spreading them. Similarly, individuals more able to spread their own views to others produced greater mentalizing-system activity during initial encoding. Unlike prior social-influence studies that focused on the individuals being influenced, this investigation focused on the brains of influencers. Successful social influence is reliably associated with an influencer-to-be's state of mind when first encoding ideas.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study scanning participants during exposure to messages about social influence; investigates social-related processes (mentalizing, reward) and influencer communication. Abstract does not state participant ages/health status, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study with healthy adult participants (interns N=19, producers N=79; mean ages ≈20.5 within 17–65). The task is social (message communication, persuasion, mentalizing — social communication and understanding of others). The paper reports group-level whole-brain, random-effects univariate analyses (buzz, intention, salesperson effects) with voxelwise thresholds and MNI coordinates (whole-brain results reported and illustrated; Table 1/Figures). Results are not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: Effect of intentional bias on agency attribution of animated motion: an event-related fMRI study.
studies.abstract: Animated movements of simple geometric shapes can readily be interpreted as depicting social events in which animate agents are engaged in intentional activity. However, the brain regions associated with such intention have not been clearly elucidated. In this study, intentional bias was manipulated using shape and pattern animations while measuring associated brain activity using event-related functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). Twenty-five higher-intention involved and twenty-five lower-intention involved animations were presented to participants. Behavioral results showed that the degree of agency attribution of the mental state increased as intentional involvement increased. fMRI results revealed that the posterior superior temporal sulcus (STS), inferior temporal gyrus (ITG), inferior frontal gyrus (IFG), premotor, temporal pole, supramarginal gyrus, and superior parietal lobule (SPL) were activated while participants viewed the high-intention animations. In contrast, occipital, lingual, and middle frontal gyri were activated while the participants viewed the low-intention animations. These findings suggest that as agent attribution increases, the visual brain changes its functional role to the intentional brain and becomes a flexible network for processing information about social interaction.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Event-related fMRI was used while participants viewed animations manipulating intentionality (agency attribution)—a social perception/understanding task. Study reports neural correlates of attributing intention in (presumably) healthy adult participants (25 per condition). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=12, mean age 25.2) examining agency attribution/intentionality (social cognition, ToM-related). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (random-effects second-level contrasts: High>Low and Low>High) with voxelwise thresholds (p<0.001) and presents activation loci (STS, IFG, occipital regions) in text/figures. It is not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only analyses, and participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met (social-related fMRI task; healthy adult sample; whole-brain group-level task activation maps reported). Exclusion criteria are not triggered.

studies.title: Intact neural representations of affective meaning of touch but lack of embodied resonance in autism: a multi-voxel pattern analysis study.
studies.abstract: Humans can easily grasp the affective meaning of touch when observing social interactions. Several neural systems support this ability, including the theory of mind (ToM) network and the somatosensory system linked to embodied resonance, but it is unclear how these systems are affected in autism spectrum disorder (ASD). Individuals with ASD exhibit impairments in the use of nonverbal communication such as social and reciprocal touch. Despite the importance of touch in social communication and the reported touch aversion in ASD, surprisingly little is known about the neural systems underlying impairments in touch communication in ASD.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract reports an fMRI MVPA study of affective/social touch in autism but does not clearly state whether a healthy adult control group (age 17–65) participated or provide full task/sample details. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone—include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy participants and task specifics.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study uses task-based fMRI in healthy adults (a neurotypical control group of 21 age- and IQ-matched adult males) during observation of social touch videos (social cognition: perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level univariate whole-brain task results: mean group effects for social vs. non-social touch and felt touch are provided (with MNI coordinates and figures/tables referenced in main/supplementary materials), satisfying the requirement for a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map. Healthy control results are reported separately from the ASD group. The sample is within the adult age range, and the study includes original empirical fMRI data. It does not fall under ROI-only, connectivity-only, or non-empirical exclusions. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

studies.title: MDMA Increases Cooperation and Recruitment of Social Brain Areas When Playing Trustworthy Players in an Iterated Prisoner's Dilemma.
studies.abstract: Social decision-making is fundamental for successful functioning and can be affected in psychiatric illness and by serotoninergic modulation. The Prisoner's Dilemma is the archetypal paradigm to model cooperation and trust. However, the effect of serotonergic enhancement is poorly characterized, and its influence on the effect of variations in opponent behavior unknown. To address this, we conducted a study investigating how the serotonergic enhancer 3,4-methylenedioxy-methamphetamine (MDMA) modulates behavior and its neural correlates during an iterated Prisoner's Dilemma with both trustworthy and untrustworthy opponents. We administered 100 mg MDMA or placebo to 20 male participants in a double-blind, placebo-controlled, crossover study. While being scanned, participants played repeated rounds with opponents who differed in levels of cooperation. On each round, participants chose to compete or cooperate and were asked to rate their trust in the other player. Cooperation with trustworthy, but not untrustworthy, opponents was enhanced following MDMA but not placebo (respectively: odds ratio = 2.01; 95% CI, 1.42-2.84,
studies.journal: The Journal of neuroscience : the official journal of the Society for Neuroscience

Study appears to involve healthy adult volunteers though ages/health not explicitly stated; include for full-text review to confirm participant health status and age range.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study reports task-based fMRI during a social decision-making paradigm (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) in a healthy adult sample (N=20 males, age 21–37). The paper presents group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (one-sample t tests for task phases in the placebo condition and flexible factorial analyses including treatment and opponent effects), with results thresholded at FWE cluster-corrected p<0.05 and reported in tables/figures. These maps represent task-evoked activation generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, or lack of whole-brain task maps) are violated.

studies.title: Age-related changes to the neural correlates of social evaluation.
studies.abstract: Recent work suggests the existence of a specialized neural system underlying social processing that may be relatively spared with age, unlike pervasive aging-related decline occurring in many cognitive domains. We investigated how neural mechanisms underlying social evaluation are engaged with age, and how age-related changes to socioemotional goals affect recruitment of regions within this network. In a functional MRI study, 15 young and 15 older adults formed behavior-based impressions of individuals. They also responded to a prompt that was interpersonally meaningful, social but interpersonally irrelevant, or non-social. Both age groups engaged regions implicated in mentalizing and impression formation when making social relative to non-social evaluations, including dorsal and ventral medial prefrontal cortices, precuneus, and temporoparietal junction. Older adults had increased activation over young in right temporal pole when making social relative to non-social evaluations, suggesting reliance on past experiences when evaluating others. Young adults had greater activation than old in posterior cingulate gyrus when making interpersonally irrelevant, compared to interpersonally meaningful, evaluations, potentially reflecting enhanced valuation of this information. The findings demonstrate the age-related preservation of the neural correlates underlying social evaluation, and suggest that functioning in these regions might be mediated by age-related changes in socioemotional goals.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study with healthy human participants performing social evaluation/impression-formation tasks (social vs non-social conditions). Includes young adult group (likely within 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis. Therefore meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: The study is an fMRI experiment of social evaluation (impression formation) using task-evoked BOLD contrasts. It includes a healthy young adult group (ages 20–29), meeting the 17–65 sample criterion, and reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses (social vs. non-social; social-meaningful vs. social-irrelevant) with corrected thresholds and conjunctions. Results are not limited to ROIs or connectivity analyses and provide whole-brain activation maps/coordinates for the healthy groups. Although an older group includes participants >65, the young adult group is analyzed and reported separately, satisfying inclusion. Therefore the paper meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the listed exclusions.

studies.title: Sex differences in own and other body perception.
studies.abstract: Own body perception, and differentiating and comparing one's body to another person's body, are common cognitive functions that have relevance for self-identity and social interactions. In several psychiatric conditions, including anorexia nervosa, body dysmorphic disorder, gender dysphoria, and autism spectrum disorder, self and own body perception, as well as aspects of social communication are disturbed. Despite most of these conditions having skewed prevalence sex ratios, little is known about whether the neural basis of own body perception differs between the sexes. We addressed this question by investigating brain activation using functional magnetic resonance imaging during a Body Perception task in 15 male and 15 female healthy participants. Participants viewed their own body, bodies of same-sex, or opposite-sex other people, and rated the degree that they appeared like themselves. We found that men and women did not differ in the pattern of brain activation during own body perception compared to a scrambled control image. However, when viewing images of other bodies of same-sex or opposite-sex, men showed significantly stronger activations in attention-related and reward-related brain regions, whereas women engaged stronger activations in striatal, medial-prefrontal, and insular cortices, when viewing the own body compared to other images of the opposite sex. It is possible that other body images, particularly of the opposite sex, may be of greater salience for men, whereas images of own bodies may be more salient for women. These observations provide tentative neurobiological correlates to why women may be more vulnerable than men to conditions involving own body perception.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Study used fMRI during a Body Perception task probing perception/understanding of self and others (social-related processing). Sample comprised healthy adult participants (15 males, 15 females) within the target age range. Original empirical study, not a review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception/understanding of self and others via a body-perception task). Sample: healthy adult participants (N=30, ages ~26, 15 male/15 female), results reported separately for healthy groups. Whole-brain, univariate group-level task contrasts are reported (e.g., own body > scrambled; same-sex and opposite-sex contrasts; parametric modulation analyses) with voxelwise Z thresholds and cluster-correction (FLAME, FSL), and results presented in text, figures and supplementary tables. The paper is empirical, not ROI-only or connectivity-only. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked activation maps in healthy adults.

analyses.name: Parametric association of greater “not me” rating during opposite‐sex morph viewing

studies.title: Common premotor regions for the perception and production of prosody and correlations with empathy and prosodic ability.
studies.abstract: Prosody, the melody and intonation of speech, involves the rhythm, rate, pitch and voice quality to relay linguistic and emotional information from one individual to another. A significant component of human social communication depends upon interpreting and responding to another person's prosodic tone as well as one's own ability to produce prosodic speech. However there has been little work on whether the perception and production of prosody share common neural processes, and if so, how these might correlate with individual differences in social ability.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Original research using fMRI examining perception and production of prosody and correlations with empathy—addresses social communication and perception of others in human participants. Not a review. Abstract does not state ages, but likely healthy adult sample; meets review objective. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is a task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (n=19, ages 18–58) investigating social communication (prosody perception and production) and its relation to empathy. Group-level, whole-brain, univariate contrasts are reported (e.g., “happy–neutral”, “question–neutral”) with random-effects analyses and multiple-comparison thresholds (FDR, cluster thresholds) and coordinates/results described in text and supplementary materials. The sample is within the 17–65 range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. The paper is empirical and not ROI-only, and it provides task-evoked whole-brain activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusions.

studies.title: The Difference between Aesthetic Appreciation of Artistic and Popular Music: Evidence from an fMRI Study.
studies.abstract: To test the hypothesis that pleasure from artistic music is intellectual while that from popular music is physiological, this study investigated the different functional mechanisms between aesthetic appreciation of artistic and popular music using fMRI. 18 male non-musicians were scanned while they performed an aesthetic rating task for excerpts of artistic music, popular music and musical notes playing and singing (control). The rating scores of artistic and popular music excerpts were both significantly higher than that of control materials while the scores of them were not different. The fMRI results showed both artistic and popular conditions activated the VS and vmPFC, compared with control condition. When contrasted popular and artistic condition directly, we found popular music activated right putamen, while artistic music activated right mPFC. By parametric analysis, we found the activation of right putamen tracked the aesthetic ratings of popular music, whereas the BOLD signal in right mPFC tracked the aesthetic ratings of artistic music. These results indicate the reward induced by popular music is closer to a primary reward while that induced by artistic music is closer to a secondary reward. We also found artistic music activated ToM areas, including PCC/PC, arMFC and TPJ, when compared with popular music. And these areas also tracked aesthetic ratings of artistic music but not those of popular music. These results imply that the pleasure from former comes from cognitive empathy. In conclusion, this study gives clear neuronal evidences supporting the view that artistic music is of intelligence and social cognition involved while the popular music is of physiology.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing an aesthetic judgment task; authors report activation of Theory-of-Mind and social-cognition regions (PCC/PC, arMFC, TPJ) linked to artistic music appreciation, fitting ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’ social processing.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This fMRI study uses a task (listening to popular, artistic music, and control notes) in healthy adult participants (n=18 males, age 18–24). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain contrasts (Popular>Notes, Artistic>Notes, Popular>Artistic, Artistic>Popular) and parametric analyses with whole-brain thresholds and coordinates, satisfying the whole-brain univariate result requirement. Although the paradigm is musical/aesthetic rather than an explicit social-interaction task, the authors explicitly interpret activation in default-mode/ToM and cognitive-empathy regions (arMFC, PCC/PC, TPJ/angular gyrus, hippocampus) as engagement of social-cognitive/mentalizing processes (Perception/Understanding of Others). Sample age is within 17–65 and results are reported for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria are met. Note: the social nature of the task is inferred by the authors rather than being an explicit social behavioral paradigm, hence confidence is moderate-high.

studies.title: Collective memory shapes the organization of individual memories in the medial prefrontal cortex.
studies.abstract: It has long been hypothesized that individual recollection fits collective memory. To look for a collective schema, we analysed the content of 30 years of media coverage of World War II on French national television. We recorded human brain activity using functional magnetic resonance imaging as participants recalled World War II displays at the Caen Memorial Museum following an initial tour. We focused on the medial prefrontal cortex, a key region for social cognition and memory schemas. The organization of individual memories captured using the distribution of the functional magnetic resonance imaging signal in the dorsal part of the medial prefrontal cortex was more accurately predicted by the structure of the collective schema than by various control models of contextual or semantic memory. Collective memory, which exists outside and beyond individuals, can also organize individual memories and constitutes a common mental model that connects people's memories across time and space.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI was recorded while participants recalled World War II displays, a task probing collective/social memory and medial prefrontal social-cognitive processing. Abstract implies human participants likely healthy adults. Participant age/health not explicitly stated, so full text should be checked for eligibility; include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study with 24 healthy adult participants (ages 22–39) that investigates collective/social knowledge and its neural representation (dmPFC/vmPFC). The experimental task involved task-evoked memory recall during fMRI (recall of museum pictures cued by captions), probing social-related constructs (collective memory, social knowledge, narrative comprehension, mentalizing). The paper reports group-level whole-brain searchlight analyses producing TFCE-corrected maps (Extended Data Fig.1) and ROI/second-level results derived from the healthy control group, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain, group-level task-evoked effects generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (only ROI, connectivity-only, non-empirical, out-of-range ages) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: Mapping the information flow from one brain to another during gestural communication.
studies.abstract: Both the putative mirror neuron system (pMNS) and the ventral medial prefrontal cortex (vmPFC) are deemed important for social interaction: the pMNS because it supposedly "resonates" with the actions of others, the vmPFC because it is involved in mentalizing. Strictly speaking, the resonance property of the pMNS has never been investigated. Classical functional MRI experiments have only investigated whether pMNS regions augment their activity when an action is seen or executed. Resonance, however, entails more than only "going on and off together". Activity in the pMNS of an observer should continuously follow the more subtle changes over time in activity of the pMNS of the actor. Here we directly explore whether such resonance indeed occurs during continuous streams of actions. We let participants play the game of charades while we measured brain activity of both gesturer and guesser. We then applied a method to localize directed influences between the brains of the participants: between-brain Granger-causality mapping. Results show that a guesser's brain activity in regions involved in mentalizing and mirroring echoes the temporal structure of a gesturer's brain activity. This provides evidence for resonance theories and indicates a fine-grained temporal interplay between regions involved in motor planning and regions involved in thinking about the mental states of others. Furthermore, this method enables experiments to be more ecologically valid by providing the opportunity to leave social interaction unconstrained. This, in turn, would allow us to tap into the neural substrates of social deficits such as autism spectrum disorder.
studies.journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study measuring brain activity during naturalistic social interaction (charades) between participants; addresses social communication and mirroring/mentalizing in humans. Not a review; likely healthy adult participants. Meets inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social communication (charades) in healthy adult participants (n=18 analyzed; mean age 27.5). The task probes perception and understanding of others through gestural communication. The authors performed group-level whole-brain analyses: they ran traditional GLM analyses (used to define mirror ROIs that were active during gesturing and guessing) and report group-level between-brain Granger-causality (bbGCM) maps (thresholded and corrected) showing directed influences across brains. Thus the paper includes whole-brain, task-evoked group results from healthy adults and is not limited to ROI-only or solely resting-state/connectivity reports. It therefore meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: Neural Modulation in Aversive Emotion Processing: An Independent Component Analysis Study.
studies.abstract: Emotional processing has an important role in social interaction. We report the findings about the Independent Component Analysis carried out on a fMRI set obtained with a paradigm of face emotional processing. The results showed that an independent component, mainly cerebellar-medial-frontal, had a positive modulation associated with fear processing. Also, another independent component, mainly parahippocampal-prefrontal, showed a negative modulation that could be associated with implicit reappraisal of emotional stimuli. Independent Component Analysis could serve as a method to understand complex cognitive processes and their underlying neural dynamics.
studies.journal: Computational and mathematical methods in medicine
studies.abstract_screening_reason: The study uses fMRI with a face emotional processing paradigm, which is a social-related task (perception/understanding of others). The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so inclusion cannot be confirmed from abstract alone; include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample and ages.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is a task-based fMRI study using a Face Matching Task (implicit emotional face perception), which clearly targets social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). The sample comprises healthy adults (n=10; mean age 25 within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise GLM results: first-level contrasts (e.g., fear > neutral) and second-level one-sample t-tests (P<0.005, k=10), with whole-brain results presented (Table S2 and Figures S1–S3 in Supplementary Material). Although the study also uses ICA, it does provide univariate whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps, satisfying the inclusion criteria and not violating exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not only connectivity/resting-state). Therefore it should be INCLUDED in the review.

studies.title: Altered brain activity and the effect of personality traits in excessive smartphone use during facial emotion processing.
studies.abstract: Excessive smartphone use is a phenomenon related to maladaptive smartphone use, leading to negative consequences. This study set out with the aim of assessing the effects of excessive smartphone use on behavioral and neural responses during facial emotional processing. We examined 25 excessive smartphone users and 27 normal control users using functional MRI during facial emotion processing and investigated Behavioral Inhibition System/Behavioral Activation System (BIS/BAS). The excessive smartphone use group (SP) showed neural deactivation in the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) and dorsal anterior cingulate cortex (dACC) during the presentation of an angry face and emotional transition compared to that of the normal control group (NC). Additionally, the SP revealed neural deactivation of the superior temporal sulcus and temporo-parietal junction related to social interaction during emotional transition compared to the NC. We found that BAS-Reward Responsiveness level was correlated with behavioral responses during repeated happy faces related to emotional reward in SP compared to NC. It can thus be suggested that excessive smartphone use is likely to fail on cognitive control during emotional processing, and this impairment might be influenced on emotional processing related to social interaction.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI was used during facial emotion processing, which is social-related (perception/understanding of others). Study includes a healthy control group of adults and is an original research article (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of facial emotion discrimination (social perceptual processing) in healthy adults (control group n=27, ages 19–35). The paper reports whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts that are clearly attributed to the healthy/control group (within-group condition contrasts for NC, e.g., AH>HH activations reported with cluster-level statistics and FWE-corrected p-values and voxel counts). The task probes perception/understanding of others (faces/emotional expressions), matching the review’s social-processing domain. Results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses and include group-level whole-brain maps/tables generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

studies.title: Psychopathic traits and deception: functional magnetic resonance imaging study.
studies.abstract: There is relatively little existing information regarding the neural correlates of deception in individuals with psychopathic traits.
studies.journal: The British journal of psychiatry : the journal of mental science
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of deception, which involves social-cognitive processing. Abstract does not specify whether healthy adults (ages 17–65) were included or participant details. Insufficient information to determine eligibility—include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of deception (a social-cognition task involving theory-of-mind/understanding others) in a healthy adult sample (n=24 males, ages 19–60). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise SPM random-effects contrasts (lie>truth and truth>lie) with whole-brain statistical maps/coordinate tables and figures (thresholds and cluster results are reported; small-volume corrections were used for a priori ROIs but whole-brain uncorrected results are also presented). The task and results are clearly from the healthy/control group and are generalizable to healthy adults. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, outside age range, or non-empirical) are violated.

studies.title: Neural representations of honesty predict future trust behavior.
studies.abstract: Theoretical accounts propose honesty as a central determinant of trustworthiness impressions and trusting behavior. However, behavioral and neural evidence on the relationships between honesty and trust is missing. Here, combining a novel paradigm that successfully induces trustworthiness impressions with functional MRI and multivariate analyses, we demonstrate that honesty-based trustworthiness is represented in the posterior cingulate cortex, dorsolateral prefrontal cortex and intraparietal sulcus. Crucially, brain signals in these regions predict individual trust in a subsequent social interaction with the same partner. Honesty recruited the ventromedial prefrontal cortex (VMPFC), and stronger functional connectivity between the VMPFC and temporoparietal junction during honesty encoding was associated with higher trust in the subsequent interaction. These results suggest that honesty signals in the VMPFC are integrated into trustworthiness beliefs to inform present and future social behaviors. These findings improve our understanding of the neural representations of an individual's social character that guide behaviors during interpersonal interactions.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract reports an fMRI study of honesty-related neural signals that predict trust during social interactions, meeting the social-related task requirement. Participant health/age not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task-based fMRI of social processing (advice-taking and trust decisions; perception/understanding of others and social evaluation). (2) Sample: 31 healthy adult participants (mean age 24.3), within 17–65. (3) Reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked results (GLM contrasts; voxel-level and cluster-level FWE-corrected results reported; supplementary tables/figures with coordinates). (4) Empirical original neuroimaging study (not review). Although the paper also includes ROI and connectivity analyses (PPI) and multivariate decoding, it clearly presents whole-brain univariate maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore include in the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Emotional prosody processing in autism spectrum disorder.
studies.abstract: Individuals with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) are characterized by severe deficits in social communication, whereby the nature of their impairments in emotional prosody processing have yet to be specified. Here, we investigated emotional prosody processing in individuals with ASD and controls with novel, lifelike behavioral and neuroimaging paradigms. Compared to controls, individuals with ASD showed reduced emotional prosody recognition accuracy on a behavioral task. On the neural level, individuals with ASD displayed reduced activity of the STS, insula and amygdala for complex vs basic emotions compared to controls. Moreover, the coupling between the STS and amygdala for complex vs basic emotions was reduced in the ASD group. Finally, groups differed with respect to the relationship between brain activity and behavioral performance. Brain activity during emotional prosody processing was more strongly related to prosody recognition accuracy in ASD participants. In contrast, the coupling between STS and anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) activity predicted behavioral task performance more strongly in the control group. These results provide evidence for aberrant emotional prosody processing of individuals with ASD. They suggest that the differences in the relationship between the neural and behavioral level of individuals with ASD may account for their observed deficits in social communication.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of emotional prosody (a social communication task) reporting both ASD and healthy control participants. Includes social-related processing during fMRI and a healthy group; include for full-text review to confirm age range and details.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study including a healthy adult control group (age range 20–46) reported separately from an ASD group. The task (emotional prosody processing) is clearly social-related (social communication/perception of others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts for controls (e.g., emotional vs neutral prosody and complexity/condition contrasts), with cluster-level FWE-corrected statistics and reported activation maps/tables, not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

studies.title: Social cognition, the male brain and the autism spectrum.
studies.abstract: Behavioral studies have shown that, at a population level, women perform better on tests of social cognition and empathy than men. Furthermore Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASDs), which are characterized by impairments in social functioning and empathy, occur more commonly in males than females. These findings have led to the hypothesis that differences in the functioning of the social brain between males and females contribute to the greater vulnerability of males to ASD and the suggestion that ASD may represent an extreme form of the male brain. Here we sought to investigate this hypothesis by determining: (i) whether males and females differ in social brain function, and (ii) whether any sex differences in social brain function are exaggerated in individuals with ASD. Using fMRI we show that males and females differ markedly in social brain function when making social decisions from faces (compared to simple sex judgements) especially when making decisions of an affective nature, with the greatest sex differences in social brain activation being in the inferior frontal cortex (IFC). We also demonstrate that this difference is exaggerated in individuals with ASD, who show an extreme male pattern of IFC function. These results show that males and females differ significantly in social brain function and support the view that sex differences in the social brain contribute to the greater vulnerability of males to ASDs.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of social decision-making from faces (social/affective judgments). Compares males, females, and individuals with ASD, implying a healthy control group; not a review. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text verification of participant ages and details.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults (n=47 healthy controls; separate healthy male control group n=12 for ASD comparison). The tasks (approachability, intelligence judgments from faces) index social perception/understanding of others. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise contrasts for healthy participants (social vs gender judgements) with thresholding and cluster-level correction, and provides within-group activation maps and coordinates for males and females separately. Results for the healthy groups are reported independently of the clinical ASD group. Participants are adults within the 17–65 range. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state/ connectivity-only, and is clearly a suitable whole-brain task activation dataset for inclusion.

studies.title: FMRI evidence of 'mirror' responses to geometric shapes.
studies.abstract: Mirror neurons may be a genetic adaptation for social interaction. Alternatively, the associative hypothesis proposes that the development of mirror neurons is driven by sensorimotor learning, and that, given suitable experience, mirror neurons will respond to any stimulus. This hypothesis was tested using fMRI adaptation to index populations of cells with mirror properties. After sensorimotor training, where geometric shapes were paired with hand actions, BOLD response was measured while human participants experienced runs of events in which shape observation alternated with action execution or observation. Adaptation from shapes to action execution, and critically, observation, occurred in ventral premotor cortex (PMv) and inferior parietal lobule (IPL). Adaptation from shapes to execution indicates that neuronal populations responding to the shapes had motor properties, while adaptation to observation demonstrates that these populations had mirror properties. These results indicate that sensorimotor training induced populations of cells with mirror properties in PMv and IPL to respond to the observation of arbitrary shapes. They suggest that the mirror system has not been shaped by evolution to respond in a mirror fashion to biological actions; instead, its development is mediated by stimulus-general processes of learning within a system adapted for visuomotor control.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study with human participants performing action observation/execution tasks after sensorimotor training; measures mirror-system responses in premotor and parietal cortex. This addresses perception/understanding of others (social processing) in healthy adults and is not a review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=21, mean age 24) that examines neural responses to observation and execution of actions (mirror representations), which falls under ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’ — a social-related construct. The paper reports group-level, univariate fMRI results including whole-brain analyses (thresholded whole-brain maps reported at p<0.001 uncorrected and tables of peak coordinates) in addition to ROI analyses. Participants are within the 17–65 age range, and results for the healthy group are clearly reported. The study is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only contrasts, nor is it non-empirical. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

studies.title: Neural correlates of second-language communication and the effect of language anxiety.
studies.abstract: Communicative speech is a type of language use that involves goal-directed action targeted at another person based on social interactive knowledge. Previous studies regarding one's first language (L1) have treated the theory of mind system, which is associated with understanding others, and the sensorimotor system, which is associated with action simulation, as important contributors to communication. However, little is known about the neural basis of communication in a second language (L2), which is limited in terms of its use as a communication tool. In this fMRI study, we manipulated the type of speech (i.e., communication vs. description) and the type of language (L1 vs. L2) to identify the specific brain areas involved in L2 communication. We also attempted to examine how the cortical mechanisms underlying L2 speech production are influenced by oral proficiency and anxiety regarding L2. Thirty native Japanese speakers who had learned English as an L2, performed communicative and descriptive speech-production tasks in both L1 and L2 while undergoing fMRI scanning. We found that the only the L2 communication task recruited the left posterior supramarginal gyrus (pSMG), which may be associated with the action simulation or prediction involved in generating goal-directed actions. Furthermore, the neural mechanisms underlying L2 communication, but not L2 description, were sensitive to both oral proficiency and anxiety levels; a) activation in the left middle temporal gyrus (MTG) increased as oral proficiency levels increased, and b) activation in the orbitofrontal cortex (OFC), including the left insula, decreased as L2 anxiety levels increased. These results reflect the successful retrieval of lexical information in a pragmatic context and an inability to monitor social behaviors due to anxiety. Taken together, the present results suggest that L2 communication relies on social skills and is mediated by anxiety and oral proficiency.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study investigating social communication (L2 communicative speech) in healthy adult participants (N=30). Task is explicitly social/communicative and neural correlates reported; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social communication (communicative vs descriptive speech) in a sample of 30 healthy adult native Japanese speakers who learned English as an L2. The paper reports group-level, task-evoked whole-brain univariate results (e.g., left posterior supramarginal gyrus, left MTG, orbitofrontal cortex/insula) associated with L2 communication, not limited to ROIs or connectivity analyses. Results are presented as generalizable healthy-group effects. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met (social-related task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task activation maps reported); no exclusion criteria apply.

studies.title: Social-network complexity in humans is associated with the neural response to social information.
studies.abstract: Humans have evolved to thrive in large and complex social groups, and it is likely that this increase in group complexity has come with a greater need to decode and respond to complex and uncertain communicatory signals. In this functional MRI study, we examined whether complexity of social networks in humans is related to the functioning of brain regions key to the perception of basic, nonverbal social stimuli. Greater activation to biological than to scrambled motion in the right posterior superior temporal sulcus (pSTS) and right amygdala were positively correlated with the diversity of social-network roles. In the pSTS, in particular, this association was not due to a relationship between network diversity and network size. These findings suggest that increased functioning of brain regions involved in decoding social signals might facilitate the detection and decoding of subtle signals encountered in varied social settings.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Functional MRI study examining neural responses to nonverbal social stimuli (biological vs scrambled motion) tied to social-network complexity, addressing social perception/communication. Conducted in humans with no clinical groups mentioned, fitting inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Uses task-based fMRI during a social-related task (perception of biological motion/social perception). (2) Sample comprises healthy adults (n=26 analyzed; ages 18–39). (3) Reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task analyses: whole-brain analyses of biological-motion selectivity and social-network diversity yielded a significant cluster in right pSTS/TG/TPJ (cluster-level correction reported). (4) Results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study is eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: Linking person perception and person knowledge in the human brain.
studies.abstract: Neuroscience research has examined separately how we detect human agents on the basis of their face and body (person perception) and how we reason about their thoughts, traits or intentions (person knowledge). Neuroanatomically distinct networks have been associated with person perception and person knowledge, but it remains unknown how multiple features of a person (e.g. thin and kind) are linked to form a holistic identity representation. In this fMRI experiment, we investigated the hypothesis that when encountering another person specialised person perception circuits would be functionally coupled with circuits involved in person knowledge. In a factorial design, we paired bodies or names with trait-based or neutral statements, and independent localiser scans identified body-selective and mentalising networks. When observing a body paired with a trait-implying statement, functional connectivity analyses demonstrated that body-selective patches in bilateral fusiform gyri were functionally coupled with nodes of the mentalising network. We demonstrate that when forming a representation of a person circuits for representing another person's physical appearance are linked to circuits that are engaged when reasoning about trait-based character. These data support the view that a 'who' system for social cognition involves communication between perceptual and inferential mechanisms when forming a representation of another's identity.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI experiment examining social cognition (person perception and person knowledge) with participants performing social-related tasks. Abstract does not state participant age or health status; therefore include for full-text review to confirm healthy adults 17–65.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=21, mean age 24.6) that investigates social cognition (person perception and person knowledge). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Bodies>Names; Traits>Neutral; interaction [(BodiesTraits>BodiesNeutral)>(NamesTraits>NamesNeutral)]) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster-level FWE correction, and presents coordinates/figures and overlap with functional localisers. Although PPI connectivity analyses are also reported, whole-brain univariate results from the healthy control sample are clearly provided. The sample and reported analyses meet the inclusion criteria and do not violate exclusion criteria.

studies.title: Neuroimaging self-esteem: a fMRI study of individual differences in women.
studies.abstract: Although neuroimaging studies strongly implicate the medial prefrontal cortex (ventral and dorsal), cingulate gyrus (anterior and posterior), precuneus and temporoparietal cortex in mediating self-referential processing (SRP), little is known about the neural bases mediating individual differences in valenced SRP, that is, processes intrinsic to self-esteem. This study investigated the neural correlates of experimentally engendered valenced SRP via the Visual-Verbal Self-Other Referential Processing Task in 20 women with fMRI. Participants viewed pictures of themselves or unknown other women during separate trials while covertly rehearsing 'I am' or 'She is', followed by reading valenced trait adjectives, thus variably associating the self/other with positivity/negativity. Response within dorsal and ventral medial prefrontal cortex, cingulate cortex and left temporoparietal cortex varied with individual differences in both pre-task rated self-descriptiveness of the words, as well as task-induced affective responses. Results are discussed as they relate to a social cognitive and affective neuroscience view of self-esteem.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of self-other referential processing (perception/understanding of self) in 20 women — a social-related task in healthy participants. Not a review. Age range not specified but participants appear to be adult; meets inclusion criteria for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study using a social cognition task (Visual–Verbal Self-Other Referential Processing Task) addressing perception/understanding of self and others. Sample comprises 20 healthy adult women (ages 18–52), within the 17–65 inclusion range. The paper reports whole-brain, univariate group-level voxelwise analyses (e.g., contrasts S‑N, S‑P, O‑N, O‑P vs fixation and contrasts between conditions), with cluster-level and coordinate results described in the text/tables/figures. Analyses are not limited to ROIs or connectivity/resting-state only. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

studies.title: Reflections of Oneself: Neurocognitive Evidence for Dissociable Forms of Self-Referential Recollection.
studies.abstract: Research links the medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC) with a number of social cognitive processes that involve reflecting on oneself and other people. Here, we investigated how mPFC might support the ability to recollect information about oneself and others relating to previous experiences. Participants judged whether they had previously related stimuli conceptually to themselves or someone else, or whether they or another agent had performed actions. We uncovered a functional distinction between dorsal and ventral mPFC subregions based on information retrieved from episodic long-term memory. The dorsal mPFC was generally activated when participants attempted to retrieve social information about themselves and others, regardless of whether this information concerned the conceptual or agentic self or other. In contrast, a role was discerned for ventral mPFC during conceptual but not agentic self-referential recollection, indicating specific involvement in retrieving memories related to self-concept rather than bodily self. A subsequent recognition test for new items that had been presented during the recollection task found that conceptual and agentic recollection attempts resulted in differential incidental encoding of new information. Thus, we reveal converging fMRI and behavioral evidence for distinct neurocognitive forms of self-referential recollection, highlighting that conceptual and bodily aspects of self-reflection can be dissociated.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study in healthy adult participants investigating self-referential (social) processing (conceptual and agentic self) during task-based scans; directly addresses perception/understanding of self. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is a task-based fMRI study of social cognition (self/other conceptual and agentic recollection) in healthy adult participants (N=18; ages 19–29). The paper reports group-level voxelwise task activation analyses, including whole-brain results (FWE-corrected clusters reported) as well as ROI analyses; whole-brain contrasts and coordinates are described in text/tables and figures. The sample falls within the 17–65 range and only healthy adults are analyzed. The study is empirical task fMRI (not solely ROI, connectivity, or resting-state) and presents univariate, generalizable healthy-group activation maps. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.
