studies.title: Out-of-body-induced hippocampal amnesia.
studies.abstract: Theoretical models have suggested an association between the ongoing experience of the world from the perspective of one's own body and hippocampus-based episodic memory. This link has been supported by clinical reports of long-term episodic memory impairments in psychiatric conditions with dissociative symptoms, in which individuals feel detached from themselves as if having an out-of-body experience. Here, we introduce an experimental approach to examine the necessary role of perceiving the world from the perspective of one's own body for the successful episodic encoding of real-life events. While participants were involved in a social interaction, an out-of-body illusion was elicited, in which the sense of bodily self was displaced from the real body to the other end of the testing room. This condition was compared with a well-matched in-body illusion condition, in which the sense of bodily self was colocalized with the real body. In separate recall sessions, performed ∼1 wk later, we assessed the participants' episodic memory of these events. The results revealed an episodic recollection deficit for events encoded out-of-body compared with in-body. Functional magnetic resonance imaging indicated that this impairment was specifically associated with activity changes in the posterior hippocampus. Collectively, these findings show that efficient hippocampus-based episodic-memory encoding requires a first-person perspective of the natural spatial relationship between the body and the world. Our observations have important implications for theoretical models of episodic memory, neurocognitive models of self, embodied cognition, and clinical research into memory deficits in psychiatric disorders.

studies.title: Autism spectrum traits predict the neural response to eye gaze in typical individuals.
studies.abstract: Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD) are neurodevelopmental disorders characterised by impaired social interaction and communication, restricted interests and repetitive behaviours. The severity of these characteristics are posited to lie on a continuum extending into the typical population, and typical adults' performance on behavioural tasks that are impaired in ASD is correlated with the extent to which they display autistic traits (as measured by Autism Spectrum Quotient, AQ). Individuals with ASD also show structural and functional differences in brain regions involved in social perception. Here we show that variation in AQ in typically developing individuals is associated with altered brain activity in the neural circuit for social attention perception while viewing others' eye gaze. In an fMRI experiment, participants viewed faces looking at variable or constant directions. In control conditions, only the eye region was presented or the heads were shown with eyes closed but oriented at variable or constant directions. The response to faces with variable vs. constant eye gaze direction was associated with AQ scores in a number of regions (posterior superior temporal sulcus, intraparietal sulcus, temporoparietal junction, amygdala, and MT/V5) of the brain network for social attention perception. No such effect was observed for heads with eyes closed or when only the eyes were presented. The results demonstrate a relationship between neurophysiology and autism spectrum traits in the typical (non-ASD) population and suggest that changes in the functioning of the neural circuit for social attention perception is associated with an extended autism spectrum in the typical population.

studies.title: Regional brain responses in nulliparous women to emotional infant stimuli.
studies.abstract: Infant cries and facial expressions influence social interactions and elicit caretaking behaviors from adults. Recent neuroimaging studies suggest that neural responses to infant stimuli involve brain regions that process rewards. However, these studies have yet to investigate individual differences in tendencies to engage or withdraw from motivationally relevant stimuli. To investigate this, we used event-related fMRI to scan 17 nulliparous women. Participants were presented with novel infant cries of two distress levels (low and high) and unknown infant faces of varying affect (happy, sad, and neutral) in a randomized, counter-balanced order. Brain activation was subsequently correlated with scores on the Behavioral Inhibition System/Behavioral Activation System scale. Infant cries activated bilateral superior and middle temporal gyri (STG and MTG) and precentral and postcentral gyri. Activation was greater in bilateral temporal cortices for low- relative to high-distress cries. Happy relative to neutral faces activated the ventral striatum, caudate, ventromedial prefrontal, and orbitofrontal cortices. Sad versus neutral faces activated the precuneus, cuneus, and posterior cingulate cortex, and behavioral activation drive correlated with occipital cortical activations in this contrast. Behavioral inhibition correlated with activation in the right STG for high- and low-distress cries relative to pink noise. Behavioral drive correlated inversely with putamen, caudate, and thalamic activations for the comparison of high-distress cries to pink noise. Reward-responsiveness correlated with activation in the left precentral gyrus during the perception of low-distress cries relative to pink noise. Our findings indicate that infant cry stimuli elicit activations in areas implicated in auditory processing and social cognition. Happy infant faces may be encoded as rewarding, whereas sad faces activate regions associated with empathic processing. Differences in motivational tendencies may modulate neural responses to infant cues.

studies.title: Limbic Interference During Social Action Planning in Schizophrenia.
studies.abstract: Schizophrenia is characterized by social interaction deficits contributing to poor functional outcome. Hand gesture use is particularly impaired, linked to frontal lobe dysfunction and frontal grey matter deficits. The functional neural correlates of impaired gesturing are currently unclear. We therefore investigated aberrant brain activity during impaired gesturing in schizophrenia. We included 22 patients with schizophrenia and 25 healthy control participants matched for age, gender, and education level. We obtained functional magnetic resonance imaging data using an event-related paradigm to assess brain activation during gesture planning and execution. Group differences in whole brain effects were calculated using factorial designs. Gesture ratings were performed by a single rater, blind to diagnoses and clinical presentation. During gesture planning and execution both groups activated brain areas of the praxis network. However, patients had reduced dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) and increased inferior parietal lobe (IPL) activity. Performance accuracy was associated with IPL activity in patients. Furthermore, patients activated temporal poles, amygdala and hippocampus during gesture planning, which was associated with delusion severity. Finally, patients demonstrated increased dorsomedial prefrontal cortex activity during planning of novel gestures. We demonstrate less prefrontal, but more IPL and limbic activity during gesturing in schizophrenia. IPL activity was associated with performance accuracy, whereas limbic activity was linked to delusion severity. These findings may reflect impaired social action planning and a limbic interference with gestures in schizophrenia contributing to poor gesture performance and consequently poor social functioning in schizophrenia.

studies.title: Distinct regions of the medial prefrontal cortex are associated with self-referential processing and perspective taking.
studies.abstract: The medial prefrontal cortex (MPFC) appears to play a prominent role in two fundamental aspects of social cognition, that is, self-referential processing and perspective taking. However, it is currently unclear whether the same or different regions of the MPFC mediate these two interdependent processes. This functional magnetic resonance imaging study sought to clarify the issue by manipulating both dimensions in a factorial design. Participants judged the extent to which trait adjectives described their own personality (e.g., "Are you sociable?") or the personality of a close friend (e.g., "Is Caroline sociable?") and were also asked to put themselves in the place of their friend (i.e., to take a third-person perspective) and estimate how this person would judge the adjectives, with the target of the judgments again being either the self (e.g., "According to Caroline, are you sociable?") or the other person (e.g., "According to Caroline, is she sociable?"). We found that self-referential processing (i.e., judgments targeting the self vs. the other person) yielded activation in the ventral and dorsal anterior MPFC, whereas perspective taking (i.e., adopting the other person's perspective, rather than one's own, when making judgments) resulted in activation in the posterior dorsal MPFC; the interaction between the two dimensions yielded activation in the left dorsal MPFC. These findings show that self-referential processing and perspective taking recruit distinct regions of the MPFC and suggest that the left dorsal MPFC may be involved in decoupling one's own from other people's perspectives on the self.

No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, and appears to be empirical fMRI data). Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

studies.title: Amygdala hypersensitivity in response to emotional faces in Tourette's patients.
studies.abstract: Tourette's syndrome is characterised by motor and vocal tics as well as a high level of impulsivity and emotional dysregulation. Neuroimaging studies point to structural changes of the basal ganglia, prefrontal cortex and parts of the limbic system. However, there is no link between behavioural symptoms and the structural changes in the amygdala. One aspect of daily social interaction is the perception of emotional facial expressions, closely linked to amgydala function.

fMRI study explicitly probing social interaction (gaze, social vs. arbitrary facial expressions, social communication, self-relevance). Aligns with review objective. fMRI study investigating neural processing of dyadic social interactions (classification of interaction types) in posterior temporal regions; involves social perception/understanding in human participants. No exclusion criteria met. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

The fMRI study examines social-emotional processing in schizophrenia patients (with and without SUD) and does not include any healthy control or healthy participant group (age 17–65) required by the review. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criterion of having at least one healthy participant group.

Original fMRI study measuring neural activity while participants processed social scenes (person interactions), addressing perception/understanding of others. Human participants and task clearly social; not a review. Abstract implies healthy adult sample. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing.

Abstract reports neural signatures of affective self- and other-touch (social-related processing: perception/understanding of self and others) comparing adults with ADHD and neurotypical controls, implying fMRI data. Includes a healthy adult control group. Not a review. Therefore meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI task involves social cognition (face processing and affect labeling). However, participant ages are 10–18 (controls non-clinical), so it is unclear whether a healthy adult group (17–65) is present. Abstract lacks sufficient age-group detail to confirm inclusion criterion — include for full-text review.

fMRI study in healthy adult volunteers (n=20) performing a social-related task—simulating and observing another person’s feelings—examining perception/understanding of others (AON). Meets inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults; no exclusion criteria apparent. Age range not specified but participants described as volunteers (likely adults); include for full-text review if ages need confirmation.

Abstract focuses on bvFTD network centrality and social-executive performance but does not state task-based fMRI or whether healthy adults were included. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone — include for full-text review.

fMRI study investigating neural correlates of speech acts/social communication (Requests vs Naming) in human participants. This addresses social communication processing and is empirical (not a review). Participant health/age not specified in abstract, but study involves healthy adult subjects typical for cognitive neuroscience; include for full-text review to confirm ages and participant details.

Participants are early adolescents (ages 10.5–13.4), outside the required 17–65 adult range. fMRI was resting-state (no task-based social processing paradigm); inclusion requires task-based fMRI during social-related tasks. Therefore excluded based on age and non-task fMRI.

fMRI study manipulating social cognitive load (social working memory) with neural activation sensitive to social processing and individual differences in perspective-taking. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and directly addresses social cognition processing. Not a review or meta-analysis.

Abstract reports an original fMRI study in humans investigating neural processing of social hierarchy (social cognition/perception). It describes task-based fMRI results engaging social-cognitive and emotional regions, implies healthy participants, and is not a review; thus meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Abstract describes fMRI acquisition during eye-contact dyadic social interaction (social processing). Human dyadic fMRI is implied but participant age and health status are not specified; insufficient detail to confirm healthy adults 17–65. Per protocol, include for full-text review to assess participant characteristics and eligibility.

Abstract describes a methodological tutorial on intersubject correlation rather than reporting a clear empirical fMRI study in healthy adults. Insufficient information to determine if original fMRI data meeting inclusion criteria are present—include for full-text review to verify.

This paper is an Activation Likelihood Estimation (ALE) meta-analysis of fMRI studies rather than a primary fMRI study collecting participant-level data. The exclusion criteria specify meta-analyses/systematic reviews should be excluded.

Participants are described as adolescent boys (minors), not adults. Although an fMRI social task and a healthy control group are present, the sample falls outside the required age range (17–65), so the study does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Study uses fMRI to investigate face-processing networks, a social-cognition task relevant to the review. Abstract focuses on temporal lobe epilepsy but does not state whether a healthy control group (ages 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to determine exclusion, so include for full-text review.

Human fMRI study using an attachment-related social task (baby-cry conditions). Includes a healthy adult control group (n=15) within age range. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Functional MRI study investigating empathy and social cognition (emotional vs neutral, one vs two persons) in human participants; assesses social-related processing automatically. No indication participants had psychiatric/neurological disorders. Abstract does not report participant ages explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm they meet the 17–65 age criterion.

Abstract reports an fMRI experiment (n=17) using mentalising/theory-of-mind story tasks—clearly social cognition processing. Participants appear to be healthy adults and the task was performed during fMRI. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study in 164 healthy adults performing an interactive mentalizing (Prisoner’s Dilemma) task assessing attachment/mentalizing (social cognition). This directly meets the inclusion criteria (social-related task with healthy adult participants) and is not a review.

fMRI study with healthy participants performing a social-related task (imagining triadic social interactions). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets review objective of social processing in healthy adults; age not specified but task and participants imply typical adult sample—include for full-text verification.

fMRI study with a social-cognitive task (third-party punishment) probing attribution of intentions/beliefs and moral responsibility; conducted in lay, healthy adult participants; directly addresses perception/understanding of others. Not a review or meta-analysis.

This is a review article summarizing fMRI findings in ASD rather than a primary fMRI study. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and does not report fMRI data from healthy adult participants performing social tasks.

Human fMRI study investigating perception of animacy (social perception) using BOLD responses; involves social-related processing in healthy adult participants (implied). Matches review objective of fMRI studies of social processing.

fMRI study examining processing of mutual vs. averted social gaze — a social-perception task involving viewing another person’s gaze shifts. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is not a review. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no task). Inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task; therefore it does not meet the task-based criterion despite involving social constructs and healthy adults.

fMRI study using the Human Connectome Project social cognition paradigm (a social-related task) that includes a matched healthy control group (n=25) performing the task. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults; not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study of voice recognition, a social-communication/perception-of-others task. Abstract reports matched healthy control participants (adults, age 32), satisfying requirement for a healthy adult group (17–65). Not a review. Include for full-text review to confirm details.

This is a review/chapter summarizing behavioral and neuroimaging literature, not an original fMRI study. It is a secondary synthesis (not primary data collection) and thus meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses.

This article is a review and meta-analysis (not an original fMRI study). It does not report primary fMRI data from healthy adult participants, meeting the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Participants are children (ASD and healthy controls), not adults 17–65; the fMRI data are resting-state and not collected during a social-related task; the study examines language network/connectivity, not social processing. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports neural responses to dynamic multimodal emotional/social stimuli in schizophrenia and depression, indicating social-cognition neuroimaging. However, it does not explicitly state use of fMRI nor confirm presence and ages of healthy control participants. Because the topic matches the review objective but key methodological details are missing, include for full-text review to confirm fMRI scanning and healthy adult group (17–65).

Abstract reports an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=38) performing mental-state judgments—directly assessing social cognition/understanding of others using naturalistic stimuli. Participants are healthy and within target age bracket; this is original research (not a review). Therefore it meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-processing studies.

Resting-state fMRI study (no social task performed) and participants are adolescents (mean ~14.5 years; range 10–18) — no healthy adult group within 17–65. Thus fails task-based and age inclusion criteria.
Study used fMRI during a simple motor task in autistic patients and controls; it does not investigate social-related processing in healthy adults, so it does not meet the review’s inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social cognition (theory-of-mind/false-belief reasoning) conducted with human participants; includes two healthy comparison groups comprising 480 adults (meets healthy adult group criterion). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract supplies sufficient information to include for full-text review.
All participants are patients with schizophrenia/schizoaffective disorder (n=47); no healthy control group is reported. Meta-analysis requires at least one healthy participant group (ages 17–65).

This study used resting-state fMRI in a developmental adolescent sample (ages 14–26) to examine maturation of functional connectivity. It did not include a social-related task or a defined healthy adult (17–65) task group. References to social cognition maps are retrospective comparisons, not task-based social processing in adults.

fMRI study where participants read passages varying in social content; investigates neural substrates of social cognition (dmPFC subnetwork) and links reading to social-cognitive performance. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and addresses perception/understanding of others. Not a review.

Abstract reports a task-based whole-brain fMRI study in humans examining social-cognitive and valuation responses to others’ popularity (face-viewing task). It targets social processing (perception/understanding of others) and does not appear to be a review; participants appear to be healthy group members. Age not specified in abstract, so moderate confidence; include for full-text review.

This is a review article (the abstract states 'The present review...'), not an original fMRI study with human participants performing a social task. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Participants are described as 'youth' (high-functioning youth with ASD and typically-developing controls), indicating they are under the 17–65 age range required. Although the fMRI social task and healthy control group are relevant, the healthy participants do not meet the age inclusion criterion.

fMRI study examining guilt (a social emotion) and social-cognition neural activity; tasks involve social-related processing. Abstract does not specify participant ages or health status, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility (healthy adults 17–65).

Abstract does not specify a task-based social processing fMRI paradigm or inclusion of a healthy adult group (ages 17–65). Focus is on neural connectivity in ASD; insufficient information to determine whether healthy adults performed a social-related task. Include for full-text review to clarify task, participant characteristics, and whether inclusion criteria are met.

All participants were older adults (mean age 79), exceeding the review's required healthy participant age range (17–65). Although it used fMRI on social/empathy tasks, the sample falls outside inclusion age limits.

Parametric fMRI study where human participants evaluated political beliefs—a social cognition task involving self-other processing and social decision-making. Not a review. While participant ages/groups are not explicitly stated, the study clearly reports task-based fMRI of social-related processing, so include for full-text review to confirm sample demographics.

Study reports fMRI experiments on biological motion perception (a social-perception task) and includes healthy adult participants alongside a schizophrenia group; not a review. Therefore it meets the fMRI + social-processing + healthy adult group inclusion criteria.
Participants are non-human (dogs); the study used canine fMRI rather than human adults. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring human participants aged 17–65.

Participants are children and adolescents with ASD and matched controls (not adults aged 17–65). No healthy adult group is reported; fMRI appears connectivity-based rather than a social-task in healthy adults. Fails age/sample inclusion criteria.

Study uses fMRI to investigate facial emotion perception, a social-processing task. Abstract does not clearly state presence of healthy control group or participant ages; insufficient information to confirm exclusion. Include for full-text review to verify healthy adult group (17–65) and task details.

Abstract reports fMRI of emotional sentence attribution in schizophrenia (a social processing task) but does not specify whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Because the task matches the review objective but participant groups are unclear, include for full-text review to confirm presence of eligible healthy participants.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing an interactive, social joint-action task (leading/following/mutual). Examines social-cognitive processes (mentalizing, social reward, perception of others), meeting inclusion criteria; not a review.

fMRI study of social reward processing (feedback about being liked) in human participants; sample are late adolescents aged 18–21 (within the 17–65 range) who appear to be healthy participants varying in social anhedonia; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Imaging modality mismatch: the study used functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS), not functional MRI. Although it examines social cognition in healthy adults, it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring fMRI.

fMRI study of healthy participants performing vocal emotional processing (social communication/perception of others), fitting the review’s social-processing task criterion. The abstract does not report participant ages (17–65 requirement unclear), so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility; not a review article.

Functional MRI was performed during social-cognition tasks (face processing, emotion recognition, affective ToM). The study includes a healthy matched control group (adult participants). Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports event-related fMRI to positive social stimuli (meets social-task criterion) but does not state whether healthy adult participants (age 17–65) were included. Insufficient information to confirm presence of a healthy control group; include for full-text review.

Study used fMRI during a second-order Theory of Mind task (a social cognition paradigm) and included a healthy control group (25 adults). It is an original fMRI study, not a review, meeting the inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI study examining legal decision-making about others’ mental states and responses to social/emotional manipulations—meets social-processing and fMRI criteria. Participant ages/health status are not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study investigating emotional inference and social-cognitive processing from vocalizations and music, which fits social-related processing (social communication/perception of others). Human participants performed an active task during fMRI. Abstract doesn’t specify ages or explicit healthy status, so include for full-text review to confirm sample characteristics.

This article is a critical appraisal/review of naturalistic stimuli in neuroscience, not an original fMRI study. The abstract does not report fMRI data from healthy adults performing social-related tasks; it is a review, so excluded.

fMRI study examining social attribution/ToM processing using a social decision task; includes a healthy control group (17 healthy women) alongside RAN participants. Study involves human adults and is not a review or meta-analysis. Satisfies inclusion criteria.

Participants are preschool-aged children with ASD and typically developing children, not healthy adults (17–65). Although the task is social-related, the study lacks a healthy adult participant group required by the review.

Study used fMRI during a visual perspective-taking task (social cognition), and included a healthy control group of 20 age- and gender-matched volunteers (adult sample). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI decoding applied to social cognition tasks and validates models on the HCP dataset, which consists of healthy adult participants. Therefore it involves fMRI during social-related tasks in healthy adults and meets inclusion criteria.

The study uses fMRI during social processing and includes a typically developing (healthy) control group. However, participants are described as adolescents and ages are not specified; inclusion requires healthy participants aged 17–65. Abstract provides insufficient age detail, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants watching realistic social-interaction movie clips (social cognition/perception of others). Meets inclusion criteria (social-related task, healthy subjects). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

fMRI was used in young, healthy participants performing an incentive delay task with social rewards (anticipation and feedback). This addresses social-related processing in healthy adults within the target age range and is an original empirical study (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

fMRI was used to assess processing of biological (body) motion, a social-perception task, and the study included a group of healthy matched controls. The abstract does not specify participant ages; because age range is unclear, include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI was conducted while participants completed social-related tasks (IAT about adultery and a date-rating task assessing interest in unfamiliar females), addressing affiliation/attachment and perception of others. Participants are human adults in romantic relationships, and this is original research (not a review). Abstract lacks explicit ages but otherwise meets inclusion criteria; include for full-text review.
Participants are young children (4 and 6 years old); the study does not include healthy adult participants aged 17–65. Therefore it does not meet the age-based inclusion criterion for the review.

fMRI BOLD data were collected while healthy adult participants (N=23) performed affective and cognitive Theory of Mind tasks, which are social-processing measures (perception/understanding of others). Study is primary research in healthy humans and not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (MDs aged 25–37) performing a social-related treatment task involving empathy and doctor–patient interaction. Task probes social processing (empathy, reward, clinician–patient rapport) and meets inclusion criteria; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

fMRI was conducted during face perception/recognition (social processing). The study includes a group of healthy control subjects compared to a clinical case; participants are adults. This meets inclusion criteria (social task, at least one healthy adult group). Not a review.

Abstract reports an fMRI investigation of attentional and attributional biases (social cognition). However, participant characteristics (presence of healthy control group and ages) are not specified in the abstract. Because the study clearly uses fMRI on social-related processing but lacks sufficient participant detail, include for full-text review to confirm inclusion criteria.

Event-related fMRI study of moral decision-making (a social cognitive task) including a healthy control group (28 matched subjects) alongside ASD patients. Not a review/meta-analysis. Fits social-processing fMRI in healthy adults; include for full-text to confirm age range/details.

fMRI study in healthy participants performing imitation (a social-related task involving perception/understanding of others and social communication). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract lacks explicit ages but participants are healthy adults; meets inclusion criteria for full review.

fMRI study of implicit facial emotion recognition, which is a social-related task. Abstract describes participants with high genetic load for schizophrenia but does not clearly state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Because the task and imaging modality match inclusion criteria but information on healthy participants/ages is insufficient, include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study examining perception/understanding of others (action perception) and includes a healthy participant group (n=31). This matches the review objective and inclusion criteria; no exclusion criteria are met. Abstract lacks precise ages but clearly reports healthy adults, so include for full-text review.

fMRI was used while participants listened to literary excerpts probing mentalizing (understanding others’ beliefs/intentions), a core social-processing construct. Study appears to involve healthy adult participants and is not a review. Satisfies inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults.

fMRI study of empathy (perception/understanding of others), involving healthy participants performing a social-related task. Not a review/meta-analysis. Satisfies inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults; abstract provides sufficient detail to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI study examining social-related processing (empathy/perspective-taking, attachment) in human participants; not a review. Abstract does not report participant ages or explicit health status, so include for full-text review to confirm participants are healthy adults aged 17–65.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (13 right-handed healthy males) performing a social cognition task (theory of mind and empathy cartoons), directly addressing social-related processing in healthy adults. Not a review or meta-analysis.

The article is a review of social neuroscience in psychiatry (narrative overview). Abstract indicates synthesis of findings rather than reporting original task-based fMRI data in healthy adults. Exclude per exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI was conducted while participants performed the Reading the Mind in the Eyes Test (a social-cognitive task involving perception/understanding of others). Participants were healthy young adult women within the 17–65 range. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Human fMRI study examining neural responses to dynamic social-attention cues (head turns) in STS, clearly addressing social perception/understanding of others. No evidence of disqualifying populations or being a review; meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants using action observation (watching others perform a task) which assesses perception/understanding of others and effort — a social-related process. Not a review/meta-analysis; meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining neural networks for understanding actions and mental-state reasoning, which maps onto social cognition (perception/understanding of others). Uses human participants and task-based fMRI. Abstract does not state ages/health explicitly, but meets review topic; include for full-text review to confirm participant demographics and health.

Abstract reports fMRI-measured changes in networks associated with social cognition/theory of mind but does not specify that participants performed an explicit social task or age/health details. Insufficient information to confirm task meets inclusion; include for full-text review to verify task details and participant characteristics.

This article is a literature review/commentary on fMRI reliability rather than an original fMRI study. It does not report primary data of a social-related fMRI task in healthy adults. It meets the exclusion criterion (review/meta-analysis), so exclude based on abstract alone.

Study involves pediatric stroke patients and examines resting-state connectivity, not task-based fMRI during social processing in healthy adults. Participants are children with neurological disorder, so it does not meet the population (healthy adults 17–65) or task-based fMRI criteria.

Participants are children (ASD and age-matched typically developing), not adults. Inclusion requires at least one healthy participant group aged 17–65; the abstract provides no indication of adult participants. Therefore it does not meet the age criterion.

fMRI performed while participants (pairs of friends) completed a social-related task (social sharing/affiliation). Participants appear to be healthy adults; study focuses on social-affiliative processes and reports neural activity. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

This article is a review/reappraisal of social cognition in multiple sclerosis, summarizing neuropsychological and neuroimaging studies. It is not a primary task-based fMRI study of healthy adults. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and does not provide evidence of an fMRI social task in healthy participants.

fMRI measured brain activity while healthy adult participants watched emotional/social movie scenes, engaging perception and understanding of others and social interaction. Task involves social-related processing; participants appear healthy; study is original research (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

fMRI study investigating theory-of-mind/social cognition during cooperative vs competitive interactions with human partners. Involves task-based fMRI of social processing in (presumably) healthy adult participants and is not a review. Meets inclusion criteria; abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

Study uses resting-state fMRI (no social-related task performed). Inclusion requires an fMRI scan during a social task; mentioning 'social cognition' networks in resting-state is insufficient. Therefore exclude based on not meeting task-based social-processing criterion.

fMRI study measuring responses to social and linguistic stimuli in human participants (social perception/cognition). Abstract suggests healthy adult sample but does not report ages; insufficient detail on age range, so include for full-text review to confirm inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI during negative emotion processing but does not specify a social-related task (e.g., social cognition, perception of others). It likely includes healthy adults, but social relevance is unclear from the abstract alone. Include for full-text review to determine whether the task is social.

fMRI was used while participants (including a matched healthy control group of adults) thought about social interactions, addressing social-related processing. The study includes healthy adult controls alongside an autism group and is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI was used with standardized probes of social reward and threat processing (social-related task). Study includes a matched healthy control group aged 50–60 (within 17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis.

Study used EEG to examine mu rhythm during emotion classification, not functional MRI. Does not meet inclusion criterion requiring an fMRI scan. Other criteria (healthy adults) are likely met, but modality mismatch excludes it.

Empirical fMRI study where participants performed a social interactive task (and in-group/out-group manipulations) compared to a non-social control. This assesses social cognition in human subjects and is not a review. Abstract implies healthy adult sample; if ages are unclear, full-text can confirm. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing.

Study reports task-based whole-brain fMRI in 15 healthy adult volunteers performing a social aggression/retaliation task (interaction with provoking vs. non-provoking opponent), which constitutes social-related processing. Participants are healthy adults (fits 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to determine eligibility.

Abstract reports fMRI during social cognition tasks (theory of mind) and includes a group of age-, gender- and education-matched healthy controls. This meets the inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults; no exclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study using a social attention/gaze-following task examining responses to in-group/out-group political faces — a clear social processing task in humans. Although ages/health status are not explicitly stated, participants are implied to be healthy adult voters; therefore it meets inclusion or at minimum should be forwarded to full-text review for confirmation.

This is a systematic review of social cognition training in schizophrenia (clinical populations), not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. Systematic reviews are explicitly excluded, and the participant group is patients rather than healthy participants.

fMRI task explicitly probes social cognition (inferring mental states from film excerpts). The study includes healthy control groups (28 HC; reproducibility in 14 HC). Not a review/meta-analysis. Age range not specified in abstract—because this is unclear, include for full-text review to confirm ages meet 17–65.

fMRI study using MVPA examining neural representation of others' mental states (social cognition). Not a review; likely conducted in healthy adult participants. Abstract meets the review objective (social-related fMRI). Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health.

Abstract reports task-related fMRI during a social perception experiment and includes a healthy control group (n=21). The task targets social-related processing (social perception/self-related networks). Not a review. Sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Abstract reports an fMRI task (self- and other-reflection) relevant to social processing but does not specify whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to confirm presence of healthy adults — include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

This is a narrative review article summarizing neuroimaging, genetics, and pathology of semantic dementia, not a primary fMRI study. It does not report task-based fMRI data in healthy adults nor focus on social processing. Excluded per the criterion excluding reviews and because no original task-based fMRI data in healthy participants are presented.

fMRI study investigating how the brain represents similarity between self and others during a social task (learning others’ preferences), involving social cognition and reward networks. Abstract indicates an fMRI task in humans and addresses perception/understanding of others. Participant health/ages not specified; include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.
Participants are school-age children (ages 9–13), not within the required adult age range (17–65). Although it's an fMRI study of social cognition, it fails the age inclusion criterion.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (perception of others’ pain/empathy). Meets inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults; not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

fMRI study using a social-related task (self-referential processing: judging trait adjectives about self, mother, president). Includes a healthy control group alongside schizophrenia patients (healthy adults likely within 17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Event-related fMRI during an irony comprehension task (social communication/perception of others) with a healthy control group (15 adult females) meets inclusion: social-related task and at least one healthy adult group. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient detail to include for full-text extraction.

Human fMRI study of perception of different laughter types (social communication/social cognition) in healthy adults; directly assesses social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides clear task and modality, so meets inclusion criteria.

This article is a review discussing MRI and behavioural research in adolescent social cognition rather than an original fMRI study with human participants. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and therefore should be excluded.

This article is a meta-analytic review of fMRI studies (not an original fMRI study). Exclusion criterion met: systematic reviews/meta-analyses are excluded. Although it addresses social cognition among other domains, it does not report primary fMRI data collected from healthy participants performing social tasks.

Double-blind placebo-controlled fMRI study of 55 healthy young men performing social-related tasks (attachment-related erotic scenes and fearful social scenes). Task-based fMRI in healthy adults directly fits the review objective; not a review article.

fMRI study of facial emotional processing (social cognition) in adults; includes a control group matched for age and IQ (healthy adults). Meets inclusion: social-related task, functional MRI, and at least one healthy adult group (likely age 17–65). Abstract is sufficiently clear to include for full-text review.

Abstract is a narrative review of neuroimaging in autism (summarizing prior PET/SPECT/fMRI studies), not an original fMRI experiment in healthy adults. It focuses on autistic patients and appears to be a review article, meeting exclusion criteria for reviews.

fMRI study using the iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma (a social interaction task) in healthy subjects; examines neural responses during social interactions. Meets inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task, healthy participant group). Not a review.

The study reports an fMRI (BOLD) investigation of social cognition (processing kin vs. friends) in 25 healthy adult female participants, directly addressing social-related processing in humans. It is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review) and fits the review objective. Age range not specified, but participants are adults; include for full-text review to confirm ages and other eligibility details.

Resting-state fMRI (no social task); study examines cerebro-cerebellar limbic networks in MCI/AD rather than social processing in healthy adults 17–65. Does not meet task-based social processing criterion.

fMRI study where adolescents (mean age 17) viewed videos of their parents—clearly a social-processing task (perception/understanding of others). Participants appear healthy and age falls within 17–65. No exclusion criteria met.

Resting-state (task-free) fMRI study in healthy adults investigating language-network connectivity, not a task-based social processing paradigm. The abstract does not report any social-related task or measures of social cognition, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with 26 healthy adult participants performing an empathy-evoking social cognition task (film clips with contextual/musical manipulation). Directly examines social-related processing in adults and is an original empirical study (not a review). Satisfies inclusion criteria.

This publication is a review article (narrative review of behavioral and imaging studies), not an original fMRI experiment in healthy adults. Exclusion criterion: systematic reviews or meta-analyses. Insufficient as a primary fMRI study.

Abstract describes a narrative review of developmental social brain research, not an original fMRI experiment. It summarizes MRI/fMRI findings across adolescence rather than reporting a primary fMRI study with healthy adult participants, so it meets the exclusion criterion for reviews.

fMRI study examining neural processing of different laughter types and attention to social information—addresses social communication/perception of others. Involves human participants and appears to study healthy adults (no clinical groups reported). Not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Hyperscanning fMRI study of real-time social interaction (joint attention) directly assesses social processing. Abstract implies healthy human dyads but does not specify participant ages; insufficient age detail for exclusion. Include for full-text review to confirm age range and participant health.

Abstract describes a face-processing task with neural activity but does not explicitly state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was scanned. Because the abstract provides insufficient information about the presence/age of healthy participants, include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

fMRI study where healthy late-adolescent participants (ages 18–22) observed risk-taking versus safe actions, a social-cognition/emotional-processing task involving perception and understanding of others. Participants are within the eligible age range (17–65) and the study is original research, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports real-time fMRI during the ultimatum game, a social interaction/decision-making task, with volunteers (healthy participants) and identifies neural correlates of social behavior. It is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults and not a review, meeting inclusion criteria.

Study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. Inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults; although healthy controls were included, no social task was performed, so it does not meet the primary inclusion criterion.

fMRI study of self-reference vs. reference to others — clearly social-cognitive tasks. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit healthy status, but no clinical groups are mentioned. Because age/health criteria are not explicitly reported in the abstract, include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Event-related fMRI was used while subjects performed a social-related task (judging trustworthiness of faces), directly addressing social perception of others. The study appears to involve human subjects with no indication of clinical populations and is a primary research article (not a review). Recommend full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

This is an fMRI study of Theory of Mind (social cognition/perception and understanding of others) in healthy adult participants (n=19). It involves a social-related task (REMICS) and is not a review/meta-analysis. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a review/proposal of deep brain stimulation for severe autism, not an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. The abstract does not report functional MRI during a social task or data from healthy participants aged 17–65.

fMRI study with 18 healthy adult participants performing a social motor response learning task involving inference about others' intentions (social processing). Meets inclusion criteria (social-related task, healthy adults). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.
Study used fMRI to examine Theory of Mind (a social-cognitive task) and includes a healthy comparison group of adults. This directly meets inclusion criteria and is not a review.

fMRI study with 29 healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (explicit emotion recognition vs implicit age discrimination of facial expressions) probing social communication/perception of others; not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Non-human animal study (rats) using resting-state fMRI under anesthesia; not a task-based fMRI of social processing in human adults. Does not meet inclusion criteria of human participants aged 17–65 performing social tasks.

Abstract examines neural substrates of social cognition and face processing in healthy young adults but does not explicitly state that fMRI scanning or a social task was used. Methods are unclear from abstract alone, so include for full-text review to confirm fMRI and task details.

fMRI study examines social perception (dynamic/static social stimuli) and reports data from typically developing adolescents as a healthy comparison group. Age range not specified beyond 'adolescents', so inclusion for full-text review is needed to confirm participants meet 17–65 criterion; otherwise meets social-task and healthy-group criteria.

fMRI study using point-light displays of biological motion—a social perception task (Perception and Understanding of Others). Sample includes adults and school-age youth; adults are healthy participants. The task was performed during scanning and the paper is original research (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Both participant groups are adolescents (typically developing adolescents and adolescents with TBI), not healthy adults aged 17–65 required by the inclusion criteria. Although fMRI during a social cognition task was used, the healthy sample is outside the eligible age range.

fMRI study using an empathy-for-pain task (social cognition: perception/understanding of others). Includes a healthy young adult group aged 20–30 (within 17–65), satisfying inclusion criteria. Not a review.

All participants are individuals with a psychotic disorder; the abstract does not report any healthy control group. Although it is an fMRI study of social (facial affect) processing, it fails the requirement of including at least one healthy participant group (age 17–65).

Hyperscanning fMRI during joint attention tasks addresses social cognition (perception/understanding of others). Study reports task-based fMRI activation in participants (presumably healthy adults) and is not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-processing studies in healthy adults.

Participants are children/adolescents (ages 10–17); no clear adult (17–65) healthy group. Study focuses on developmental sample rather than healthy adults, so it does not meet the age inclusion criterion.

Neuroimaging study reporting neural correlates of interpersonal synchrony and affiliation in healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (perception of synchrony/affiliation). Fits inclusion criteria (fMRI during social processing); not a review.

Study used fMRI during social-related task (neural response to facial expressions/emotional processing) and includes a healthy control group. Abstract does not specify participant ages (17–65), so full text is needed to confirm age eligibility. Include for full-text review.

All participants were patients with amnestic mild cognitive impairment; no healthy adult group (age 17–65) is included. Although the fMRI task (face–name encoding) involves social/emotional processing, the study fails the criterion requiring at least one healthy participant group.

fMRI study investigating impression updating (perception/understanding of others) — a social cognition task. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit healthy status. Because stimulus/task and imaging meet inclusion but key participant details are missing, include for full-text review to confirm health and age criteria.

Empirical fMRI study using the Why/How Task to probe Theory of Mind (social cognition) across three experiments; involves healthy adult participants and reports task-based functional MRI results. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI was used while healthy adult mothers viewed images of their own vs unfamiliar child and dog, addressing affiliation/attachment and social processing. Participants are adults; task is social-related. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

The study used resting-state fMRI in healthy males following intranasal oxytocin; no social-related task was performed during scanning. Thus it does not meet the inclusion requirement of an fMRI scan during a social-related task.

fMRI was resting-state (no social-related task); inclusion requires a functional MRI during a social task. Although oxytocin relates to social behavior, the study did not involve task-based social processing in the scanner.

fMRI study examines processing of social vs nonsocial gestures—directly addresses social-related processing. Abstract does not state participant health status or ages; cannot confirm inclusion criteria regarding healthy adults (17–65). Per screening rules, include for full-text review to confirm participant characteristics.

Abstract reports an fMRI study examining social influence during a group decision-making task, directly addressing social processing and neural correlates. Although participant age/health isn’t explicitly stated, the study appears to involve healthy adult participants. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related task; include for full-text review to confirm sample demographics.

fMRI was used while participants performed a social-related task (self-attribute evaluations; perception/understanding of self). Abstract reports neural results in healthy-sounding samples and no clinical groups are mentioned. Age range not specified in abstract — include for full-text review to confirm participant age/health details.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants investigating self-recognition (self-face and name), which falls under Perception and Understanding of Self — a social-related construct. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract indicates healthy adult sample and task-based fMRI, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of self–other processing (social cognition) including a healthy typically developing control group of young adults (age within 17–65). Task is social-related (self vs other judgments). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.
This paper is a meta-analysis/systematic review of >200 fMRI studies rather than an original fMRI study in healthy adults, meeting the exclusion criterion.

Abstract describes a review/narrative article about resting-state fMRI and social cognition, not an original study with participants performing a social-related fMRI task. No task-based fMRI data in healthy adults are reported.

This is a review/overview chapter summarizing oxytocin studies (including fMRI) in schizophrenia spectrum disorders rather than an original fMRI study in healthy adults. It is a secondary source and appears focused on clinical populations, so it does not meet inclusion for primary fMRI data in healthy participants.

Abstract does not specify that an fMRI task was used or whether healthy adult participants (age 17–65) were included. The study concerns neurobiological correlates of social-cognitive processes in psychopathy, which aligns with the review objective. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone — include for full-text review.

Participants are children (high-functioning ASD and typically developing children), not adults; no healthy participant group within the required age range (17–65). Although it uses fMRI and a social/pragmatic language task, it fails the criteria requiring healthy adult participants.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants using face-viewing task comparing racial ingroup vs outgroup faces — a social-cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Participants appear to be healthy adults; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Dual‑fMRI study where participants performed social interaction tasks (cooperation and competition), directly addressing social processing with functional MRI. Abstract does not report participant ages/health status; inclusion requires confirming healthy adults 17–65. Include for full‑text review to verify sample characteristics.

fMRI study investigating face processing (perception/understanding of others), a social-related task, with a healthy control group (n=21). Fits the review objective and inclusion criteria; not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text extraction.

This is a narrative review of human neuroimaging literature on cerebellar function, not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses.

Participants are criminal offenders from an adjudicated inpatient forensic psychiatric population (psychotic and nonpsychotic offenders). No group of healthy (community) adults is reported; nonpsychotic offenders are not clearly 'healthy' controls. Therefore it does not meet the criterion of including at least one healthy participant group.

Original fMRI study examining neural processing of social interaction/mentalizing in human participants (live vs recorded speech). Not a review/meta-analysis. Task probes social communication/understanding of others. Although participant ages aren’t specified in the abstract, it clearly involves healthy adult participants and meets inclusion; include for full-text review to confirm demographics.

The paper is a coordinate-based multimodal meta-analysis of fMRI and VBM studies in first-degree relatives of schizophrenia patients. It is a meta-analysis, which meets the exclusion criterion (systematic reviews/meta-analyses). The abstract does not report primary fMRI data of social-processing tasks in healthy adults.

Abstract does not report an fMRI study or any neuroimaging; it examines gene–environment interaction and response inhibition in adolescents, not social-related processing. Participants are adolescents (likely under 17), outside the 17–65 adult range. Thus it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of emotion perception/social communication (facial and vocal emotion discrimination and priming) in human participants. Abstract does not explicitly state participant ages or health status, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.
Abstract explicitly states this is a review article; it does not report original fMRI data from healthy adult participants. Excluded per criterion: systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Abstract examines neural bases of biological motion perception (a social-related process) and includes a healthy control group (N=67). However, the imaging modality is not specified in the abstract—fMRI is not confirmed. Insufficient information to determine whether an fMRI task was used; include for full-text review.

FMRI study in healthy participants performing self-descriptiveness judgments (Perception/Understanding of Self), a social-related task. Neural correlates reported; not a review or meta-analysis. Although ages not stated in abstract, participants are described as healthy (no psychiatric/neurological groups mentioned). Meets inclusion criteria; include for full-text review.

Randomized within-subject pharmaco-fMRI in 40 healthy adult males assessing neural and emotional responses to interpersonal touch (social communication/affiliation). Fits inclusion: fMRI, social-related task, healthy adults 17–65. Not a review.

fMRI study examining social cognition (agency and communion) using a valence classification task in humans. Abstract indicates social-related processing; however participant demographics/health status and ages are not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study measuring neural responses to visible and invisible faces (facial identity and expression), directly addressing social perception/communication. Involves human observers (presumably healthy adults); abstract lacks explicit age info, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health.

fMRI study on voice processing (social auditory information), relevant to social communication. Abstract implies comparison to normal activation patterns, suggesting healthy control data, but does not explicitly state controls or ages. Because inclusion hinges on presence of healthy adults and abstract is not fully explicit, include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

The study investigates memory retrieval, white-matter connectivity, and functional networks in ventrolateral PFC, not social-related processes. The fMRI task is not social (no affiliation, communication, or self/other perception), so it does not meet the review’s inclusion criteria.

Functional MRI was conducted during a validated social cognition (Theory of Mind) task (Reading the Mind in the Eyes) in a sample of healthy adult volunteers (18 males, within 17–65). Study is empirical fMRI research of social processing, not a review, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using a social task (social BART) but sample is ages 8–17 (adolescents). Inclusion requires at least one healthy participant group aged 17–65; the abstract does not clearly report a distinct adult group (only up to age 17). Include for full-text review to verify whether adult (17+) participants meet the review age criterion.

fMRI study of mentalizing (social cognition) with tasks involving self/other judgments; includes a healthy adult control group (33 age- and IQ-matched controls, adults). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

This article is a meta-analysis of neuroimaging studies (systematic review/meta-analysis), not a primary fMRI study. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses and does not provide original fMRI data from healthy adults.

Abstract reports testing social cognitive networks in patients with schizophrenia and their unaffected siblings using neural activation measures (implying fMRI) during social cognitive tasks; includes a healthy group (unaffected siblings, adults). No exclusion criteria met. Full text should be reviewed for explicit fMRI methods and participant ages/details.

The article is a narrative discussion/review of resting-state fMRI findings in ASD rather than an original task-based fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It does not report functional MRI during a social-related task and is not appropriate for inclusion.

fMRI study of charitable donation decisions (social decision-making/altruism), implicating affiliation/attachment and perception/understanding of others. Conducted in human participants (healthy adults likely within 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study in adults using a social task (viewing dynamic emotional facial expressions); includes a healthy control group (adults) alongside ASD participants. Fits social perception/understanding criteria and meets age/group requirements; not a review.

The article is a narrative review of negative symptoms, social cognition and facial affect processing in schizophrenia, summarizing behavioural and imaging (fMRI) studies rather than reporting new fMRI experiments. The abstract does not describe original fMRI scans on healthy adult participants, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion.

fMRI study where participants viewed approaching characters displaying angry/happy expressions, investigating social perception (social communication/affiliation). Involves human participants (presumably healthy adults), fits the review objective and inclusion criteria, and is not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

Abstract examines oxytocin effects in adults with Asperger syndrome and does not specify any healthy control group. Inclusion requires at least one healthy adult group; because the abstract lacks this information, it should be included for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Abstract describes a program of fMRI research including studies of typically developing adults in social perception, but it reads like a program/narrative review and does not report specific primary study details (participant ages, sample). Insufficient information to confirm inclusion—include for full-text review to determine if original fMRI data on healthy adults (17–65) are reported.
Resting-state fMRI study (no social task); participants are children with ASD and controls (not healthy adults aged 17–65). Does not meet task-based healthy adult inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes methodological network analysis of functional connectivity related to psychosis risk; no indication that participants performed a social-related task or that social processing was assessed. Therefore it does not meet the fMRI social-task inclusion criterion.

fMRI study in which participants read a narrative; reported activations are in brain regions associated with social cognition and predictive inference, indicating a social-related task (perception/understanding of others). Abstract does not report participant ages or explicit health status, so include for full-text review to confirm sample meets age and health criteria.

fMRI study with healthy adult Danish Christian participants performing prayer, which the authors interpret as recruiting social-cognition networks (medial PFC, TPJ, precuneus). Task involves social-related processing (perception/understanding of others/God). No exclusion criteria met.

Sample consists of typically developing adolescents aged 14–18 with no clearly defined adult group within the 17–65 range. Although ages include 17–18, the study focuses on adolescents rather than a distinct adult (17–65) group required by the review. Therefore it does not meet the age inclusion criterion.

fMRI recorded during live social exchanges (reciprocal imitation), addressing social cognition and interaction. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adult sample (17–65).

This article is a voxel-based meta-analysis (systematic meta-analysis) of fMRI studies rather than an original fMRI study of participants; exclusion criterion disallows systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Abstract focuses on schizophrenia and cognitive remediation; it mentions social cognition but does not specify that an fMRI social-task was performed or whether healthy control participants (age 17–65) were included. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone — include for full-text review.
This article is a large-scale meta-analysis of fMRI studies rather than a primary fMRI study of social processing in human participants. Exclusion criterion: systematic reviews or meta-analyses.

fMRI study with 36 healthy adult participants (age within 17–65 range implied) performing social interaction observation task probing perception/understanding of others; not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria.

This is an essay/review advocating cross-species social neuroscience; the abstract describes conceptual arguments rather than an empirical fMRI study. No human participants, fMRI scanning, or social task are reported, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI was conducted during an empathy task (a social cognition/Perception and Understanding of Others construct) and the study included a healthy control group of adults. Not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

The article reports an Activation Likelihood Estimation (coordinate-based) meta-analysis comparing schizophrenia patients and healthy controls. It is a meta-analysis rather than an original fMRI study, meeting the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study of verbal irony comprehension engaging Theory of Mind network (social communication/perception of others). Participants are described as human listeners (implied healthy adults). Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

This is a selective (narrative) review article synthesizing existing neuroimaging literature, not an original fMRI study reporting participant-level data or scans during a social-related task in healthy adults. It therefore does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring an fMRI study with human participants.

Abstract describes a multilevel kernel density fMRI analysis (meta-analytic approach) investigating neural bases of sexual desire and love. Exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews or meta-analyses; therefore exclude.

fMRI study where healthy participants processed vocal emotions (social communication/perception of others). Task involves decoding emotional prosody—clearly social-related processing. Not a review/meta-analysis and meets participant criteria. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

The study reports fMRI during an affective ToM task in 25 unmedicated chronic depression patients and does not mention any healthy control or healthy participant group. Inclusion requires at least one healthy group (age 17–65). The paper is original research (not a review), so it fails the healthy-participants inclusion criterion based on the abstract.

fMRI study examining mothers’ brain responses to emotional expressions of their children — a social/attachment-related task. Participants are adult mothers (healthy adult sample) comparing preterm vs. full-term; meets age and healthy-participant criteria. Not a review article. Abstract provides sufficient detail to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI study of empathy/social processing comparing responses to self, familiar friend, and stranger; involves healthy adult participants and uses a social-related task (perception/understanding of others). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social cognition (automatic perception of cooperative behavior) with a healthy matched control group (19 controls) and patient group; task is social-related and meets inclusion. Although ages aren’t specified, 'matched controls' implies adult participants; include for full-text review to confirm age range.

Abstract focuses on structural MRI (VBM) associations with moral sentiments but also references subgenual cingulate fMRI responses; it is unclear whether functional scans were acquired during a social-related task as required. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone — include for full-text review to confirm presence of task-based fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study of social interaction (friend vs celebrity) manipulating relationship and emotional valence; probes affiliation, empathy, and reward-related social processing. Sample of 28 human participants (presumably healthy adults). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria based on abstract.

fMRI study in healthy participants investigating social-signal detection and mental-state inference (eye-gaze, self-propulsion, implicit mental inference). Directly fits review objective of social processing in healthy adults and is not a review. Age range not reported in abstract; include for full-text confirmation.

This is a review/chapter summarizing oxytocin effects and neuroimaging in ASD rather than an original fMRI study. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and does not report primary fMRI data in healthy adult participants.

fMRI study in humans investigating social cognition (emotion inference about social targets) conducted during task performance. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not state participant ages explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult (17–65) sample and other details.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=20) performing a social-related mimicry task modulated by eye contact, addressing social communication and perception of others. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Empirical fMRI (BOLD) study of social processing (affiliation vs isolation) with healthy younger and older adults performing pleasantness judgments. Not a review. Abstract does not specify exact participant ages; include for full-text review to confirm at least one healthy group falls within 17–65.

Study used fMRI hyperscanning during an interactive social-exchange task probing social cognition (cooperation/competition), which aligns with the review objective. The abstract does not state participant ages or health status; per screening rules, if information is insufficient for exclusion, include for full-text review.

This publication is a mini-review integrating multimodal MRI and OXTR literature, not an original task-based fMRI study. It is a review article (excluded by the criterion excluding systematic reviews/meta-analyses) and does not report primary fMRI data from healthy adult participants.

Participants are adolescents (mean ages 15.8 and 16.2), below the required adult age range (17–65); no healthy adult group is included. Therefore the study does not meet the age criterion for inclusion.

Study participants are middle childhood children (roughly ages 7–13), not adults. Inclusion requires at least one healthy participant group aged 17–65. Although it is an fMRI social cognition study, the participants fall outside the eligible age range, so exclude based on participant age.

Study uses resting-state fMRI rather than an active social-related task, and the abstract focuses on ultra-high-risk subjects; it does not report a task involving social processing in healthy adults. Does not meet task-based inclusion criterion.

Event-related fMRI study of social gaze processing (social cognition). Abstract reports a neurologically normal/typically developing subject group (n=9), so at least one healthy group is present. Ages not reported in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants meet the 17–65 age criterion.

This is a narrative review discussing neuroimaging and behavioral studies in high-functioning autism, not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. No fMRI task or healthy adult sample is reported; it meets the exclusion criterion for reviews.

fMRI study of social reflection (self/other judgments) in 22 healthy subjects, directly addressing social-related processing. Not a review/meta-analysis. Although exact ages not reported, sample described as healthy subjects and likely adult; include for full-text review to confirm age range and details.

fMRI study where participants viewed social vs non-social stimuli during scanning; includes a matched healthy control group (n=14). Study directly investigates perception/understanding of others, meeting inclusion criteria.

Study reports human fMRI during processing of emotional faces, a social-related task (perception/understanding of others). It presents data from healthy human participants (single-subject analyses). No exclusion criteria apply. Full-text review can confirm participant ages if needed.
