Neural activations (somatosensory cortices, amygdala, hippocampus, IFG) are described. Participants are implied to be healthy adults and this is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review. Thus it meets inclusion criteria.

This is a review article of fNIRS studies in children/infants with Autism Spectrum Disorder, not an original fMRI study in healthy adults. It is a review (excluded by criteria) and does not involve fMRI or the target population (healthy adults 17–65).

Study used fMRI in healthy adult participants while they viewed and processed mouth actions by humans and animals—an explicit social cognition task involving perception/understanding of others. Participant groups are healthy adults; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes resting-state brain activity in bvFTD patients, not an fMRI task of social processing. It does not report a task-based social paradigm nor clearly state inclusion of a healthy adult group (17–65). Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Abstract lacks methodological details (no explicit mention of fMRI, task, or participant ages). Title suggests imaging and comparison of typical development and ASD, but insufficient to confirm healthy adult fMRI social-task data. Include for full-text review to verify criteria.

fMRI study examining social competition/social-referencing during a learning task—clearly addresses social-related processing. Participants appear to be healthy adults (no clinical groups mentioned), though ages are not specified in the abstract. Include for full-text review to confirm participant age range and health status.

Abstract focuses on developmental changes in face specialization and does not specify participant ages or explicitly state an fMRI scan during a social-related task. It’s unclear whether a healthy adult (17–65) group was included. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from the abstract alone — include for full-text review.

fMRI study in healthy adults performing a social-related task (preference judgments about human faces) versus gender ID; examines neural mechanisms of social evaluation. Meets inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text extraction.

fMRI study investigating agency inferences (perception/understanding of self), which falls under social-related processing. Includes a healthy control group (31 participants). Abstract lacks specific ages but likely adults; include for full-text review to confirm age range and extract data.

This is a review article summarizing task-based functional neuroimaging studies (not an original fMRI study). Exclusion criterion: systematic reviews or meta-analyses applies. Abstract does not report new fMRI data in healthy adult participants.

Event-related fMRI in healthy right-handed adult subjects investigating self-face recognition (Perception and Understanding of Self), a social-related process. Participants described as normal (healthy); study is original research, not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing a task judging social concepts (social semantic processing). Task clearly probes social-related cognition (perception/understanding of others/self). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI was used while participants judged pride (a self-conscious, social emotion) versus joy, engaging social cognition/theory-of-mind processes. The study reports 16 healthy volunteers. Abstract indicates social-related processing in healthy adults; no exclusion criteria met. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/details.

Event-related fMRI in human participants investigating processing of others' decisions and attribution of mental states (perception/understanding of others), a social cognition task. Likely healthy scanned subjects; not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults.

fMRI study of dynamic facial expressions (onset/offset), clearly addressing social communication processing. Abstract indicates task-based BOLD responses in emotion/motivation networks. Participant health/ages not specified—insufficient for exclusion—so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and ages.

fMRI conducted during a face-recognition task (social perception/understanding of others), meeting the review’s social-processing and task-based fMRI criteria. Abstract does not explicitly report participant ages or health status; likely healthy adults but not confirmed. Include for full-text review to verify participant demographics and eligibility.

fMRI study using a social cognition task (Reading the Mind in the Eyes). Includes a healthy control group (age-matched adults) alongside HD patients, meeting the requirement of at least one healthy participant group aged within typical adult range. Not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study examining amygdala responses to masked fearful eyes (social-perception of others’ affect) during an experimental task; meets review objective. Abstract does not explicitly state participant health status/ages, so include for full-text review to confirm demographics.

Study used an fMRI social-cognitive task (neutral facial expressions) in healthy participants (n=74) investigating social processing (pSTS responses). It is empirical (not a review) and includes healthy adult participants, meeting inclusion criteria. Age range not stated in abstract, but participant group is clearly healthy adults—include for full-text to confirm ages if needed.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing a social task (speed-dating) probing affiliation/understanding of others (responses to romantic interest/rejection). Fits inclusion criteria (social-related processing in healthy adults) and is not a review. Abstract gives sufficient detail for inclusion.

The study used resting-state fMRI (RSFC) rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. The review requires functional MRI during a social-related task in healthy adults; although healthy controls were included, absence of a social task means it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes a review/synthesis of functional neuroimaging studies of deception rather than reporting original fMRI data. It appears to be a review article, which meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses; insufficient evidence of a primary fMRI study in healthy adults.

fMRI study examining face perception and changeable aspects (expressions, viewpoint) directly relevant to social communication/perception of others. Abstract does not specify participant demographics or health status; insufficient information to confirm age/healthy sample, so include for full-text review.

Study used fMRI in preterm infants (31–36 weeks postmenstrual age), not healthy adults aged 17–65. The task was somatosensory mapping of sensorimotor cortex, not a social-related task. Does not meet population or task inclusion criteria.

This article is a meta-analysis of fMRI studies (systematic review), which matches the exclusion criterion. The abstract does not describe original fMRI data from participants, so it should be excluded.

Original fMRI study in humans where participants watched violent social interactions (social perception/understanding of others). Involves healthy adult observers and examines neural responses modulated by personality traits. Not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study with 34 healthy participants performing an empathic accuracy task (social cognitive processing — perception/understanding of others) during scanning. Not a review/meta-analysis. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text confirmation of ages and other details.

Participants are children (ages 10–15) and include an autism group; the task is passive auditory change detection (non-social). Does not study social processing in healthy adults (17–65). Exclude based on population and non-social task.

This publication is a literature review (reviewing research from 2005–2010) rather than a primary fMRI study. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and does not report original fMRI data from healthy adults performing social-related tasks.

Study uses fMRI during a social cognition task (adapted Reading-the-Mind-in-the-Eyes Test). Abstract reports a healthy non-offender control group (H) of adult men. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing with healthy adults.

fMRI study using an interactive trust game (social reward/ToM) with a healthy control group. However, controls are aged 13–19 so it’s unclear whether they meet the review’s 17–65 healthy adult age criterion; abstract lacks sufficient age-specific details. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and eligibility.

Study 2 used fMRI to measure neural responses during a social-cognitive task (mental-state attribution/perception of others) in healthy adult participants (heterosexual men). It meets criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Abstract reports functional MRI analyses with participants performing a social-closeness task (photos of friends vs unknown people), directly addressing social-related processing. Not a review. Age range/health status not explicitly stated, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants examining interpersonal space (social-affiliation) while scanned; reports task-related neural activity (dmPFC) and oxytocin modulation. Matches inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults and is not a review.

Event-related fMRI in healthy human subjects performing a social communication task (gaze and pointing/following directional cues). Meets inclusion criteria for social-related processing; abstract lacks explicit participant ages so include for full-text review to confirm age range and other details.

Functional MRI was used with theory-of-mind (social cognition) tasks (a social-related construct), and the study includes a comparable healthy control group (n=14) of adults. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Resting-state fMRI study in children aged 3–5, not a task-based social-processing fMRI study and participants are well below the 17–65 adult age range required. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Participants are preadolescents/young adolescents (children), not adults. Inclusion requires at least one healthy participant group aged 17–65; this study therefore fails the age criterion despite using an fMRI social-cognition task.
Resting-state fMRI in adults with autism spectrum disorder; no task-based social-processing paradigm and no clear healthy adult comparison group reported, so it fails the inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of theory-of-mind (social) processing comparing agents and objects—clearly a social-related task. No indication it's a review or meta-analysis. The sample is described as ‘people’ (presumably healthy adults), but ages/health not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm sample meets 17–65 healthy criteria.

Original fMRI study in healthy adult volunteers using social cognition (theory-of-mind) tasks involving cooperation and deception. Fits social-related processing in healthy adults; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

fMRI study using an observe/imitate emotional faces task (social processing) in healthy adult participants (final N=20). Fits review objective of social-related fMRI in healthy adults; not a review or meta-analysis.

This is a narrative review article (not a primary fMRI study). The abstract reviews monkey and human experiments on motor and non-motor tasks and does not report an fMRI scan of healthy adult participants performing a social-related task.

Abstract does not specify inclusion of healthy control participants nor clearly indicate a social-related task (anger/aggression may be interpersonal but not explicit). Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone; include for full-text review to confirm participant groups and task relevance.

Abstract reports structural MRI and resting-state fMRI analyses in autism subtypes, not a task-based fMRI during social-related processing. Participants are clinical (ASD) and healthy adult status/age and a social task are not described. Does not meet inclusion requirement for task-based fMRI in healthy adults.

Participants are adolescents (developmental sample), not adults aged 17–65. Additionally, the fMRI tasks described concern risk processing and cognitive control rather than social-related processing in healthy adults. Exclude based on age/sample and unclear social task.

fMRI study investigating impression updating and neural responses to others’ behavior—clearly a social cognitive task (perception/understanding of others). Not a review; appears to report primary data. Abstract does not specify participant ages/health explicitly, so include for full-text to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study with human participants (n=14) performing a social-perception task (observing others' pupil dynamics), engaging regions involved in social salience. No indication it's a review; participants appear to be healthy adults. Abstract lacks specific ages, so include for full-text review to confirm age criteria and health status.

Original fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=18) performing a social-cognition task (predicting others' behavior; theory-of-mind vs. deontic inference). Fits inclusion: functional MRI during social-related processing in adults 17–65 and is not a review or meta-analysis.

Event-related fMRI study of emotion-word processing (affective/social language) comparing individuals with ASC and typically-developing controls. Task involves social/affective semantic processing (relevant to Social Communication/Perception of Others). At least one healthy control group is included. Not a review. Therefore meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related processing in healthy adults.

fMRI was used to measure neural responses to observed actions (mirror system), which addresses social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). Participants appear to be healthy adults and no exclusion criteria (e.g., review article) apply. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

fMRI study examining self-face recognition—a form of ‘Perception and Understanding of Self’—during a task, which fits the review’s social-related processes. Likely conducted in healthy adult participants. Abstract lacks explicit participant age/health details, so include for full-text verification.

fMRI study using a social interactive task (virtual handshake assessing acceptance vs refusal) and includes a healthy control group (n=16). Although also includes schizophrenia patients, the inclusion criteria allow studies with at least one healthy participant group. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet the review objective.

Abstract investigates neural correlates of social cooperation in dyadic interaction, implying use of neuroimaging during a social task and likely includes non-clinical participants with varying psychopathic traits. Abstract lacks explicit mention of fMRI and participant age—include for full-text review.

Abstract discusses model-based fMRI during social interactions in healthy humans and reports BOLD imaging; it is not labeled a systematic review/meta-analysis but lacks participant age/sample details. Include for full-text review to confirm fMRI task, healthy adult sample (17–65), and that original fMRI data are reported.

fMRI study of social (Theory of Mind/mentalizing) processing including a typically developing (healthy) group. The abstract does not specify participant ages and likely involves adolescents, so it is unclear whether the healthy group meets the review’s 17–65 age criterion. Include for full-text review to confirm ages and eligibility.

fMRI study using a pain-empathy paradigm (observing/listening to others in pain), which targets social cognition (perception/understanding of others). Includes a healthy control group (n=21) likely within adult age range. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract gives sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with 44 healthy participants performing explicit social trait judgments (trustworthiness, attractiveness) on voices—directly addresses social-related processing in healthy adults. Not a review/meta-analysis. Ages not specified in abstract, but participants are healthy adults; include for full-text review to confirm age range and details.

fMRI study examining face/social-emotional processing (attention to eyes) with 20 neurotypical matched controls (healthy adults) and 20 ASD; task is social-related (perception/understanding of others); participants are young adults within 17–65. Not a review.

fMRI study of social processing (direct vs averted gaze; theory-of-mind/gaze perception). Includes 23 matched healthy control participants alongside ASC group, satisfying requirement for a healthy adult group. No exclusion criteria met; age range not specified in abstract but likely adults—include for full-text review to confirm ages and details.

The fMRI task assessed reward responses to monetary incentives and autism-relevant object images (e.g., trains), not social-related processing (e.g., affiliation, social communication, perception of others). Although healthy control participants were included, the study does not address the review’s social processing constructs and thus does not meet inclusion criteria.

Participants are young children (mean age ~5) and include an ASD clinical group; imaging was resting-state under sedation rather than task-based social processing in healthy adults (17–65). Does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social processing (empathy/sympathy) in a healthy sample that includes adults (ages 7–40, so participants ≥17 present). Abstract does not specify an adult-only group or separate adult results; insufficient detail to determine eligibility from abstract alone, so include for full-text review.

fMRI was used while healthy adult males performed the Taylor aggression paradigm (social provocation/interaction), a social-related task engaging social cognition; participants were healthy adults and the study is empirical (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

fMRI study uses a social-related task (Theory of Mind/intentional causality). Abstract reports participants with ASD and group differences, implying healthy control group presence. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult (17–65) sample and extract relevant data.

This is a review/meta-analytic article synthesizing lesion work, TMS, MVPA, and Neurosynth analyses rather than reporting original fMRI data from human participants performing social tasks. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and should be excluded.

fMRI was used while participants performed a social attribution task (judging others’ behaviors). The study includes a healthy control group alongside BPD patients, addressing social processing in adults. No exclusion criteria met; abstract provides sufficient information to warrant full-text review to confirm ages and other details.

fMRI study examining social communication (perception of communicative intentions from vocal prosody) with participants performing a prosody-categorization task. Abstract implies original empirical work with human participants (likely healthy adults) and meets the review’s social-related fMRI criteria; not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study investigating neural basis of disgust perception in racial prejudice during a passive face-viewing task—this addresses social perception/understanding of others. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit healthy status; insufficient detail to confirm eligibility, so include for full-text review to verify sample meets 17–65 healthy adult criterion.

fMRI study using the Cyberball social exclusion paradigm (a social processing task) and includes a healthy control group of adult women. Not a review/meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults; full text can confirm exact ages if needed.

fMRI study involving social-emotional processing (gender identification of angry and happy faces), which fits the review objective. Abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or ages; include for full-text review to confirm that at least one group are healthy adults (17–65) and to extract details.

fMRI study with healthy participants performing a familiarity judgment of personally familiar vs famous/unfamiliar faces—addresses social perception/understanding of others. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility and extract details.

fMRI study using an attribution task (social cognition: inferring others' emotional behaviors) and includes a healthy control group (n=16). Abstract does not report participant ages; include for full-text review to confirm healthy adults fall within 17–65 and to verify data reporting.

Task-based fMRI examining perception of others (faces varying in race and socioeconomic status), addressing social cognition. Sample: 61 healthy adult (white male) participants within the target age range. Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study using an emotional face recognition task (social processing: perception/empathy/attachment) with adult participants. Includes healthy groups (mothers without current mental disorders). Not a review/meta-analysis.

Participants are adolescents (13-year-olds), outside the required age range of 17–65. Although an fMRI social-exclusion task was used, the sample does not meet the adult age criterion; therefore the study should be excluded based on age.

fMRI study examining integration of facial and vocal emotional expressions—addresses social perception/communication (perception of others). Uses whole-brain and ROI analyses in (presumably) healthy adults; not a review. Sufficiently meets inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health if needed.

Study reports fMRI data collected while healthy adult participants (American and Korean samples) performed persuasion tasks — a social-cognitive process related to perception/understanding of others. Multiple fMRI studies and media types are reported; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Study used fMRI during an emotional face-viewing task (social perception/understanding of others) and includes a healthy control group. Although ages of participants are not specified in the abstract, the design meets the review objective; include for full-text review to confirm age range and other details.

Functional MRI was used in healthy adult (college) participants performing a task that probes social-related processing: emotional memory retrieval tied to fan identity and rivalry (social cognition/affiliation). The study examines neural correlates of memories from the fan’s perspective; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion.

fMRI study examining social-cognitive processing (animacy/mentalizing) using animated figures; reports neural responses in social brain networks. Participants appear to be healthy adults and task is clearly social-related. No exclusion criteria (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

fMRI study with 42 healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (self vs. other processing using romantic partner video vignettes). Fits inclusion criteria (social processing, healthy adults 17–65); not a review or meta-analysis.

The fMRI paradigm assessed pain anticipation and fear of movement via observing exercise videos, not a social-processing task. Although authors reference brain regions involved in social cognition, the study’s objective and task focus on pain and manual therapy, not social-related processing. Healthy controls are present but the core task does not meet the review’s social-processing inclusion criterion.

This is a resting-state fMRI study (no social-related task performed during scanning). Although it includes healthy adult participants, inclusion requires a task-based fMRI social paradigm; the abstract does not report one.

fMRI measured brain responses in healthy adult participants (football supporters) during a social task (watching matches) probing group bias/social cognition. Fits review objective of social-related fMRI in healthy adults; not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

fMRI study directly investigates social-related processing (social reward: agreement of music preferences). Includes a matched stimulant-naive healthy control group (adult participants), and is primary research (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.
The article is a quantitative meta-analysis of 35 fMRI studies (not original primary fMRI data). Per exclusion criteria, systematic reviews/meta-analyses should be excluded.

This is a resting-state fMRI study with no task-based social processing paradigm. The review requires functional MRI during a social-related task in healthy adults; although healthy controls are included, absence of a social task means it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This study uses resting-state fMRI (rfMRI) rather than a task-based fMRI involving social-related processing. Inclusion requires participants perform a social-related task; the abstract reports no such task. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Primary fMRI study with 27 healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (observing cooperative vs affective interactions) probing intention understanding/mentalizing and action understanding. Fits the review objective and inclusion criteria; not a review or meta-analysis.

Study reports functional neural responses (fMRI) during a social-affective task (witnessing others’ distress) in healthy adult participants, examining compassion/empathy (social processing). Not a review/meta-analysis and meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study probing imitation/observation (mirror neuron system) — a social-related task. Abstract does not state explicitly whether healthy control participants (age 17–65) were included. Insufficient detail to confirm exclusion, so include for full-text review to verify presence of healthy adult group and task details.

fMRI study where participants imagined personally familiar others—a social cognitive task (perception/understanding of others). Involves healthy adult participants (no clinical groups mentioned) and is an original empirical study, not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing.

Contains three original fMRI experiments examining neural responses to dynamic vs. static facial expressions (social cognitive processing) in humans. Not a standalone systematic review/meta-analysis (includes original data). Participant ages/groups not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult (17–65) sample eligibility.

This study used resting-state fMRI (no social-related task) and focused on DMN connectivity in Williams syndrome vs matched controls. It does not report a task of social processing in healthy adults, so it fails the inclusion criterion requiring task-based social processing fMRI.

Abstract does not specify that an fMRI task was performed with a healthy adult control group aged 17–65. It focuses on CHR youth and neural networks but lacks participant age/details and explicit mention of healthy participants. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone — include for full-text review.

fMRI was used with autism, siblings, and control subjects; at least one healthy control group is present. The task named (Embedded Figures Task) is a visuospatial task and not clearly a social-processing task in the abstract, and ages are not specified. Because the abstract provides insufficient information to confirm the task meets the review’s ‘social-related’ criterion, include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Resting-state fMRI study in adolescents (neurotypical and ASD); no task-based social processing paradigm reported and participants are adolescents rather than healthy adults aged 17–65. Therefore it does not meet the review’s task-based and age inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social processing (facial expression perception). Abstract reports an independent replication sample of healthy adult participants (North American replication, n=85), satisfying the requirement for at least one healthy group aged 17–65. Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study of social-related processing (empathizing with emotional faces) including a healthy typically developing control (TDC) group. Participant ages span 12–31; while some are under 17, the sample includes adults within 17–31. Abstract lacks full age breakdown, so include for full-text review to confirm adult-only data and extract relevant results.

Abstract describes neural mechanisms of social information sharing but does not explicitly state that functional MRI was used or that participants were healthy adults aged 17–65. Insufficient detail in abstract to confirm inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to verify fMRI methods and participant characteristics.

fMRI study of social processing (interactive face-to-face joint attention task). Includes healthy adult comparison groups (neurotypical adults n=14 and n=22), ages described as adults (within 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI task involved sensorimotor eye movement paradigms (saccades and pursuit), not social-related processing. Although healthy control group included, the tasks do not probe social cognition; thus it does not meet the meta-analysis inclusion criterion.

This is a resting-state fMRI study comparing dynamic functional connectivity in SZ, ASD, and healthy controls; no social-related task was administered. Inclusion requires task-based fMRI of social processing, so exclude.

Abstract reports atypical frontal activation in unaffected siblings and discusses social cognition and visual attention, implying neuroimaging of social-related processing and inclusion of healthy relatives. However, the abstract does not explicitly state fMRI, task details, or participant ages—insufficient detail, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study measuring responses to emotional faces during a gender-discrimination task, which is a social-perception task in adults. The abstract describes genotype groups (likely healthy subjects) and does not meet any exclusion criteria. Include for full-text review to confirm participant health status and ages.

fMRI study with healthy sighted adult participants performing action perception/recognition and motor pantomime tasks engaging the mirror system — fits 'Perception and Understanding of Others' social processing. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

Primary fMRI study in healthy adult participants examining responses to social control by another person. Task involves social interaction and social-cognitive measures; neural results relate to social cognition. Meets inclusion criteria (fMRI, social-related task, healthy adults).

Participants are young children with autism (clinical pediatric sample); study does not include a group of healthy adults aged 17–65. The task examines neural responses in children with ASD, so it does not meet the population criterion for this review.

Event-related fMRI in 51 healthy adults performing emotional sentence classification involving social cognition/Theory-of-Mind (affective speech comprehension). Fits inclusion criteria (social-related task in healthy adults) and is not a review. Abstract gives sufficient detail for inclusion.

fMRI study in adult human participants investigating socially-induced cognitive emotion regulation involving a psychotherapist (social cognition/attachment). Healthy adults are implied and no review/meta-analysis. Task is explicitly social-related (Affiliation/Attachment, social regulation), meeting inclusion criteria.

The paper reports two fMRI experiments on perception/interpretation of social actions (person presence, orientation, action directedness), fitting social-related processing. It involves human participants and does not report clinical groups or that it is a review. Thus it meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study with healthy adults performing social-related tasks (SELF vs OTHER emotion attribution) probing empathy and perception/understanding of others. Tasks clearly social-cognitive and use functional MRI. Not a review. Age not explicitly stated but participants described as subjects (adults); include for full text review.

fMRI study of anticipatory interpersonal touch comparing human vs fake hand — a social sensorimotor task relevant to social processing. Not a review. Abstract lacks explicit participant age/health details, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

The study reports an fMRI experiment of emotion processing (a social cognition task) in unaffected siblings of schizophrenia patients, who are healthy participants. This meets the review’s requirement for fMRI during social-related processing and inclusion of a healthy adult group.

fMRI was conducted while adult mothers observed dynamic infant videos (social/attachment task). Participants were healthy adults (n=23). Study addresses social processing (affiliation/attachment) and is not a review.

Article is a brief review of neuroimaging in autism (a review article), not an original fMRI study in healthy adults. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and does not report fMRI data from healthy 17–65 participants.

This article is a systematic review and meta-analyses of fMRI studies (not an original fMRI study). It meets the exclusion criterion 'systematic reviews or meta-analyses' and therefore should be excluded.

fMRI was conducted in healthy human participants to study perception and recognition of faces, which falls under ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’ (social-related processing). Participants are adults (male and female). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

The study used resting-state fMRI and ERP, not a task-based fMRI scan during social-related processing. Inclusion requires fMRI conducted while participants performed a social-related task. Although healthy controls are included, the abstract does not describe task-based fMRI, so exclude.

This is an EEG (electrophysiological) study, not a functional MRI study. Although it examines social-related processing (gossip) in healthy adults, it does not meet the inclusion criterion of a functional MRI scan; therefore exclude.

fMRI study of decision-making influenced by expert advice (social influence), examines social-cognition regions (TPJ) and valuation; includes healthy adult group (18+), within 17–65 range; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.
Non-human animal study (mouse) using resting-state fMRI; no human participants aged 17–65 and no social-related task. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in 46 healthy adult volunteers performing theory-of-mind tasks (emotion, belief, pain) — directly examines social cognition/perception of others. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining neural correlates of initiating and responding to joint attention—clearly a social-processing task. Not a review. Abstract implies healthy adult participants; include for full‑text to confirm ages/health status.

fMRI study with human listeners performing auditory emotion discrimination (social communication/perception of others), consistent with social-related processing in adults; not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract implies healthy participants. Included for full-text extraction.

Empirical fMRI study (four experiments, n=98) examining social-cognitive processing (judgments about self, friends, unknown others; closeness/similarity). Involves healthy human participants performing social-related tasks and is not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in adults; include for full-text review to confirm age range and other details.

This is an animal study focusing on birdsong (songbirds) and discusses fMRI in songbirds; no human participants (age 17–65) performing social-related tasks are reported. Therefore it does not meet the review’s human fMRI inclusion criteria.

Study used fMRI (3T) during a social task (multiround trust game) and includes a healthy comparison group. The abstract does not report participant ages; per criteria, this is insufficient to confirm the 17–65 age range, so include for full-text review to verify age eligibility and extract details.

The study used disruptive transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) of the rTPJ rather than functional MRI. Inclusion requires an fMRI scan during a social task; modality mismatch is clear from the abstract. Therefore exclude.

Human fMRI study with healthy adult participants (men, n=10 per group) performing social-related tasks (viewing romantic images—affiliation/attachment). Fits inclusion criteria (social processing in healthy adults). Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI was conducted while healthy adult participants viewed masked emotional faces (social/attachment-related stimuli). The study examines attachment/affiliation processing in a sample of 51 healthy adults and is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social-related processing (direct and reflected self/other evaluations). Includes a healthy young adult group (ages 22–31), which falls within 17–65. Not a review—meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes a neuroimaging study of trustworthiness appraisal (social-related processing) in borderline personality disorder; likely compares to controls. The abstract does not explicitly state fMRI or healthy participant age range, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study in healthy adults examining neural mechanisms distinguishing self vs other via visuo-motor/visuo-proprioceptive synchrony; directly relates to perception/understanding of self and others, a social-related construct. Not a review/meta-analysis. Include for full-text extraction.

fMRI study with healthy participants who freely watched film scenes evoking emotional conflicts and provided social/emotional evaluations. Investigates social-cognitive processing (STS, IPL involvement) during perception/evaluation of others’ emotions, meeting the social-related task criterion.

This is a review article summarizing ERP and fMRI findings rather than an original fMRI study reporting primary data. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses and does not provide evidence of conducting an fMRI social-task with healthy adult participants.

Abstract does not specify that an fMRI was used, nor details about task or participant ages. The topic (parental brain, oxytocin/vasopressin) could involve social processing and healthy adults, but information is insufficient to determine eligibility. Include for full-text review.

fMRI was used while healthy adult participants (21 men) experienced negative social feedback — a social-processing task. Participants are within the target age range and the study is empirical (not a review), meeting inclusion criteria.

The study used functional MRI and manipulated perspective during a social interaction (out-of-body vs in-body), addressing social-related processing. Participants appear to be healthy adults and the task was performed during fMRI. No exclusion criteria met.

fMRI study in typical adults examining neural responses to others' eye gaze (social attention/perception), fits social-related processing; includes healthy adult participants; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of emotion recognition from dynamic gait—falls squarely under social perception/understanding of others. Human subjects underwent fMRI; likely healthy adults but ages not reported in abstract. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health.
The study used positron emission tomography (PET), not functional MRI. The meta-analysis requires fMRI studies; therefore it does not meet the modality inclusion criterion.

The study used resting-state fMRI (rsFC) rather than an fMRI scan conducted while participants performed a social-related task. Although it examines peer influence and involves healthy emerging adults, it does not meet the requirement of a task-based social processing fMRI, so it should be excluded.

fMRI study of social rejection (Cyberball) in healthy participants; includes an adult participant group (16 adult females) and examines social-related processing (social evaluation, affect regulation). Not a review. Adult group likely within 17–65; if age uncertainty remains, full-text can confirm.

Abstract reports fMRI ‘imaging epigenetic’ study measuring neural activity during emotional face processing (social perception), which meets the review objective. Participant health and exact ages are not specified in abstract; include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult (17–65) sample and task details.

Participants are children (middle childhood, ages 8–12); the meta-analysis requires at least one healthy adult group aged 17–65. Abstract gives no indication of adult participants, so it does not meet the age criterion.

Study uses fMRI during a social cognition task (Reading the Mind in the Eyes) and includes siblings (possible healthy participants), but participants are described as adolescents and ages are not reported. Because age eligibility (17–65) and presence of healthy adult group cannot be confirmed from the abstract, include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

The study includes an fMRI facial emotion processing task (social-related processing) and a healthy control group (n=27). Age range is not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants are within 17–65 and to extract relevant data.

Randomized, placebo-controlled fMRI study examining neural and behavioral responses during a social-interaction task (Prisoner’s Dilemma) in healthy adult males and females. Directly addresses social processing in healthy adults and is not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of cross-modal person recognition (voice-face priming) addressing perception/understanding of others, a social-related process. Human participants are implied; abstract lacks explicit age/health details. Include for full-text review to confirm sample are healthy adults (17–65) and meet criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI study using parental stimuli (attachment/affiliation/social processing) and includes a healthy volunteer group. Ages of participants are not specified in the abstract, so full text is needed to confirm the 17–65 age criterion; otherwise it meets the review focus.

The study used resting-state fMRI with the social manipulation (critical remarks) presented before scanning rather than a social task performed during the fMRI. Inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task; this does not clearly meet that criterion despite healthy adult sample.

This is a meta-analysis (explicitly stated) of fMRI studies in schizophrenia patients. The protocol excludes systematic reviews/meta-analyses; the abstract does not report primary data from healthy adult participants meeting inclusion criteria.
This article is a systematic review and meta-analysis (not a primary fMRI study). Exclusion criterion 'systematic reviews or meta-analyses' is clearly met.

fMRI study of social-related processing (implicit facial emotion task: fearful vs neutral faces — perception/understanding of others). Includes a healthy adult control group (24 matched controls). Not a review. Therefore meets inclusion criteria.

The study examines cognitive emotion regulation to positive/negative/neutral pictures, not social-related processing. It does not involve social stimuli or tasks (e.g., affiliation, communication, perception of others/self in social context). Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring an fMRI social task.

The article is explicitly a review and meta-analysis of behavioral and neuroimaging studies; it is not an original fMRI study of healthy adults performing social tasks. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Original fMRI study where participants viewed text messages believed to be from a friend vs a computer, probing social communication and social-context modulation. Healthy participants are implied and task is social-related. Not a review/meta-analysis and meets inclusion criteria for social processing in adults; include for full-text review.

Study uses resting-state fMRI (no social task); meta-analysis requires task-based fMRI during social-related processing. Although healthy control group present, absence of a social task means it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Event-related fMRI in healthy nulliparous adult women (n=17) using infant cries and faces—social stimuli tapping affiliation/attachment, perception of others, and reward processing. Fits inclusion criteria (social-related task; healthy adults 17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis.

Abstract does not report that participants performed a social-related task; study focuses on resting-state parcellation and task-related coactivation/meta-characterization. Although 'social cognition' is mentioned in functional labeling, it is unclear whether original fMRI involved a social task. Insufficient detail to exclude—include for full-text review to determine whether social-task fMRI in healthy adults was performed.

Study used magnetoencephalography (MEG), not functional MRI. The review requires fMRI data collected during a social-related task. Although participants are healthy adults and task is social, the imaging modality fails inclusion.

This publication is a meta-analysis of fMRI studies (a systematic review/meta-analysis), which meets the exclusion criterion. Additionally, it focuses on psychopathic populations rather than reporting primary fMRI data from healthy adult participants performing social tasks.

Task-based fMRI examines self-referential processing (a social-related construct: perception/understanding of self). Although participants include aMCI and controls, ages are not provided and may be >65; insufficient age information to rule out inclusion. Abstract therefore warrants full-text review to confirm participant ages and task details.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (theory of mind/belief processing) using a behavioral task (Sally-Anne type false-belief) in human participants. It is empirical (not a review) and appears to involve healthy adult participants, meeting the review’s inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Abstract provides insufficient information: unclear whether an fMRI task of social processing was used (may be resting-state connectivity) and unclear if a healthy adult group (age 17–65) was included. Include for full-text review.

Study uses resting-state fMRI (no social task) and reports outcomes in individuals with autism; no evidence of a social-related task or a healthy adult (17–65) sample. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of supraliminal fearful face processing (social/emotional processing) that includes a healthy control group of adults matched on age and IQ. Task assesses perception/processing of others; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI data were collected during gesture planning and execution (social action/communication), which fits social-related processing. The study includes a healthy control group of adults (n=25). It is an original fMRI study, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

The abstract describes an fMRI study of social cognition (self-referential processing and perspective taking) with human adult participants and tasks targeting self/others. It is an empirical study (not a review) and directly addresses perception/understanding of self and others. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health status if needed.

The study uses resting-state connectivity, structural covariance, and meta-analytic connectivity modeling rather than a task-based fMRI of social processing. No evidence participants performed a social-related task during scanning, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion for task-based social fMRI.

Abstract describes fMRI connectivity in autism spectrum disorder and clinical severity; it does not report fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults nor mention a healthy 17–65 group. Focus is clinical ASD, not the review’s social-processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of perspective-taking (self/other evaluation), a social cognition task (Perception/Understanding of Self and Others). Includes a healthy control group of 24 typically developed adults (age: adults), and is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports hyperscanning fMRI during joint attention, a social processing task. However, participant health status and ages (17–65) are not specified in the abstract. Include for full-text review to confirm sample consists of healthy adults within the eligible age range and meets other criteria.

fMRI study of cognitive empathy (social processing) that included a healthy control group (24 controls). Task assesses perception/understanding of others. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adult participants; abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

The study used fMRI to examine self-referential processing and perspective-taking (social-related constructs). The abstract focuses on ultra-high risk individuals but does not clearly state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Because inclusion criteria permit studies with clinical groups if a healthy group is present and the abstract is insufficient to determine this, include for full-text review.

Abstract describes an fMRI task involving perception of emotional facial expressions (a social-related process) which matches the review objective. However, the abstract does not state whether a healthy adult control group (age 17–65) was included. Include for full-text review to confirm presence and age range of healthy participants.

The study used task-based fMRI during social-related processing (emotion recognition and gaze integration). It includes a healthy younger participant group aged 17–27 (within the 17–65 inclusion range). It is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review.

fMRI was resting-state functional connectivity only, not a task-based fMRI during a social-related task. Although healthy controls and behavioral social cognition measures were included, the study does not meet the requirement of an fMRI scan conducted while participants performed a social-related task.
Study examines children and adolescents with autism spectrum disorder; no healthy adult (17–65) participant group is reported. Population and age range do not match the review’s inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI functional connectivity related to autistic traits in neurotypical adults but does not state that participants performed a social-related task. Insufficient information to confirm the key inclusion criterion (task-based social processing); include for full-text review to determine task details and participant ages.

fMRI study of fearful face-processing (social cognition) in adults; includes a matched healthy control group (adults) alongside HFA/AS group. Task is social-related (perception of others’ emotions). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports oxytocin modulation of processing of socially relevant cues in the human VTA, implying human neuroimaging of social stimuli. Participant health status and imaging modality not explicitly stated in abstract; insufficient information to exclude. Include for full-text review to confirm fMRI and healthy adult sample.

Abstract reports fMRI investigation of facial emotion processing in individuals at clinical high risk for psychosis—this is a social-related task. The abstract does not clearly state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to confirm healthy participants, so include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm, and no measures of social behavior/processing were reported. Although healthy controls were included, it does not meet the requirement of a social-related task.

This is a resting-state fMRI study in adolescents with early-onset schizophrenia and healthy controls; it does not involve a task-based social processing paradigm in healthy adults (17–65). Therefore it does not meet the review’s requirement for fMRI during social-related tasks in healthy adults.

fulltext_screening_results.reason: While the study uses task fMRI of social processing and includes a healthy adult control group (healthy females aged 19–36 reported separately), it does not present an unmasked, group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. The reported whole-brain results focus on between-group contrasts (BPD > HC or HC > BPD) and a seed/regression analysis; the key amygdala finding is from an ROI analysis and several effects are reported as interactions or group comparisons. Therefore the paper lacks a within-group, whole-brain healthy adult task map generalizable to the healthy population, violating the requirement for whole-brain healthy-group evidence.

Although this fMRI study uses a social task (Cyberball) and reports whole-brain, group-level task contrasts (EX>IN; SUP>EX) in an adult undergraduate sample, the sample includes a clinical subgroup (9 of 46 met criteria for social anxiety disorder) and the reported whole-brain maps are computed on the combined sample. The paper does not present univariate, whole-brain group-level results clearly identified as coming from a healthy/control-only group. Per the inclusion rule requiring separate healthy-group whole-brain maps when clinical participants are included, this study fails that criterion and must be excluded.

Although this study used fMRI during a social interactive task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) in a healthy adult sample (ages 18–22), it does not report any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation maps for the healthy/control group. Analyses are restricted to ROI-based univariate tests and task-based gPPI connectivity; the paper explicitly focuses on ROI averages and pairwise connectivity and does not present unmasked whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked statistical maps. Per the review’s inclusion criteria requiring at least one whole-brain univariate healthy-group task result, this study must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults using a social-interaction task (Cyberball ball-toss) that manipulates frequency of social interaction. Sample comprises healthy adults (n=38 recruited; n=31 analyzed; mean age ~21, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (SPM8) with voxelwise and cluster-level inference and provides peak coordinates and statistical thresholds (cluster FWE-corrected p<0.05) for contrasts (ball-toss high-frequency > normal-frequency, task-by-frequency interaction). Results are reported for the healthy participant group and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, patient-only, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

The paper reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (two samples of N=24; ages within 17–65). The task probes social cognition (perception/understanding of others’ regret). Group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses and voxelwise contrasts (e.g., IP−IF, OP−OF), parametric modulation and conjunction analyses are reported with thresholding and cluster results, identifying cortical and subcortical loci. Not ROI-only, not connectivity-/resting-state-only, and healthy-group whole-brain effects are clearly presented; thus it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social interaction perception (dyadic interactions) in healthy adults (N=21; ages 18–35), using a task that directly probes social interaction processing. The methods describe task-based fMRI with GLM estimation, group-level whole-brain analyses used for localizer contrasts (e.g., interaction>scrambled, bodies>objects, faces>objects, mentalizing>pain) to define ROIs, and whole-brain searchlight analyses. Thus the paper reports group-level, voxelwise task-evoked analyses that generalize to a healthy adult sample (and supplemental materials are indicated). The study is not limited to ROI-only, resting-state, or connectivity-only analyses, and participants fall within the eligible age range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This study reports task-based fMRI of social touch (self- vs other-touch), a social-related processing paradigm (perception/understanding of self and others). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=30, age ~23.7) reported separately from the ADHD group. The paper provides whole-brain, group-level univariate results for the control group (within-group contrasts and activations for other-touch vs baseline/self-touch), with FWE-corrected voxelwise maps and figures described in the text. Thus all inclusion criteria are met: social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and clearly reported whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy/control group.

This study used resting-state fMRI and graph-theory connectivity (network centrality) rather than a task-based fMRI paradigm. Although social cognition measures (TASIT, RMET) were administered behaviorally, there are no reported group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked activation maps from a healthy/control group. The paper therefore fails the primary inclusion criterion requiring task-evoked whole-brain fMRI results in healthy adults. It is a resting-state/connectivity study and should be excluded from a meta-analysis of task-based social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social communication (comprehension of speech acts — Naming vs Requesting) in healthy adults (n=18, ages 18–41). It reports group-level, random-effects whole-brain univariate analyses (whole-brain FDR-corrected results reported, e.g., Request > Naming contrast significant at p<0.05 FDR) and provides coordinate/SVC ROI analyses as well. The task is social-related (social communication/pragmatics). All inclusion criteria are met (healthy adult sample, task-evoked fMRI, whole-brain group results). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, participants within 17–65). Therefore the study should be included in the meta-analysis.

Although the study reports dyadic fMRI during eye contact (a social task), the provided full-text content is a short conference abstract with no details on sample characteristics (participant ages, N) and no explicit reporting of group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise task-evoked statistical maps for a healthy adult group. The inclusion criteria require clear whole-brain healthy-group task maps (e.g., main effect or within-group contrast) generalizable to healthy adults (17–65). Because critical information is missing and it cannot be confirmed that the required whole-brain results and eligible healthy adult sample are reported separately, the study does not meet ALL inclusion criteria and must be excluded.

This paper is a methodological tutorial/review on intersubject correlation (ISC) methods (Nastase et al., 2019). It does not present original empirical fMRI data from a healthy adult sample nor report any group-level, whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps attributable to a healthy/control group. The manuscript summarizes and discusses many empirical studies and analytic approaches but is non-empirical (methods/tutorial) in nature, so it fails the inclusion criterion requiring original fMRI results (whole-brain maps) in healthy adults. Therefore it should be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (mentalising/theory of mind), involving healthy adult participants (Experiment 1: N=39, ages 18–60; Experiment 2/fMRI: N=17, mean 22 years), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., mentalising > factual; parametric modulation of intentionality level > factual) with voxelwise thresholds and whole-brain correction and provides tables/coordinates and figures. Analyses are task-evoked, not limited to ROI or connectivity-only results. Results are reported for the healthy/control group and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only; not resting-state; not only between-group contrasts). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It uses task-based fMRI probing social cognition (third-party punishment/attribution of others’ intentions — perception/understanding of others/mentalizing). (2) Sample comprises healthy adults (n=26; mean age 26 ±5.7), within the 17–65 range. (3) The authors report group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (random-effects GLM/2×2 ANOVA on β parameters) with voxelwise thresholding (q(FDR)<0.05) and provide peak coordinates (e.g., right TPJ, right anterior insula). (4) The paper is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Therefore the article provides healthy-group whole-brain task activation maps generalizable to healthy adults and should be INCLUDED in the meta-analysis.

The study is an fMRI investigation of social gaze processing in healthy adult participants (initial N=8; fMRI analyses after motion exclusion). The task probes social communication/perception (mutual vs. averted gaze), matching the review’s constructs. In addition to ROI analyses, the authors report voxel-based group activation maps (across-subjects t-statistic activation maps displayed on a standard brain; whole-brain voxelwise analyses described and thresholded), providing a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map for the healthy sample. Although the sample analyzed is small and the group maps were generated with a fixed-effects average (limiting generalizability), the paper nevertheless reports whole-brain, voxelwise task activations from a healthy adult group and thus satisfies the inclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Uses task-based fMRI with a social cognition paradigm (HCP Animated Triangles) targeting perception/understanding of others. (2) Includes a healthy adult control group (N=25) with results reported separately from the first-episode schizophrenia group. (3) Reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked results for the healthy/control group (e.g., Social > Non‑social and visual motion contrasts) with MNI coordinates and FWE-corrected statistics. Although the paper also includes DCM/effective connectivity analyses, it also provides the required whole-brain healthy-group activation maps, so it is eligible for inclusion.

This is an fMRI study of social-emotional processing (guilt; social cognition) in healthy adults (students, mean age 25.7; scanned sample n=20). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., guilt memories vs neutral memories; guilt hypotheticals vs neutral; guilt memories vs guilt hypotheticals) with whole-brain thresholding (p<0.001, cluster extent) and region results presented in text/figures/tables. Although small-volume corrections were also used, whole-brain univariate activation maps for the healthy group are clearly reported. The study is empirical, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and meets the age and healthy-sample requirements. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task-based fMRI investigating social-related processing (evaluation of political beliefs, self–other processing, and social decision-making); (2) Sample comprises healthy adult participants (MDS N=24; fMRI N=26; ages 22–45), within 17–65; (3) Reports group-level, whole-brain univariate random-effects analyses (second-level contrasts, F and t statistics) with voxelwise maps and reported peak coordinates and thresholds; results are clearly described for the healthy sample and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, not only between-group contrasts). Therefore include.

Although this is an fMRI study of biological-motion perception including a healthy adult control group, the paper reports results primarily as ROI-based analyses (STSp and MT) and individual ROI localizers. It does not present a group-level, whole-brain univariate task activation map for the healthy/control group that is generalizable to healthy adults; whole-brain analyses described were focused on patients and no unmasked healthy-group whole-brain statistical maps or coordinates of such maps are reported. Therefore it fails the requirement for reporting healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked results.

This is an fMRI study of joint action/partnered social interaction (leading, following, mutual) engaging social-cognitive processes (mentalizing, perception of others, social reward) — clearly a social-related task. Sample: healthy adult dancers (N=18 after exclusion), mean age 40.4 (within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked statistical maps and contrasts (e.g., partnered > non-partnered; improvisation contrasts) with FDR-corrected results and Talairach coordinates reported in tables/figures. Analyses are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only approaches. Healthy-group whole-brain effects are clearly presented and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Thus the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

Although the study uses task-evoked fMRI in healthy adult participants and addresses social-relevant vocal emotion processing (social communication), it does not report any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation maps. The analyses are ROI-/connectivity-based (Power-264 parcellation), reporting functional connectivity and graph-theoretical metrics (nodal/global network measures and FC comparisons) rather than voxelwise task activation contrasts. This falls under the exclusion criterion for studies reporting only connectivity/ROI/network analyses without a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map.

Although the study uses task fMRI of a social interaction in healthy adult physicians (ages 25–37) and reports group-level activations with coordinates, the neuroimaging results are derived from an a priori ROI/small-volume analysis (5 mm spheres) with FWE correction performed within the ROIs. The paper does not present or describe an unmasked, whole-brain (voxelwise) group-level task activation map generalizable to healthy adults. Because the review requires at least one whole-brain, univariate task-evoked map and excludes studies reporting only ROI/SVC results, this study fails the whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

This is a single-case clinical study (patient PK with high-functioning ASD and developmental prosopagnosia) compared to control subjects. The abstract and provided text describe case-focused findings, connectivity analyses, and differences versus controls but do not clearly report a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map for a healthy adult group. It appears to emphasize a case vs control contrast and functional connectivity/ROI-type findings rather than providing clearly identified whole-brain healthy-group task activation results required by the inclusion criteria. Therefore it does not meet the whole-brain evidence requirement and must be excluded.

This study used task-based fMRI of social-cognitive processes (attention to threatening material relevant to self and self-serving attributional bias), which fit the review’s social-related constructs (perception/understanding of self; attribution). Participants are described as "normal subjects" (healthy adults). The Results report group-level task-evoked brain activations across multiple regions (e.g., left inferior frontal gyrus BA47/44, right caudate, cingulate BA24, left precentral gyrus BA6, left middle temporal gyrus BA39), indicating whole-brain univariate activation findings rather than ROI- or connectivity-only analyses. The reported activations appear to be generalizable to a healthy adult group and are not limited to a special subgroup. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy sample, or non-empirical) are met. Therefore the paper meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis. Confidence is high (0.90) because the excerpt lists specific whole-brain activations, though full methods/thresholding details are not included in the excerpt.

This study meets all inclusion criteria. It uses task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=37, ages 18–25). The task probes social-related processing (imitation/urge to imitate = perception and understanding of others/social communication). Group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise analyses are reported (parametric modulation one-sample t-tests identifying regions correlated with Urge, with cluster-level correction and peak coordinates provided), so whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy sample are available. Although PPI connectivity was also performed, the paper clearly reports univariate whole-brain task effects rather than only ROI or connectivity results. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, healthy adult group reported separately). Therefore the paper should be INCLUDED in the review.

This paper reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants performing action observation and weight-discrimination tasks that probe perception/understanding of others (social-related processing). Healthy control groups (n=31 and other healthy samples across Experiments 1–4; ages matched to patients) are reported separately from the patient (SCA6) group. The study provides group-level, univariate, voxelwise statistical contrasts (e.g., ActionOBS–CtrlOBS; Sleeve/NoSleeve) and whole-brain analyses (they report whole-brain results and maps, including fusiform and thalamic activations), not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only analyses. Results are generalizable to healthy adults and presented as group activation maps and contrasts. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This fMRI study examines mentalizing (Theory-of-Mind) and sensorimotor simulation during narrative comprehension—directly addressing social-cognitive processing (perception/understanding of others). Sample: healthy adult participants (N=18; ages 18–27) within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (Mentalizing > Action and Action > Mentalizing), corrected for multiple comparisons, with reported clusters (e.g., aMPFC, superior temporal gyri, posterior cingulate). Although ROI analyses are also used, whole-brain results are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (e.g., clinical-only sample, connectivity-only analyses, or absence of whole-brain maps) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social perception (direction-sensitive coding of observed head turns—a social attention cue) in healthy adult participants (final N=17 after exclusions; ages 22–38). The study reports task-evoked whole-brain and region-restricted group-level univariate analyses (SnPM, FWE-corrected results and coordinates) and multivariate searchlight results; whole-brain/group-level univariate statistical maps and coordinates are described in the text and figures. The healthy adult group is clearly identified and results are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met.

This is an empirical fMRI study of action observation/execution probing perception of others’ grip force (a form of ‘perception and understanding of others’). Participants are healthy adults (final N=12, mean age 26). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate GLM results (multiple-order parametric SPMs, whole-brain and SUIT analyses) with maps/tables of significant clusters described in the text. It is not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

Although the sample consists of healthy adults and the study manipulates an implied social presence, the experiment is a resting-state design that reports seed/network functional connectivity results. The paper does not present any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps from a social-related task. Exclusion criterion applies: studies reporting only resting-state or connectivity analyses without a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map are excluded. Therefore the study does not meet the required whole-brain task-activation evidence for inclusion.

Meets all inclusion criteria: task-based fMRI study probing social-related processing (social sharing/affiliation) in healthy adult participants (female, ages 20–33). The paper reports task-evoked, group-level random-effects whole-brain analyses and whole-brain corrected activations (e.g., DLPFC, precuneus) and refers to Supplementary whole-brain results (Supplementary Table S3). Although ROI analyses are also reported, whole-brain voxelwise results are present and clearly attributed to the healthy/control group. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, not a review). Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

Although this study tests social cognition in a healthy adult sample (N=20, ages 19–31) using multiple task-based fMRI contrasts (ToM, face, biological motion, voice, language) and reports group-level activation peaks/coordinates, the second-level/group analyses were explicitly restricted to a bilateral STS anatomical mask. The paper does not present an unmasked, whole-brain group-level (voxelwise) task activation map generalizable to the healthy adult population; instead results are ROI/mask-restricted. Per the review’s inclusion criteria, studies must report at least one whole‑brain, univariate, group-level task-evoked statistical map. Because this criterion is not met, the study should be excluded.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social-related processing (thinking about 16 dyadic social interactions) and specifically addresses perception/understanding of self and others. The sample includes a healthy adult control group (17 age- and IQ-matched young adults) reported separately from the autism group. The manuscript reports group-level, univariate whole-brain GLM contrasts (within-group social-interactions > fixation) for the control group (with SPM results and figures/tables described), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and task-based (not resting-state), so it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although this study uses fMRI during social tasks (SID, EFP) and includes a healthy control group of adults aged 50–60, it does not report a clear, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) group-level activation map explicitly for the healthy/control group alone. The paper primarily presents ROI-based analyses (small-volume corrections in amygdala, NAcc, mPFC, vmPFC), whole-group (combined COC+CTRL) whole-brain results, and between-group contrasts (COC vs CTRL). The inclusion criteria require an unmasked, whole-brain task activation map identified as coming from the healthy/control group and generalizable to healthy adults; this is not clearly provided. Because the healthy-group whole-brain task effect is not separately reported (and much of the inference relies on ROI and combined-sample maps), the study fails the ‘whole-brain evidence for healthy group’ inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-interaction task (Taylor Aggression Paradigm) probing retaliatory aggression—clearly social-related processing. Sample consists of healthy adult participants (N=15, mean age 22.3, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects univariate analyses (contrasts and parametric modulation), with Talairach coordinates and cluster-corrected statistical maps described in the text and tables. It is not limited to ROI, connectivity-only, or resting-state analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Although the sample is small and all-male, the healthy adult group results are reported and generalizable within the stated population. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI task study of social-related processing (self- and other-reflection = perception/understanding of self and others). The sample includes a healthy adult control group (21 HCs) reported separately. The paper reports within-group, whole-brain univariate task effects for the healthy control group (contrasts self > semantic and other > semantic) with voxelwise thresholding and cluster statistics; activations and coordinates are described in the text and supplementary materials. Analyses are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only approaches. Participants are adults (matched on age/intelligence) and data are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range ages) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Empirical fMRI study of social processing (learning about others’ preference similarity/affiliation) using task-based, social-related paradigms. (2) Sample comprises healthy adults (N=25, mean age 25.1) within the 17–65 range.
