(3) Reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked results (cluster-corrected activations, MNI peak coordinates, conjunction analyses) clearly from the healthy sample. (4) Not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or non-empirical methods. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore the study should be included in the review.

The study uses fMRI during a social-processing task (irony comprehension) and includes healthy adult controls, but the full text does not clearly report an unmasked, group-level whole-brain task activation map explicitly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. Results focus on combined participant main effects and between-group contrasts (controls>patients) and reference previously published control results, but do not present a standalone healthy-group whole-brain activation map or coordinate table clearly attributable to the healthy adult group. Because the inclusion criteria require an accompanying whole-brain healthy-group task effect (not only between-group contrasts), this study does not meet all inclusion requirements.

Although this fMRI study uses a social-related facial emotion task and includes a healthy adult control group (n=9, mean age 37), the full text reports only between-group contrasts (VCFS vs controls) and highlights between-group differences (Table 1). The paper does not present a clear, unmasked, group-level whole-brain task activation map or coordinate table specifically for the healthy/control group (no within-group ‘on>off’ healthy-group map or coordinates are reported in the provided text). Per the inclusion criteria, at least one whole-brain, univariate task-evoked statistical map attributable to healthy adults must be reported; the absence of such healthy-group whole-brain results means the study does not meet the required whole-brain evidence criterion and must be excluded.

This is a task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (ages 18–22) using an interactive social task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma), meeting the review’s domain (social processing). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise analyses (FEAT OLS, Z-stat images thresholded at Z>3.1 with FWE cluster correction) and presents whole-brain results (text, figures, tables), not ROI-only. Healthy participants’ results are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not resting-state only, not ROI-only, not outside age range). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception and evaluation of different laughter types, including explicit social categorization) in healthy adult participants (n=18, mean age 26). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (second-level random effects contrasts such as CSL>TIC and CAT>COU) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster-level FWE correction, and presents whole-brain results in text/figures/tables. Although the study also includes connectivity (PPI) analyses, it additionally provides univariate whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy adult sample. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, participants within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of healthy adult participants (n=25; ages 18.0–22.8) using a social-related action-observation task (risk-taking vs. safe hand actions) addressing perception/understanding of others and social/emotional processing. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate voxelwise contrasts (risk-taking vs safe) analyzed with SPM8 and presents cluster results and anatomical coordinates (whole-brain thresholding reported), not ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Participants are within the eligible age range (17–65) and are screened healthy undergraduates. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Study used task-based fMRI during a social interaction paradigm (ultimatum game) in healthy adult participants (ages 23–28). Although the primary analyses used multivariate classification, the paper reports offline whole-brain analyses and lists discriminative brain volumes/regions (with voxel-wise p-values from permutation tests and coordinates) derived from the cross-subject SVM weight maps, which constitute whole-brain, group-level voxelwise results generalizable to healthy adults. All other inclusion criteria are met (healthy adult sample, social task); no exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, empirical fMRI data reported). Therefore the study should be included.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (empathy for pain) using a task contrasting pain vs no-pain stimuli. It includes a healthy young adult subgroup (age 20–30) within the 17–65 range, and reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation maps (e.g., pain>no pain) with results and statistical maps available (NeuroVault/OpenfMRI). Whole-brain analyses and age-group contrasts are reported in the text/tables/figures. Therefore it meets the task, sample, and whole-brain evidence inclusion criteria.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI of social processing (implicit facial emotion task) and reports whole-brain, group-level activation maps for the control group, the sample comprises adolescents aged 12–18 (mean ~15). The meta-analysis requires at least one group of healthy adults aged 17–65, or a separately analyzed healthy adult subgroup. This paper does not present a separate healthy adult subgroup or analyses restricted to adults; the control group is adolescent. Therefore the sample criterion is not met and the study must be excluded.

This is an empirical task-fMRI study of social/attachment processing (mother–child and mother–dog affiliation). Sample consists of healthy adult participants (women aged 22–45); results are reported for this healthy group. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise univariate task contrasts (e.g., own child vs. fixation, own dog vs. fixation, own child vs. own dog) with MNI coordinates, statistical maps/figures, and cluster-level inference (even though small-volume correction/ROI masks were used for many hypotheses). It is not limited to connectivity or resting-state analyses and is not a non-empirical paper. Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults. Note: sample is a specific subgroup (mothers who own dogs), but the healthy adult group-level task activations are reported and thus eligible for inclusion.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (attribute framing, self and reflected perspectives). Sample comprises healthy adults within the target age range (19–41 years; group results reported after excluding 2 participants). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., task vs control, positive vs negative frame, frame-inconsistent vs frame-consistent) with stereotactic coordinates, statistical thresholds and cluster sizes described in the text and figures. It is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, nor a non-empirical paper. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

The study reports task-based fMRI using a social-cognitive paradigm (face processing, emotion recognition, affective Theory of Mind) that directly addresses social-related processing. The sample includes a healthy adult control group (n=18) reported separately from the psychopathy group. The paper conducts whole-brain second-level random-effects analyses (thresholds for whole-brain results given, and supplementary tables referenced) and explicitly reports task-associated activation in the healthy controls (bilateral STS, inferior prefrontal gyrus and other cortical activations), satisfying the requirement for a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked map from healthy adults. The study is empirical and within the 17–65 adult range. It does not rely solely on ROIs or connectivity. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult subjects examining neural responses to racial ingroup vs outgroup faces — a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). The reported results describe significant BOLD signal differences in the amygdala for outgroup vs ingroup faces across subjects (a within-group contrast), and the authors subsequently conducted an ROI analysis on voxels identified from that effect, implying an initial voxelwise group-level task activation. No clinical or special groups are reported, and the contrast is a group-level, task-evoked effect generalizable to healthy adults. Although the excerpt does not explicitly list whole-brain statistical maps or coordinate tables, the description of identified voxels and group-level BOLD effects supports inclusion. Age range is not specified but participants are described as adult subjects. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

While this is an fMRI hyperscanning study of social interactions in healthy adults (38 participants, mean age 22.4) using an interactive cooperation/competition task, the reported neuroimaging results are entirely data-driven (group-ICA spatial components and inter-subject correlation of component time-series). The paper does not present a group-level, univariate, voxelwise task-evoked statistical map (e.g., GLM main effects or within-group contrasts) attributable to the healthy sample. The primary outputs are ICA component spatial maps and ISC coupling coefficients, which fall under connectivity/data-driven analyses rather than conventional whole-brain task activation contrasts. Per the review’s inclusion criteria, studies must report at least one univariate whole-brain task activation map for the healthy group. Because that criterion is not met and the study mainly reports ICA/ISC (connectivity) results, it should be excluded.

The provided full-text content is only a website privacy/cookie notice and does not contain the article’s methods, participant information, task description, or results. Although the title and citation indicate an fMRI study of self-knowledge (a social-related construct) by healthy-adult researchers, I cannot verify critical inclusion criteria: presence of a healthy adult sample (ages 17–65) reported separately, or at least one group-level univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map for the healthy group. Because the full text does not provide these necessary details and no whole-brain results can be confirmed, the study cannot be included. Recommend obtaining the full article text or PDF to reassess eligibility.

This is an fMRI task study of social-related processing (social interpersonal touch/affiliation). Sample comprises 40 healthy adult males (mean age 25.8), meeting the age and healthy-sample criteria. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked activation maps and statistical results (whole-brain contrasts, coordinate tables, PFWE-corrected clusters, figures) for the healthy/control group. Analyses are not restricted to ROI-only or resting-state/connectivity-only approaches. Results are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social cognition (agency vs. communion) in healthy adults (n=42, ages 18–25). It reports group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise contrasts (agency vs. fixation/implicit baseline, communion vs. fixation/implicit baseline, conjunctions, and direct contrasts) analyzed in SPM8 with AlphaSim correction and tables/figures of activations. The sample is within the 17–65 range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity/resting analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusions.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (voice perception—a social-perceptual task). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=8 males, mean age 27.1) reported separately from the autism group. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, task-evoked univariate analyses for the control group (random-effects analysis, P < 0.001 corrected) with figures and supplementary tables of activation peaks (voice > non-voice). No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, healthy adults within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

The study sample comprises children and adolescents aged 8.1–16.5 years (final N=55) with no healthy adult group in the 17–65 age range. Although the study uses fMRI and reports whole-brain task-evoked analyses of social processing, it fails the sample inclusion criterion requiring at least one group of healthy adult participants (age 17–65). Therefore it does not meet the meta-analysis’ participant-age requirement despite meeting other methodological criteria.

This is an fMRI study of charitable donation and altruistic decisions—socially relevant constructs (affiliation/attachment, moral/social judgment). Sample: 19 healthy adult participants (mean age 28.2), within the 17–65 range. Analyses: group-level, random-effects, univariate whole-brain contrasts are reported (GLM contrasts, conjunctions, tables of activations/coordinates and cluster thresholds are described), not limited to ROI or connectivity-only results. The task is a social-related, decision-making paradigm (donate/oppose causes) and results are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not a non-empirical paper, and healthy adults reported separately). Therefore the paper meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

This article is a narrative/review-style synthesis of multiple fMRI studies of social cognition (including the authors’ prior empirical work) rather than an original empirical fMRI report presenting new whole-brain, group-level task activation maps for a healthy adult sample. Although it describes fMRI experiments (some conducted in adults), the manuscript compiles and discusses prior findings and does not report novel, separable whole-brain voxelwise results for a healthy adult group in a way that would meet the meta-analysis inclusion criteria. Therefore it fails the requirement for original whole-brain task-evoked maps from a healthy adult sample and must be excluded.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task involves social-related processing—reading suspenseful text engages mentalizing/theory-of-mind (authors interpret suspense-related activations in medial frontal cortex and TPJ as social-cognitive/mentalizing processes). (2) Sample: healthy adult participants (N=23; ages 19–32). (3) Whole-brain evidence: group-level, voxelwise random-effects GLM results reported for the parametric suspense regressor (cluster-level FWE-corrected maps and tables of peak coordinates). Not excluded by any criterion: analyses include whole-brain univariate task activations (not ROI-only), and results are reported for the healthy group. Therefore the study is eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis of social-related fMRI processing in healthy adults.

Insufficient information to confirm required whole-brain, group-level univariate task activation maps for a healthy adult group. The study involves mothers of preterm infants (a specific subgroup) and, while it appears to use fMRI on social/attachment-related stimuli (own children’s emotional expressions), the provided full-text excerpt contains only references and no methods or results confirming: (1) a healthy adult sample (generalizable, age 17–65) reported separately; (2) at least one univariate, voxelwise whole-brain task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group. Without explicit whole-brain results (tables/figures/coordinates) or clear reporting of a healthy-group effect, the inclusion criteria are not met. Therefore exclude.

This is an fMRI study of social perception (automatic perception of cooperative vs noncooperative behavior), with a healthy control group of adults (n=19) reported separately alongside a clinical group. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts for the healthy control group (e.g., C+ > C–) with voxelwise statistical results (FDR/FWE-corrected), coordinates, figures, and text description. It is not ROI-only and not limited to connectivity or resting-state analyses. Participant ages are described as adults and groups were matched; healthy-group whole-brain maps are clearly presented and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI hyperscanning study of healthy adult participants (N=44; mean age 22.4) performing an interactive social task (pattern game) manipulating cooperation/competition and interaction structure — clearly a social-processing paradigm. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate GLM analyses (FEAT/FLAME) with non-parametric permutation correction (randomize/TFCE), provides clusterwise results and coordinate tables/thresholded maps, and describes group effects generalizable to healthy adults. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and participants fall within the 17–65 range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

Although the study includes a healthy adult control group (n=29) and uses an fMRI task explicitly probing social processing (group vs individual social-emotional images), all reported healthy-group activation results are presented from ROI-restricted analyses (a composite a priori mask of frontopolar, temporal poles, IFG, and TPJ) and described as surviving correction within ROIs (FDR/FWE within ROI). The paper does not report an unmasked, whole-brain group-level voxelwise task activation map for the healthy/control group (nor tables/figures clearly identified as whole-brain healthy-group results). Because the review’s inclusion criterion requires at least one whole-brain, group-level task-evoked map for healthy adults, this study must be excluded.

This is a proof-of-concept methods paper reporting simultaneous EEG–rt-fMRI correlations focused on a right pSTS ROI for neurofeedback. The manuscript describes feature extraction and correlation analyses between EEG segments and an fMRI ROI rather than reporting group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task-evoked activation maps from a healthy adult sample. It appears to focus on ROI-based correlation and NF feasibility rather than univariate whole-brain task results; sample details and healthy-group whole-brain statistical maps are not provided in the abstract/full-text excerpt. Therefore it fails the requirement for whole-brain, group-level univariate task activation maps and is excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=28, age 30–50) that explicitly investigates self-referential and social stimulus processing. The task includes social-related stimuli (pictures depicting humans) and a self-referential judgment; analyses report group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (main effects, conjunctions, direct contrasts and interactions) with FDR correction and coordinate tables/figures. Results for the healthy sample are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The paper is not limited to ROI, connectivity-only, patient-only, or non-empirical analyses. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy young adults using a social attribution task (perception/understanding of others), directly addressing the review objective. The abstract reports group-level activations in multiple brain regions (FFA, amygdala, temporal pole, medial PFC, STS), indicating whole-brain, task-evoked univariate results rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. The sample is healthy adults, and the reported effects are described at the group level and are generalizable to healthy participants. No exclusion criteria are met (not a review, not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, and participants are within the 17–65 age range). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria and should be INCLUDED.

This is an fMRI study of social interaction perception in healthy adults (experiments: N=49, ages 19–34; and N=23, ages 18–30). Tasks probe perception and understanding of others (observed social interactions vs independent actions; cooperation vs competition). The paper reports group-level whole-brain univariate analyses (e.g., group contrast interaction > independent actions with FDR-corrected clusters in pSTS; whole-brain thresholds and maps described) and provides voxelwise contrast results/generalizable healthy-group findings. Analyses include whole-brain random-effects group analysis and reported corrected results; results for healthy adult participants are reported separately. No exclusion criteria apply (not only ROI/FC/resting, not only between-group contrasts, participants within 17–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social processing: participants passively viewed socially relevant vs. arbitrary facial expressions in a social-interaction paradigm. Sample: 17 healthy adults (right-handed males, mean age 25.9) within the 17–65 range. Whole-brain, voxelwise, group-level univariate analyses were reported (SPM5 random-effects ANOVA; FIR model; whole-brain coverage) with thresholding and coordinates presented (figures/tables and MNI peak coordinates for the main effect of SOC/time-bin 5). The reported effects are task-evoked, generalizable to the healthy group, and not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only results. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the paper meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although the study includes a healthy adult control group (20 adults) and uses task-based fMRI during a social (trust) game, the paper’s primary imaging analyses are ROI-restricted. The only whole-brain, voxel-wise results reported are between-group contrasts (control > patient) from an exploratory analysis; the manuscript does not present an unmasked, within-group whole-brain task activation map for the healthy/control group that is generalizable to healthy adults. Per the inclusion criteria, a healthy-group whole-brain task effect (e.g., within-group or main effect in controls) is required. Therefore the study must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (25 scanned participants, ages ~22) using a social-interaction task (repeated pairwise public good game) that probes affiliation/other-regarding preferences. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked results (parametric modulation of tie, impulse, contribution magnitude) with MNI coordinates, cluster-wise FWE correction and figures/tables of activation maps. Analyses include voxelwise GLM contrasts and parametric modulators; results are clearly reported for the healthy/control group. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and participants fall within the target age range. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is a task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (n=20, mean age 20.65 within 17–65). The paper investigates event simulation tied to situational understanding and social cognition (references to theory-of-mind, trait inference; separate analyses for social vs non-social trials). The authors report group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (e.g., Imp–Con, Exp–Imp, Ftr–Exp) with cluster-level multiple-comparison correction and peak coordinates, and random-effects second-level inference — satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, not non-empirical). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for healthy adult whole-brain social-related fMRI task studies.

Although the study uses task fMRI with a social-affective (movie) stimulus and includes a healthy adult group, it does not report any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps for the healthy/control group. The paper’s primary analyses are sliding-window network-cohesion (connectivity) metrics based on a priori meta-analytic nodes and group comparisons of those connectivity indices; no unmasked whole-brain healthy-group activation maps or voxelwise within-group contrasts are presented (only network-based activity summaries). Because the review requires at least one healthy-group whole-brain task activation map, this study fails criterion 3 and must be excluded.

Although the study uses fMRI during a social decision task in a healthy adult, it reports data from a single pilot subject (n=1). Inclusion requires at least one group of healthy adult participants and a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map generalizable to the healthy adult population. The reported contrasts and whole-brain statistics are based on a single subject rather than a group-level analysis, so the study does not meet the sample and whole-brain, group-level evidence inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-cognition task (Theory of Mind and empathy comic-strip task) in a healthy adult sample (76 college students, ages 17–21). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain SPM activation maps (ToM vs control, Empathy vs control, pooled condition) with random-field-theory correction and uses these maps in analyses; thus whole-brain task-evoked results for the healthy group are available. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, and participants fall within the 17–65 range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related processing in healthy adults.

The study includes a healthy adult control group (20 females, mean age 28.15) and uses task-based fMRI of social processing (social judgment/feedback). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise within-group task contrasts for controls (acceptance>control and rejection>control) with cluster correction and lists activations (e.g., ventral striatum, anterior insula, medial prefrontal cortex). Results for the healthy group are reported separately and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, or absent healthy-group whole-brain maps) are violated.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Uses task-based fMRI with two social-cognitive tasks (emotional perspective-taking and emotion attribution) that probe perception/understanding of others (social-related processing). (2) Sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=121 for fMRI tasks; overall n=129; age 18–35), within the 17–65 range. (3) Reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts (emotion perspective-taking > shape match; emotion attribution > gender match) with family-wise error correction and subsequent whole-brain regression analyses; results are described and localized (STS, fusiform, IFG) and thus generalizable to the healthy group. Not excluded by any exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not resting-state/ connectivity only). Therefore include for meta-analysis of healthy adult task fMRI social processing.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (attribution of emotions/understanding others) using healthy adult participants (final samples: Explicit Task n=16, Implicit Task n=17; ages 21–46). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., Emotion > Expression; Face > Scramble) with whole-brain cluster-level FWE correction and conjunction analyses, not limited to ROI-only results. Healthy-group within-subject contrasts are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, patient-only, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This study used task-based fMRI during a social interaction task (a one-shot Prisoner’s Dilemma) directly addressing social cooperation. The sample comprises healthy adult participants (final imaging N=18; mean age ~21, within 17–65). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked activation results (contrasts such as CC vs. other outcomes), including MNI coordinates, cluster statistics, and FWE-corrected thresholds, not ROI-only analyses. Results are presented clearly for the healthy control group and are generalizable to healthy adults (although sampled from young adult females only). No exclusion criteria are violated (not resting-state/connectivity-only, not a methods/review paper, and healthy adults are within age range). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study is an fMRI task-based investigation of face identity and emotional-expression processing (social perception of others) in healthy adult participants (N=35, mean age 29). It reports whole-brain, group-level random-effects voxelwise analyses (ANCOVA) with FDR-corrected maps, specific voxel coordinates, contrasts (e.g., angry vs neutral), and reported correlations with behavior — meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, or non-empirical) are violated.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task is social-related—learning facts about persons and contrasts person > building/hammer targeting social/person knowledge; (2) Sample comprises healthy adults (12 right-handed, age 20–32); (3) Reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked analyses (conjunctions, voxelwise contrasts, cluster-corrected maps and ROI-corrected thresholds) with results described in text, figures, and supplementary material; (4) Not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

Although this study uses fMRI during a social-emotional (face) task and includes a healthy adult (TD) control group (ages within 17–65), the reported fMRI results are restricted to amygdala ROI analyses. The paper does not present an unmasked, whole-brain, group-level task activation map (or whole-brain voxelwise coordinates) for the healthy/TD group; results and statistical corrections are reported within the a priori amygdala ROI. Because the inclusion criteria require at least one whole-brain task-evoked group map from the healthy adult group, this study must be excluded.

The study reports fMRI task activations for social-cognitive (sadness introspection) processing and provides whole-brain, group-level univariate maps. However, the sample consists of adolescents (participants were age ~16; samples drawn from youth cohorts) and does not include a healthy adult group in the 17–65 year range. No separate analyses of a healthy adult subgroup are reported. Therefore it fails the sample inclusion criterion (healthy adults 17–65) and must be excluded despite meeting other criteria (task relevance and whole-brain results).

This study reports task-based fMRI of social interaction (SI) recognition using point-light displays — a social-related task. It includes a healthy adult group (n=16, mean age 28.8) within the 17–65 range and reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (SI > NM) analyzed with SPM8, including thresholding and FWE cluster/peak information for the adult group. Healthy adult results are presented separately from child/adolescent groups. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, or lacking healthy adult whole-brain task maps) apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (N=17, mean age 26). The task probes social-related constructs (observation of social vs. individual actions; gaze manipulation). They conducted whole-brain, voxelwise random-effects analyses using SPM and report group-level univariate contrasts, activation maps, and tables of coordinates for main effects and interactions (dMPFC, pSTS, amygdala, IFG, etc.). The paper is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and reports healthy-group whole-brain task effects generalizable to healthy adults. All inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are violated.

The study uses task-based fMRI of action observation/anticipation, which fits the review construct 'Perception and Understanding of Others' (social-related processing). Participants are healthy adult badminton players (novices to international), and group-level whole-brain, univariate random-effects analyses are reported (shots–mctrl contrasts; maps/peak coordinates and figures reported; FWE-corrected thresholds). Although ROI analyses are also performed, whole-brain results are explicitly presented, satisfying the whole-brain evidence criterion. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state-only, participants are within adult range). Therefore the paper meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social-related processing (empathy/social cognition: viewing human and animal suffering). Sample includes 60 healthy adults (ages 18–60) meeting the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked analyses (first-level contrasts and second-level random-effects ANOVA; one-sample and paired t-tests; coordinates in MNI space; results reported at p<0.05 FWE and in tables/figures). Analyses are not limited to ROIs, connectivity, or clinical subgroups. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Meets all inclusion criteria: task is an fMRI study of social cognition (action understanding/mentalizing), sample comprises healthy adults (N=19, ages 18–32) with group-level random-effects analyses reported. The paper reports univariate voxelwise task contrasts with coordinates and cluster results (Table 1) within an a priori mask and indicates whole-brain results are provided in the Supplemental Material, satisfying the requirement for group-level whole-brain task-evoked maps generalizable to healthy adults. It is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only contrasts, nor non-empirical work. Therefore it should be included in the meta-analysis.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI of a clearly social paradigm (direct vs. averted gaze) in a healthy adult sample (N=55), the reported neuroimaging results are ROI-based (amygdala and inferior occipital gyrus) with FWE correction within those ROIs. The paper does not present or report any unmasked, whole-brain group-level (voxelwise) task activation maps or whole-brain coordinate tables/generalizable healthy-group task effects. Because the review requires at least one whole-brain univariate healthy-group task activation map, this study does not meet that key inclusion criterion.

This study reports an fMRI task specifically probing social processing (observing virtual social interactions). Participants are described as typical/healthy volunteers with informed consent, and group-level results are reported from 15 participants. Data acquisition provided whole-brain coverage and preprocessing/analysis used SPM, and the paper presents group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked activation maps (figures showing STS, mPFC, amygdala activations) reflecting healthy-group effects. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, and participants appear to be healthy adults within the target age range). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This fMRI study uses a task that probes social-related processing (participants imagine performing/relating to body-checking actions of others, engaging self-referential and social cognition/mirroring processes). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=15, ages 17–34) with results reported separately. The paper reports univariate, whole-brain group activation maps for the healthy control group (figures/tables and cluster-corrected voxelwise results), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked evidence. The study is empirical, task-based, and not limited to ROI/connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: study used task-based fMRI of social processing (dynamic vs. static facial-expression perception — social communication/perception of others). Includes a healthy adult control group (n=13, mean age 24.3, within 17–65). Reports group-level, univariate whole-brain contrasts for the control group (simple main effect dynamic>static), with corrected whole-brain results and coordinates shown in tables/figures and described in text. Although the paper also includes clinical (ASD) participants, healthy-group results are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met (whole-brain results are provided; not ROI-only or connectivity-only). Therefore the paper should be INCLUDED in the meta-analysis.

Study employed task-based fMRI of social judgments (approachability), including healthy adult control participants. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain analyses (social vs gender and social vs baseline contrasts) with cluster- and voxel-wise FWE correction, and within-group analyses are described (supplementary tables s3–s6, figures s1–s5), providing univariate whole-brain task activation maps attributable to the healthy/control group. Analyses are not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only methods, and healthy controls’ results are reported separately from clinical groups. Thus all inclusion criteria are met.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (ages 17–43) using a social/group-related task (minimal-group in-group/out-group action perception and judgments). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts (single-video and paired-video trials) with cluster-level FWE correction and provides coordinates and statistical maps/results. Sample and analyses are reported for the healthy control group separately. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-only, not a non-empirical paper). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This article is a narrative review (non-empirical) describing functional neuroimaging approaches to social cognition. It does not report original fMRI data from a sample of healthy adults, nor does it present group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps or coordinates. As such it meets the exclusion criterion for non-empirical papers without original fMRI data. Although it discusses fMRI methods and example findings, it does not provide eligible whole-brain results for a healthy adult group that could be included in the meta-analysis.

The provided full text is a brief conference abstract that does not report key required details. It does not provide participant/sample characteristics (age range, number of healthy adults) or clearly report at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map for a healthy/control group (results are described qualitatively). The methods/results appear to focus on BOLD/network changes and comparisons between dyadic and monadic fMRI but lack explicit whole-brain voxelwise task activation maps or coordinates. Because the inclusion criteria require clearly identified healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked maps generalizable to healthy adults, and the abstract lacks these data (and may be a preliminary conference report), the study must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (Theory of Mind using validated Heider–Simmel animations). The sample comprises healthy adults (n=20; age range 24–64), within the 17–65 inclusion range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task contrasts (e.g., ToM > Random, ToM > Baseline) with voxelwise thresholds and identified activations (coordinates/regions and cluster-level correction), not limited to ROI analyses. Results for the healthy control group are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, not outside age range). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although the study includes a healthy adult control group (TD; ages 18–34) and uses a task-based fMRI Domino paradigm, the reported imaging results are ICA/component-based (GIG-ICA spatial maps and component-level beta-weights/temporal-sorting) and group comparisons of component modulation. The paper does not report any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked contrast map (e.g., TD show>no-show GLM voxelwise map or table of coordinates) that would qualify as whole-brain activation evidence for the healthy group. Therefore it fails the ‘Whole-brain evidence’ inclusion criterion.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (real-time mutual eye contact/social communication) in healthy adults (N=32–34; mean age ~21.8 years, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (LIVE > REPLAY) analyzed with random-effects GLM and cluster-level FWE correction, with detailed clusters/coordinates and figures. Although additional connectivity and interbrain analyses are present, the manuscript clearly provides whole-brain task-evoked activation maps for the healthy sample. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, and participants are healthy adults). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception/understanding of others via point-light social interactions). Sample: 14 healthy adults (mean age 29.4), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (SI vs NSI contrast) using random-effects one-sample t-tests with FDR correction (p<0.05) and cluster reporting; activations are described in text, figures and tables. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and reports healthy-group whole-brain results generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study with healthy adult participants (n=20, ages 20–28). The task involves social-related processing (empathy, socio-cognitive evaluation of others) using campaign videos designed to elicit empathy—clearly within the review’s constructs (perception/understanding of others, social communication). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (CV > NV), thresholded at p<0.05 FWE corrected, with peak coordinates and cluster information provided and used as ROIs; these are clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. The study is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or clinical groups. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study using the Ultimatum Game, a social-exchange task probing social decision-making (perception/understanding of others, affiliation/cooperation). Sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=51 initially; final analyses on healthy adults with mean age ~31, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (parametric regressors, conjunctions, interaction contrasts) with voxelwise results and MNI coordinates, cluster- and FDR-corrected significance thresholds, and tables/figures of activations. Although ROI and PPI analyses are included, whole-brain healthy-group activation maps are clearly reported. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

Although the study includes a healthy adult control group (young TD adults) and uses task-based fMRI on a social (pseudo-interactive) paradigm, the paper does not report any group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy/control group. The authors explicitly state that whole-brain and connectivity analyses could not be conducted due to signal loss and instead present an ROI-only analysis of the arMPFC. This violates the inclusion criterion requiring at least one whole-brain, task-evoked healthy-group map. Therefore the study must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study with healthy adult participants (interns N=19, producers N=79; mean ages ≈20.5 within 17–65). The task is social (message communication, persuasion, mentalizing — social communication and understanding of others). The paper reports group-level whole-brain, random-effects univariate analyses (buzz, intention, salesperson effects) with voxelwise thresholds and MNI coordinates (whole-brain results reported and illustrated; Table 1/Figures). Results are not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Although this fMRI study used a social task (angry vs neutral face viewing) in healthy adult participants and reports ROI (FFA, amygdala) results and seed-based PPI connectivity maps (with whole-brain cluster thresholds), it does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked activation map (e.g., main effect or within-group contrast of faces) for the healthy/control group. The reported voxelwise results are from seed-based PPI connectivity analyses and ROI-based percent signal change; per the review’s exclusion criteria, studies that report only ROI and/or seed-based connectivity results without a healthy-group whole-brain univariate task activation map must be excluded.

This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=12, mean age 25.2) examining agency attribution/intentionality (social cognition, ToM-related). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (random-effects second-level contrasts: High>Low and Low>High) with voxelwise thresholds (p<0.001) and presents activation loci (STS, IFG, occipital regions) in text/figures. It is not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only analyses, and participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met (social-related fMRI task; healthy adult sample; whole-brain group-level task activation maps reported). Exclusion criteria are not triggered.

This study uses task-based fMRI in healthy adults (a neurotypical control group of 21 age- and IQ-matched adult males) during observation of social touch videos (social cognition: perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level univariate whole-brain task results: mean group effects for social vs. non-social touch and felt touch are provided (with MNI coordinates and figures/tables referenced in main/supplementary materials), satisfying the requirement for a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map. Healthy control results are reported separately from the ASD group. The sample is within the adult age range, and the study includes original empirical fMRI data. It does not fall under ROI-only, connectivity-only, or non-empirical exclusions. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This study reports task-based fMRI during a social decision-making paradigm (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) in a healthy adult sample (N=20 males, age 21–37). The paper presents group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (one-sample t tests for task phases in the placebo condition and flexible factorial analyses including treatment and opponent effects), with results thresholded at FWE cluster-corrected p<0.05 and reported in tables/figures. These maps represent task-evoked activation generalizable to healthy adults. Although the design includes a pharmacological manipulation (MDMA) and only male participants, the healthy-group whole-brain task effects are explicitly reported, meeting the inclusion criteria. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, or lack of whole-brain task maps) are violated.

The study is an fMRI experiment of social evaluation (impression formation) using task-evoked BOLD contrasts. It includes a healthy young adult group (ages 20–29), meeting the 17–65 sample criterion, and reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses (social vs. non-social; social-meaningful vs. social-irrelevant) with corrected thresholds and conjunctions. Results are not limited to ROIs or connectivity analyses and provide whole-brain activation maps/coordinates for the healthy groups. Although an older group includes participants >65, the young adult group is analyzed and reported separately, satisfying inclusion. Therefore the paper meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the listed exclusions.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception/understanding of self and others via a body-perception task). Sample: healthy adult participants (N=30, ages ~26, 15 male/15 female), results reported separately for healthy groups. Whole-brain, univariate group-level task contrasts are reported (e.g., own body > scrambled; same-sex and opposite-sex contrasts; parametric modulation analyses) with voxelwise Z thresholds and cluster-correction (FLAME, FSL), and results presented in text, figures and supplementary tables. The paper is empirical, not ROI-only or connectivity-only. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked activation maps in healthy adults.

This is a task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (n=19, ages 18–58) investigating social communication (prosody perception and production) and its relation to empathy. Group-level, whole-brain, univariate contrasts are reported (e.g., “happy–neutral”, “question–neutral”) with random-effects analyses and multiple-comparison thresholds (FDR, cluster thresholds) and coordinates/results described in text and supplementary materials. The sample is within the 17–65 range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. The paper is empirical and not ROI-only, and it provides task-evoked whole-brain activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusions.

This article is a narrative review/theoretical paper (discusses findings, frameworks, and prospects) and does not report original empirical fMRI data, participant sample, or group-level whole-brain task activation maps from healthy adults. Inclusion requires an empirical fMRI study with healthy adult participants and at least one univariate whole-brain group map; those criteria are not met. Therefore it must be excluded.

This fMRI study uses a task (listening to popular, artistic music, and control notes) in healthy adult participants (n=18 males, age 18–24). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain contrasts (Popular>Notes, Artistic>Notes, Popular>Artistic, Artistic>Popular) and parametric analyses with whole-brain thresholds and coordinates, satisfying the whole-brain univariate result requirement. Although the paradigm is musical/aesthetic rather than an explicit social-interaction task, the authors explicitly interpret activation in default-mode/ToM and cognitive-empathy regions (arMFC, PCC/PC, TPJ/angular gyrus, hippocampus) as engagement of social-cognitive/mentalizing processes (Perception/Understanding of Others). Sample age is within 17–65 and results are reported for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria are met. Note: the social nature of the task is inferred by the authors rather than being an explicit social behavioral paradigm, hence confidence is moderate-high.

This is an fMRI study with 24 healthy adult participants (ages 22–39) that investigates collective/social knowledge and its neural representation (dmPFC/vmPFC). The experimental task involved task-evoked memory recall during fMRI (recall of museum pictures cued by captions), probing social-related constructs (collective memory, social knowledge, narrative comprehension, mentalizing). The paper reports group-level whole-brain searchlight analyses producing TFCE-corrected maps (Extended Data Fig.1) and ROI/second-level results derived from the healthy control group, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain, group-level task-evoked effects generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (only ROI, connectivity-only, non-empirical, out-of-range ages) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social communication (charades) in healthy adult participants (n=18 analyzed; mean age 27.5). The task probes perception and understanding of others through gestural communication. The authors performed group-level whole-brain analyses: they ran traditional GLM analyses (used to define mirror ROIs that were active during gesturing and guessing) and report group-level between-brain Granger-causality (bbGCM) maps (thresholded and corrected) showing directed influences across brains. Thus the paper includes whole-brain, task-evoked group results from healthy adults and is not limited to ROI-only or solely resting-state/connectivity reports. It therefore meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

Although the study used fMRI in healthy adult participants and includes analyses of 'social communication' as one of many labeled categories during passive viewing of natural movies, it does not meet key inclusion requirements for this meta-analysis. The experiment employed passive movie viewing rather than a targeted social-related task or condition, and the analyses are voxelwise encoding and clustering models rather than standard group-level univariate task contrasts. The paper does not report a clear, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) group-level task activation map for social processing (e.g., a social > baseline or social > non-social contrast) that is generalizable to healthy adults; results focus on ROI-based model fits, encoding-model prediction scores, and cluster/PC projections. Therefore it fails the criterion requiring a whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked statistical map for the healthy group and should be excluded.

This is a task-based fMRI study using a Face Matching Task (implicit emotional face perception), which clearly targets social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). The sample comprises healthy adults (n=10; mean age 25 within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise GLM results: first-level contrasts (e.g., fear > neutral) and second-level one-sample t-tests (P<0.005, k=10), with whole-brain results presented (Table S2 and Figures S1–S3 in Supplementary Material). Although the study also uses ICA, it does provide univariate whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps, satisfying the inclusion criteria and not violating exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not only connectivity/resting-state). Therefore it should be INCLUDED in the review.

This is an fMRI study of facial emotion discrimination (social perceptual processing) in healthy adults (control group n=27, ages 19–35). The paper reports whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts that are clearly attributed to the healthy/control group (within-group condition contrasts for NC, e.g., AH>HH activations reported with cluster-level statistics and FWE-corrected p-values and voxel counts). The task probes perception/understanding of others (faces/emotional expressions), matching the review’s social-processing domain. Results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses and include group-level whole-brain maps/tables generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of deception (a social-cognition task involving theory-of-mind/understanding others) in a healthy adult sample (n=24 males, ages 19–60). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise SPM random-effects contrasts (lie>truth and truth>lie) with whole-brain statistical maps/coordinate tables and figures (thresholds and cluster results are reported; small-volume corrections were used for a priori ROIs but whole-brain uncorrected results are also presented). The task and results are clearly from the healthy/control group and are generalizable to healthy adults. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, outside age range, or non-empirical) are violated.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task-based fMRI of social processing (advice-taking and trust decisions; perception/understanding of others and social evaluation). (2) Sample: 31 healthy adult participants (mean age 24.3), within 17–65. (3) Reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked results (GLM contrasts; voxel-level and cluster-level FWE-corrected results reported; supplementary tables/figures with coordinates). (4) Empirical original neuroimaging study (not review). Although the paper also includes ROI and connectivity analyses (PPI) and multivariate decoding, it clearly presents whole-brain univariate maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore include in the meta-analysis.

Although this study uses fMRI in healthy adult participants (age range within 17–65) and investigates social cognition (theory of mind), the reported analyses focus on ROI-based MVPA using individually-defined ROIs (based on first-level Belief>Photo contrasts) and decoding within those ROIs. The provided full text does not clearly report any group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map (e.g., group GLM contrasts or whole-brain activation maps/coordinate tables) identified as coming from the healthy/control group. Because the inclusion criterion requires at least one group-level whole-brain univariate task activation map and the paper’s results as presented rely on ROI-localized analyses (and explicitly state ROI selection from first-level contrasts), this study fails the “Whole-brain evidence” requirement and should be excluded per the review’s criteria.

This is an fMRI study including a healthy adult control group (age range 20–46) reported separately from an ASD group. The task (emotional prosody processing) is clearly social-related (social communication/perception of others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts for controls (e.g., emotional vs neutral prosody and complexity/condition contrasts), with cluster-level FWE-corrected statistics and reported activation maps/tables, not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults (n=47 healthy controls; separate healthy male control group n=12 for ASD comparison). The tasks (approachability, intelligence judgments from faces) index social perception/understanding of others. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise contrasts for healthy participants (social vs gender judgements) with thresholding and cluster-level correction, and provides within-group activation maps and coordinates for males and females separately. Results for the healthy groups are reported independently of the clinical ASD group. Participants are adults within the 17–65 range. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state/ connectivity-only, and is clearly a suitable whole-brain task activation dataset for inclusion.

The fMRI task is a monetary-reward continuous performance task (CPT), not a social-related task (e.g., social communication, perception/understanding of self/others, affiliation). Although the study includes a healthy adult control group (n=10) and reports whole-brain, group-level task activation maps for controls, the experimental paradigm does not probe social processing. Correlations of activation with clinical social-interaction scores in the clinical group do not make the task itself social. Therefore the primary inclusion criterion (fMRI during a social-related task) is not met, so the study must be excluded.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=21, mean age 24) that examines neural responses to observation and execution of actions (mirror representations), which falls under ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’ — a social-related construct. The paper reports group-level, univariate fMRI results including whole-brain analyses (thresholded whole-brain maps reported at p<0.001 uncorrected and tables of peak coordinates) in addition to ROI analyses. Participants are within the 17–65 age range, and results for the healthy group are clearly reported. The study is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only contrasts, nor is it non-empirical. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social communication (communicative vs descriptive speech) in a sample of 30 healthy adult native Japanese speakers who learned English as an L2. The paper reports group-level, task-evoked whole-brain univariate results (e.g., left posterior supramarginal gyrus, left MTG, orbitofrontal cortex/insula) associated with L2 communication, not limited to ROIs or connectivity analyses. Results are presented as generalizable healthy-group effects. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met (social-related task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task activation maps reported); no exclusion criteria apply.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Uses task-based fMRI during a social-related task (perception of biological motion/social perception). (2) Sample comprises healthy adults (n=26 analyzed; ages 18–39). (3) Reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task analyses: whole-brain analyses of biological-motion selectivity and social-network diversity yielded a significant cluster in right pSTS/TG/TPJ (cluster-level correction reported). (4) Results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study is eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Although the paper includes an fMRI subsample, the neuroimaging component comprises only 25 female patients with social anxiety disorder and reports correlations of OXTR methylation with amygdala responsiveness within this patient group using an ROI approach. The study does not present a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map for a healthy/control group that is generalizable to healthy adults. Primary whole-sample healthy participants (N=110) provided behavioral and methylation data but were not included in an fMRI whole-brain analysis. Therefore the study fails the inclusion requirement of a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map (and largely reports ROI-based patient-only results), so it must be excluded from the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=21, mean age 24.6) that investigates social cognition (person perception and person knowledge). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Bodies>Names; Traits>Neutral; interaction [(BodiesTraits>BodiesNeutral)>(NamesTraits>NamesNeutral)]) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster-level FWE correction, and presents coordinates/figures and overlap with functional localisers. Although PPI connectivity analyses are also reported, whole-brain univariate results from the healthy control sample are clearly provided. The sample and reported analyses meet the inclusion criteria and do not violate exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social cognition task (Visual–Verbal Self-Other Referential Processing Task) addressing perception/understanding of self and others. Sample comprises 20 healthy adult women (ages 18–52), within the 17–65 inclusion range. The paper reports whole-brain, univariate group-level voxelwise analyses (e.g., contrasts S‑N, S‑P, O‑N, O‑P vs fixation and contrasts between conditions), with cluster-level and coordinate results described in the text/tables/figures. Analyses are not limited to ROIs or connectivity/resting-state only. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social cognition (self/other conceptual and agentic recollection) in healthy adult participants (N=18; ages 19–29). The paper reports group-level voxelwise task activation analyses, including whole-brain results (FWE-corrected clusters reported) as well as ROI analyses; whole-brain contrasts and coordinates are described in text/tables and figures. The sample falls within the 17–65 range and only healthy adults are analyzed. The study is empirical task fMRI (not solely ROI, connectivity, or resting-state) and presents univariate, generalizable healthy-group activation maps. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

This study uses task-based fMRI during a social-related paradigm (perception of fearful faces with direct vs. averted gaze), addressing social perception/understanding of others. It includes a healthy adult control group (N=22, mean age 23.7±5.9) reported separately. The paper reports group-level whole-brain, voxelwise within-group contrasts for the control group (e.g., AVERTED>DIRECT and AVERTED>FIXATION), using mixed-effects analyses and FWE-corrected statistical maps/coordinates, meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. Results are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Age range and reporting permit generalization to healthy adults. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI task study of social-related processing (attentional orienting to gaze vs. arrow cues — social perception/understanding of others). Sample: 22 healthy adult participants (mean age ~22.95), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (whole-brain ANOVAs, contrasts with cluster/FWE thresholds and peak voxels reported; small-volume corrections and ROI follow-ups supplement but do not replace whole-brain results). Results for the healthy/control group are presented and interpretable for general healthy adults. The study is empirical original research and does not meet any exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not patient-only, and participants are within age range). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This fMRI study includes a social decision-making (altruism/dictator-game) task that probes perception/understanding of others and social choice. Participants are healthy adults (altruism N=55, subset N=37 also completed the food task; mean age ≈28, within 17–65). The methods describe group-level, whole-brain GLMs (trial-wise GLM1/GLM2) and report voxelwise, cluster-corrected whole-brain results (e.g., attribute and decision-value effects, conjunctions in VMPFC/DLPFC, and other reported contrasts), meeting the requirement for univariate whole-brain task-evoked maps from the healthy group. Although the paper emphasizes MVPA, univariate whole-brain analyses and results are reported, and findings are generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it satisfies inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social perception in healthy adults (final N=23, ages within 17–65). The task manipulates stimulus and knowledge cues to animacy (social-related constructs involving perception/understanding of others, mentalizing). The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise univariate task contrasts (e.g., human>robot, robot>human, belief effects, interactions) with voxel-level thresholds and cluster correction, and lists peak coordinates and clusters in tables/figures. Analyses are group-level and clearly generalizable to a healthy adult sample. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, includes within-group whole-brain task activations). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adults (N=30, ages 19–41) using a social gaze/action control paradigm (social perception/understanding of others). It provides group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., incongruent > congruent; direct > averted) with cluster-forming and FWE thresholds and reports coordinates/activation maps. Although it also includes seed-based PPI connectivity, whole-brain task activation results for the healthy adult sample are clearly reported. Sample age and healthy-group reporting meet inclusion criteria, and none of the exclusion criteria (ROI-only results, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only groups, or non-empirical paper) apply. Therefore the paper qualifies for inclusion in the review of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI task study probing social-related processing (perception/understanding of others/group dynamics) using footstep sounds contrasting one vs. two walkers. Sample: 12 healthy adults aged 22–37, reported separately (meets age and healthy-sample criterion). Whole-brain, group-level random-effects GLM maps are reported (contrasts such as STEP1+STEP2 – REST, STEP2 – NOISE2, STEP1 – NOISE1), with statistical thresholds and tables/figures of Talairach coordinates; therefore univariate whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked results are provided. The paper is empirical, not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and not limited to between-group contrasts. All inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria apply.

This study used task-based fMRI to investigate prosodic speech perception (a social-communication construct) and reports group-level, whole-brain univariate results for a healthy adult control group (one-sample t-tests and deactivation maps). The sample includes healthy adults (8 male controls aged ~23) reported separately from the HFA group. Whole-brain voxelwise activation and deactivation results for the control group are clearly described (thresholds, atlas localization, conjunctions), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The task is social-related (social communication/perception of affect in speech). No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, healthy adult group present and reported). Note: sample size is small, but that does not conflict with inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI task study of social processing (empathy-for-pain) in adults that includes a separately reported healthy control group (n=18, ages 22–63). The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (see Supplementary Table 1 and whole-brain contrasts described in the text) with peak coordinates (e.g., left anterior insula) and group-level results that are identifiable and generalizable to healthy adults. Although ROI analyses are used, whole-brain results and group-level contrasts involving the control group are reported (e.g., control-group increases in visual cortex and whole-brain contrasts for alexithymia subgroups), satisfying the requirement for univariate whole-brain task maps for healthy participants. Therefore the study meets the review’s inclusion criteria.

This study reports task-based fMRI in a healthy adult sample (n=20, mean age 24.1) investigating social-related perception (representation of two-body configurations implying interaction). It includes group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (random-effects GLMs; contrasts dyads > single-bodies and facing > nonfacing dyads) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster-level FWE correction, reported in tables and figures. The sample is within the 17–65 age range, and results for healthy participants are reported separately. The paper is empirical and not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or patient groups. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (memory for identities embedded in social goal-relevant vs. goal-irrelevant situations). Sample: healthy adult participants (final N=17, ages 20–36) within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (first- and second-level GLMs, random-effects ANOVAs) with voxelwise thresholds, cluster correction, and tables/figures of activations (ventral striatum, VTA/SN, STS, etc.). Results are not limited to ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrasts; whole-brain maps/coordinates are presented and clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults investigating perception/understanding of others (action recognition), a social-related construct. The full text reports group-level fMRI adaptation effects (decreased activity) in lateral occipitotemporal regions (pSTS, MT/MST, EBA), indicating univariate task-evoked activation contrasts generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state, non-empirical, or out-of-range age group) appear to apply based on provided information.

While this fMRI study uses a social task (trustworthiness judgments) and includes a healthy adult control group (ages 18–35), the reported analyses are limited to predefined ROI-based percent signal-change and group comparisons. The full text does not present any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation maps or tables of whole-brain coordinates identified as coming from the healthy/control group. Results focus on ROI extractions and between-group interactions rather than unmasked whole-brain healthy-group task effects. Therefore it violates the inclusion criterion requiring at least one healthy-group whole-brain task activation map and meets the exclusion criterion for studies reporting only ROI analyses without whole-brain results.

Although this is an fMRI study of social-related processing (action understanding/ToM) and includes a healthy adult control group, the paper does not report an unmasked, within-group whole-brain task activation map for the healthy/control group. Results are presented primarily as between-group contrasts (ALS > HC and HC > ALS) and ROI/SVC and conjunction analyses; no clearly identified whole-brain, group-level healthy-control task effect (e.g., HC observe>baseline or HC understand>baseline) is reported that is generalizable to healthy adults. Thus it fails the required whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social processing (face-to-face eye contact) in healthy adults. Sample: 19 pairs (38 healthy individuals), ages 18–33, with group analyses reported. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise univariate GLM results and paired t-tests (Ω_A, Ω_B, exogenous/endogenous contrasts) with inference thresholds (Z>2.3, p<0.05 and cluster reporting), cluster sizes, MNI coordinates, and atlas labels — satisfying the whole-brain, group-level task-evoked map requirement. Although ICA is also used, the study includes standard task GLM whole-brain results rather than only connectivity or ROI analyses. Participants are within the 17–65 range and results are presented for the healthy group. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This fMRI study reports task-evoked whole-brain, group-level univariate activation maps for a social-related Self/Other reflection task. A healthy adult control group (n=33) is included and reported separately, with whole-brain contrasts (Self>Facts, Other>Facts, Other>Self) presented and cluster-level corrected voxelwise results (with MNI coordinates and cluster statistics). Participants are adults within the eligible age range and healthy-group results are generalizable (not limited to a narrow subgroup). The paper therefore meets all inclusion criteria (social task, healthy adult sample with separate reports, and whole-brain task activation maps) and does not violate any exclusion criteria (no ROI-only, connectivity-only, or resting-state-only reporting).

Study reports task-based fMRI in 54 healthy adult participants (27 male pairs, age 18–27) engaged in a social communication task. It includes group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (e.g., search for BOLD dynamics matching behavioral mutual understanding; cluster-level FWE-corrected results reported) and reports anatomical activation (rSTG) from whole-brain contrasts. Although the paper also contains connectivity/coherence analyses, it provides univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps clearly from the healthy adult sample. Therefore it meets the review’s inclusion criteria.

This is a task-based fMRI study in healthy adult participants (women aged 18–35) that explicitly probes self-related social processing (participants rated whether odors made them want to “smell like this” — perception/understanding of self). The paper reports group-level, task-evoked univariate contrasts (e.g., ‘self’-peptide minus solvent; ‘self’-peptide minus ‘non-self’-peptide) with activation coordinates in MNI space and statistical thresholds; methods state that whole-brain analysis was performed in addition to ROI analyses. Results are reported for the healthy adult sample and are generalizable to the healthy group. No exclusion criteria (only ROI, resting-state, or non-healthy sample) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social processes (empathy, perspective taking, attention) in a healthy adult sample (N=33, ages 20–34). Tasks are social-related (charitable donation, EmpaToM), and participants are within the 17–65 age range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked results (univariate GLM contrasts are described; e.g., a significant cluster in early visual cortex for low>high donations) and extensive whole-brain multivariate analyses. Results are reported for the healthy/control group and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical and not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social perception (face emotion and age judgments), conducted in healthy adult participants (n=25, ages 21–33). The experiment used task-based fMRI with whole-brain preprocessing and group-level analyses: a random-effects whole-brain univariate contrast (faces > objects) was reported to define face-responsive ROIs, and whole-brain searchlight analyses (group-level, SnPM-corrected) are reported for task and stimulus decoding (tables/figures and cluster coordinates are provided). The sample and task fall within the review’s social-related constructs, and the paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked results for the healthy adult sample. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state only, or non-healthy-only sample) are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=22, mean age 24.36) using a social cognition task (mind perception; gaze-cueing social attention).
