The study reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (parametric regressors) with cluster-based correction (Z=1.96, p<.05) and identifies significant clusters (e.g., vmPFC, TPJ, fusiform). Healthy-control results are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. The methods include whole-brain GLM, preprocessing, and group-level inference; results are presented as whole-brain maps/tables. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity/resting-state-only, clinical-only sample, or non-empirical) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception/understanding of others; stigmatization/dehumanization responses to facial disfigurement). The fMRI sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=31; ages 18–35). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise contrasts (pre- vs post-treatment faces) analyzed with SnPM and corrected for multiple comparisons (FWE cluster-level correction) with results described in text, figures, and tables. The study is task-based (gender judgment while viewing faces) and not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for healthy adult whole-brain task-evoked fMRI evidence relevant to social processing.

Study is an empirical fMRI experiment using social scenarios (social-related task) with late adolescents and a separate young adult group. The paper reports task-evoked, whole-brain univariate activations (e.g., OFC, MTG, PCC, precuneus) described for the groups and contrasts (negative outcomes eliciting regret activated these regions for both age groups), and also reports between-group comparisons. The young adult group constitutes healthy adults within the target age range and their whole-brain results are reported separately. The study therefore meets the inclusion criteria (social fMRI task, healthy adult group, and group-level whole-brain task activation maps).

This is an fMRI study of healthy adult participants (N=15; ages 20–28) that includes a social-processing task (participants judged social distance using names and photos of friends vs acquaintances). The study reports group-level whole-brain analyses: a conventional univariate GLM with paired t-tests (sooner vs later; closer vs farther; more vs less familiar) and a conjunction analysis (they explicitly report voxelwise whole-brain results, noting no voxels survived FDR correction), as well as whole-brain MVPA (searchlight) and RSA results identifying right IPL effects. Thus it meets inclusion criteria: social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and reporting of group-level whole-brain task-evoked analyses (even though univariate results were null). No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception/integration of non-verbal vocalizations and facial movements). The fMRI sample includes healthy adults (n=10, ages 24–37). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise univariate analyses and whole-group activation maps/voxelwise t-tests (condition vs rest and AV versus unisensory contrasts) with cluster correction and Talairach-space maps/ROIs. Results are presented as group activation maps and statistical contrasts generalizable to the healthy adult sample (not limited to a clinical subgroup), and are not ROI-only or connectivity-only. Thus all inclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (fMRI sample N=29, 27 analyzed; mean age 25.6 within 17–65). The task is social in nature (delegated inter-temporal choice; learning about and simulating another person’s preferences), addressing perception/understanding of others and social influence. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts and repetition-suppression effects with cluster-level FWE correction and coordinates provided (mPFC, pMFC, striatum, STS), not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Results for healthy controls are reported and generalizable. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

Although the study tests social cognition in healthy adult participants (multiple social tasks; ages within 17–65) and reports group analyses, the primary neuroimaging analyses are localized ICA applied within a TPJ ROI and seed-to-voxel functional connectivity maps. The paper does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical activation map (e.g., whole-brain GLM contrast) for the healthy group generalizable across the brain; task-related results are derived from ROI-constrained ICA components and connectivity analyses. Because the review requires at least one whole-brain task activation map (voxelwise) for the healthy group, this study fails the ‘Whole-brain evidence’ inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (direct and reflected self-appraisals — ‘Perception and Understanding of Self’). It includes a healthy adult group (N=12, ages 22.6–30.4) and reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task activation results for adults (one-sample t-tests, conjunction analyses, within-group contrasts and whole-brain interaction analyses). Analyses are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only approaches. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked maps in healthy adults.

Although the study uses task fMRI in healthy adult participants and reports whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts (one-sample contrasts with FWE correction), the experimental paradigm assesses sexual arousal and incentive/reward responses to erotic pictures and videos rather than social-related processing as defined by the review (e.g., affiliation/attachment, social communication, perception/understanding of self or others in a social-cognitive sense). The primary aims and dependent measures focus on sexual orientation and reward (ventral striatum) and subjective arousal, not social cognition. Therefore it does not address the meta-analysis objective and should be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social processing using Cyberball (a social exclusion task addressing affiliation/belonging). Sample comprises healthy adults (final n=20, mean age ~25, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (e.g., social exclusion > fair play; same- versus other-gender exclusion) with cluster-level correction and tables/coordinates and figures. Analyses are not limited to ROIs or connectivity only. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore the study provides usable whole-brain task-evoked activation maps for healthy adults and should be included in the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study using a social task (cooperation vs competition; self/other ability estimation) in healthy adults (final N=24, ages 19–31). The paper reports group-level, task-evoked whole-brain univariate analyses (GLMs) identifying regions (pgACC, area 9) and links these maps to behavior; whole-brain results and contrasts are described and used to define ROIs. The sample falls within the 17–65 range and results are reported for the healthy group. The study is empirical and reports original task-based fMRI activation maps rather than only connectivity or ROI-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (Princeton undergraduates, mean age 19.5) performing a social-cognition task (evaluating emotions toward social-group images — perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain analyses (random-effects GLM, subtractive contrasts, 3-vs-1 contrasts) with Talairach coordinates and ROI conjunctions, i.e., univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps from the healthy sample. It is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or non-healthy populations. Age range fits inclusion (17–65). Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (kinship/moral dilemma). Sample comprises healthy adult participants (N=30, females aged 19–39). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise results: inter-subject correlation (ISC) maps across the whole brain and a GLM-based whole-brain contrast for the moral-dilemma decision task, with cluster/voxel statistics and coordinates. Analyses are not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, and results are reported for the healthy adult group. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI in healthy adults.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI assessing personal familiarity (a social-related construct) and reports whole-brain, within-group activation contrasts for the healthy control participants, the control sample is described as ‘healthy elderly’ (i.e., older adults). The review’s age inclusion criterion requires healthy adult participants aged 17–65, and studies that include only participants outside this range are excluded unless a qualifying healthy adult subgroup in-range is analyzed separately. No subgroup of healthy controls within 17–65 is reported. Therefore the study does not meet the age-range inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (n=19, males, age range 18–51 within 17–65) using an explicit social-related task (emotional prosody comprehension distinguishing simple vs. complex/social emotions). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise univariate contrasts (emotional vs. neutral; complex vs. simple), thresholding and correction procedures, and presents activation maps and tables, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Analyses are generalizable to a healthy adult group and results are not limited to an ROI or connectivity-only approach. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for an fMRI study of social-related processing in healthy adults.

While the study uses fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=8, ages 22–39) and examines social-related natural touch, it does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked (voxelwise) statistical map or GLM contrasts for the healthy group. The analysis is based on group ICA (multivariate component maps) and component time courses with post-hoc event-related averages. Per the review’s criteria, studies that report only ICA/multivariate or connectivity-type results without an accompanying univariate whole-brain task activation map must be excluded. All other eligibility criteria (healthy adults, whole-brain acquisition, social task) are met, but the lack of a voxelwise task activation map disqualifies inclusion.

Meets all inclusion criteria: healthy adult sample (N=32 males age 21–33; task data reported for 21 participants within 17–65), uses task-based fMRI probing social-related processing (anticipation of touching an animate vs. inanimate target — social interaction/Perception of Others), and reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked statistical maps and contrasts (paired-sample t-tests and covariate analyses with Narcissistic Grandiosity) generalizable to healthy adults. Although resting-state PLE analyses are also performed, the paper includes clear whole-brain task activation results (FDR-corrected maps and coordinates) rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only findings. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore include.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social perception in healthy adults (N=16, ages ~22.8) using a social-related task (judging facing-toward/away from point-light and human-like walkers). Group-level, task-evoked contrasts are reported and described in the text with stereotaxic coordinates (voxelwise GLM second-level contrasts and ANOVAs), and results are generalizable to healthy adults. Although targeted masks for the Mirror Neuron and Mentalizing systems were used for main ANOVAs, the paper reports whole-study, group-level activation contrasts and voxelwise coordinates (FWE-corrected peaks) for the healthy sample. The study therefore meets inclusion criteria: fMRI task in healthy adults and reporting group-level whole-brain/univariate task activation results (coordinates and text).

Meets inclusion criteria: (1) Task involves social-related processing (perception and categorization of others’ gender from faces), a relevant social construct. (2) Sample comprises healthy adults (N=15 analyzed; ages 19–42), within 17–65. (3) Paper reports group-level, voxel-wise whole-brain univariate analyses (random-effects GLM; contrast gender-different > gender-same; thresholded group activation maps reported and displayed). No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state only, includes direct within-group whole-brain task effects). Therefore eligible for the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

While this is an fMRI study of social evaluation in healthy adult participants (N=36, mean age 22) and uses an appropriate social task, the paper reports results based on a small-volume–corrected ROI analysis of the ventral ACC. The methods and results focus on ROI-based SVC clusters and do not present or describe any unmasked, whole-brain group-level voxelwise task activation maps or whole-brain coordinates. Because the inclusion criteria require at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map from the healthy/control group, this study must be excluded.

The study uses fMRI in healthy adult participants and investigates social processing (empathy for pain). However, based on the provided full text, the reported whole-brain, voxelwise results are presented primarily as between-group contrasts (STRESS > CONTROL and conjunctions) and ROI analyses. The manuscript excerpt does not clearly report an unmasked, group-level whole-brain task activation map for a healthy/control group or an across-healthy-participants main effect (e.g., injection>Q-tip within the healthy/control group or all participants) that is generalizable to healthy adults. Per the review’s exclusion criteria, studies that report only between-group contrasts without an accompanying univariate whole-brain healthy-group task effect must be excluded. Therefore this study does not meet the ‘whole-brain evidence’ inclusion requirement.

This is an fMRI study of social evaluation (forced-choice social judgment task) in healthy adults (N=20; ages 18–29), satisfying the sample criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (multilevel whole-brain MLM, cluster thresholds, coordinates, and tables/figures showing activation in dACC, bilateral DLPFC and other regions), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. It is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses, and results are reported for the healthy/control group and generalizable within the healthy adult range. No exclusion criteria (clinical-only sample, ROI-only reporting, or non-empirical paper) are met, so the study should be INCLUDED.

The study’s participant sample is ages 8–19 (adolescents); no separate healthy adult group (age 17–65) is reported and no analyses limited to an adult subgroup are provided. Although the paper reports whole-brain, task-evoked fMRI maps, these results are from a youth sample and therefore are not generalizable to a healthy adult population as required. Thus the study fails the sample inclusion criterion (healthy adult group reported separately) and does not provide the required whole-brain healthy-adult task map. Other criteria (social task, whole-brain methods) are met for the youth sample, but the adult-sample requirement is not satisfied, so the paper must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social feedback task probing social inclusion/exclusion (relevant constructs). Sample comprises healthy adolescents/young adults (N=56 analyzed; ages 17–20), which falls within the review’s 17–65 age range and participants were screened to exclude Axis-I psychiatric disorders and other health issues. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task activation results (positive>neutral, negative>neutral, conjunction analyses) with familywise error correction and peak coordinates and overlays—fulfilling the whole-brain evidence requirement. The study is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and reports unmasked within-group healthy participant contrasts generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI task study of social processing (facial emotion recognition) that includes a healthy adult control group (N=14; mean age 23.6, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, univariate, voxelwise whole-brain analyses: exploratory whole-brain results are presented separately for the neurotypical (NT) control group (e.g., significant clusters for NTOXT>PLA in inferior frontal gyrus and fusiform gyrus, reported with coordinates/cluster tables). The study therefore provides healthy-group, whole-brain task-evoked activation maps (within-group contrasts) generalizable to healthy adults and meets all inclusion criteria (task fMRI; healthy adult sample; whole-brain results). It is not ROI-only and is empirical original data.

This is an fMRI study of healthy adults (N=7, ages 20–35) using a sentence-reading task that includes sentences describing people and social interactions. The authors identify a ‘‘people and social interactions’’ semantic factor and report associated brain region clusters (group-level factor analysis results; Supporting Information Table S3 and Figure 4A). The study provides group-level, voxelwise analyses linking sentence content to whole-brain activation patterns and explicitly discusses neural substrates of social content. Thus it meets: (1) use of fMRI during a task involving social-related content (perception/understanding of others/social interactions), (2) healthy adult sample within the age range, and (3) reporting of group-level voxelwise brain locations/clusters (whole-brain evidence). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy sample) apply. Inclusion is somewhat borderline because social processing is one of several content domains rather than the sole focus, but the presented group-level whole-brain results for social-related content satisfy the review criteria.

This is an fMRI study of naturalistic social cognition (theory-of-mind mentalising) that includes a healthy adult control group (n=22; ages 19–46). The paper reports within-group, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (ToM video phases > physical inference) for the control group with cluster-corrected whole-brain results (Table 3, Fig.1a) rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Although a clinical ASD group is included, control-group results are reported separately and generalizable to healthy adults. All inclusion criteria are met (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain univariate group-level maps). No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of face perception (perception/understanding of others), a social-related construct. The sample includes a healthy adult group (n=51; ages 18–42) reported separately from child groups. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., Face>Object, Face>Texture) analyzed with mixed-effects (FLAME) and cluster-corrected thresholds; whole-brain statistical maps and group activation figures/tables are described for the adult group. The design is task-evoked and not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or patient-only contrasts. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria for healthy adult, whole-brain, task-evoked fMRI of social processing.

Meets inclusion criteria: empirical event-related fMRI study in healthy adults (N=12, mean age 21) using a social/mentalizing task (monitoring others’ decisions vs computer), reporting group-level, voxelwise second-level random-effects analyses (SPM) with peak coordinates and statistical maps. Although multiple-comparison correction used small-volume correction within an anatomically defined ACC, results derive from whole-brain voxelwise GLMs and are reported as group-level contrasts generalizable to healthy adults. Not an ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-groups-only, or non-empirical paper. Therefore it should be included.

Meets social-processing task and healthy adult sample criteria, but does not report an unmasked, whole-brain voxelwise group-level task activation map. Analyses and reported statistical results are based on region-of-interest masks with small-volume correction (ROI/SVC) rather than whole-brain, unmasked voxelwise results. Because the review requires at least one whole-brain, group-level univariate task map for healthy adults, this study must be excluded.

Meets inclusion criteria: task is an fMRI event-related face recognition paradigm addressing perception/understanding of others (social processing). Sample comprises healthy adults (n=18 recruited, ages 19–36; one excluded for motion; healthy-group results reported). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain (RFX) task contrasts (false recognition vs. recognition and correct rejection) with cluster correction and Talairach coordinates — not limited to ROI-only or connectivity analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore include.

This is an fMRI study of social perception (masked fearful vs. happy eyes) using a social-related task (perception of others’ emotional eye signals) in healthy adult participants (male, mean age ~24; final N=43). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task analyses (exploratory whole-brain results reported in Results and Supplementary Tables) in addition to ROI analyses, with contrasts clearly attributed to the healthy/control group under placebo and oxytocin. Thus all inclusion criteria are met (task-based fMRI social processing, healthy adult sample within 17–65, and reported whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked results). No exclusion criteria are violated.

This study reports task-based fMRI in a healthy adult sample using a social-cognitive paradigm (neutral face processing, emotion recognition, affective ToM). The sample consists of healthy adults reported separately (N=74; no clinical groups included). The paper provides group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (one-sample t-tests and ANOVA of task effects) with whole-brain results reported (FWE-corrected, p<0.05) and displayed in figures/tables, fulfilling the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although ROI and connectivity analyses are also presented, whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy group are clearly reported. Age range is not explicitly listed but participants are described as healthy adults; inclusion criterion of adult healthy group (17–65) is met based on sample description. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis objective.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (observing dyadic violent interactions) in healthy adults (N=15, final N=14; all male, mean age 23.6). The study reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate GLM results (e.g., interaction vs baseline; focus on aggressor vs victim), with cluster-size correction and Talairach-space reporting, describing activations across distributed brain regions (amygdala, insula, EBA, ACC, STS, visual cortex, etc.). Results for the healthy participant group are reported and generalizable to healthy adults within the target age range. The paper also includes connectivity analyses but does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity-only approaches. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social processing (empathy/empirical accuracy—perception and understanding of others) in healthy adults (final fMRI sample n=34, ages 20–30). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (e.g., emotional>neutral contrasts, parametric modulation by empathic accuracy and time-series correlations with intensity ratings) with TFCE/FWE correction and peak coordinates/tables described. Results for the healthy/control group are reported directly and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and not a non-empirical paper). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

Although the study uses task fMRI during a social (trust game) paradigm and reports whole-brain task activation, the sample consists of adolescent participants (ages 13–19) and the healthy/control group is not a healthy adult sample. The review requires healthy adults aged 17–65 or a separately reported healthy adult subgroup. The paper does not report results for a separate adult subgroup (e.g., 17–65) nor present whole-brain results generalizable to a healthy adult population. Therefore it fails the sample-age inclusion criterion.

Meets all inclusion criteria: Task-based fMRI of social cognition (theory-of-mind: cooperation, deception, intention and belief attribution). Sample consists of healthy adults (n=13; ages 22–38). Reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain task-evoked analysis (ToM vs non-ToM) with reported peak coordinates and maps, and subsequent within-group contrasts; not limited to ROI-only or connectivity/resting analyses. Results are clearly from the healthy/control group and generalizable within the adult range. No exclusion criteria (e.g., patient-only sample or only ROI/connectivity results) are violated.

Study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adults (age 18–55) using an imitation/observation emotional face paradigm — a social-related task. Participants were screened healthy; imaging data from 20 participants were analyzed. The paper includes whole-brain analyses: a univariate GLM in SPM8 is reported (GLM results referenced and similar to task-PLS LV1, with Supplementary Figure 1), and voxelwise PLS maps are presented (thresholded bootstrap-ratio maps across the brain). This is not an ROI-only, connectivity-only, or between-group-only study, and it presents group-level, voxelwise task-evoked effects generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception of others’ pupils and social salience). Participants are healthy adults (N=14, mean age 22), meeting the age and healthy-sample criteria. The paper reports group-level whole-brain, random-effects univariate analyses (second-level t-tests and ANOVA) with cluster-corrected thresholds for the main effect of viewing eye stimuli and reported whole-brain results for pupil-change effects; ROI analyses are supplementary but whole-brain task-evoked maps are clearly presented and described. The design involves an explicit task (implicit eye observation with biofeedback) and the results are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (e.g., only ROI, resting-state, or non-healthy-only samples) are violated. Therefore the study should be included in the review.

Although this is an event-related fMRI study with a healthy control group and probes emotion-related (socially relevant) word processing, the paper does not report an unmasked, whole-brain, group-level task activation map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. The manuscript primarily presents pooled (all-subjects) activation maps, and whole-brain between-group contrasts (controls > ASC). Within-group effects for controls are discussed but appear limited to ROI analyses or are not presented as an independent whole-brain statistical map generalizable to the healthy adult population. Because the review requires at least one whole-brain, univariate healthy-group task map (not only between-group contrasts or ROI results), the study fails to meet the whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of self-face recognition (Perception and Understanding of Self), a social-related construct. Sample: healthy adult participants (16 analyzed, ages 19–24), reported separately. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise random-effects analyses (SPM) with reported thresholding and cluster-level FWE-corrected results and coordinates (e.g., MPFC, PCC, precuneus), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although ROI analyses are also presented, whole-brain task-evoked maps are reported, so the study is not limited to ROI-only results. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (social rejection via a virtual handshake task) that includes a healthy adult control group (n=16, mean age 27.4). The paper reports whole-brain, univariate voxelwise task contrasts for the control group (refusal > acceptance), identifying significant activations (right pSTS and right thalamus) and describing cluster-level and FWE-corrected results. Methods explicitly describe whole-brain preprocessing and group-level voxelwise t-tests using AFNI, and results for the healthy group are presented separately. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met (social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample reported separately, and whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps). No exclusion criteria are violated.

Meets all inclusion criteria: fMRI task involves social-related processing (face perception, emotion/mentalizing via Thatcher Illusion); includes a healthy adult control group (NT; n=18, mean age 25.8 within 17–65) with results reported separately from the clinical ASD group; reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts for the healthy/control group (within-group whole-brain activation maps and thresholding described, and between-group contrasts also reported). Not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore eligible for inclusion.

While this is an fMRI study of social processing that includes a healthy adult control group, the paper’s primary statistical results are reported using a priori ROI analyses and small-volume corrections for theory-of-mind regions, and the key reported contrasts are group interactions (ASC vs control). The manuscript does not present an unambiguous whole‑brain, voxelwise task activation map explicitly reported for the healthy/control group alone (the whole‑brain, FWE‑corrected contrasts mentioned appear to be derived from the combined sample or used to define control networks rather than a standalone healthy-group map). Because the inclusion criteria require at least one group-level, univariate whole‑brain task-evoked statistical map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group, this study does not meet that requirement and should be excluded.

The study uses fMRI during a social task and reports whole-brain task activations, but the sample spans ages 7–40 and all group-level whole-brain results are reported for the combined (child-to-adult) sample or as age correlations. The paper does not report a separate group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation map restricted to a healthy adult (17–65) subgroup that would be generalizable to adults. Because participants under age 17 are included and no adult-only whole-brain analysis is provided, the study does not meet the requirement for a healthy adult group-level whole-brain task effect.

This is an fMRI study of social communication (recognition of communicative intentions from vocal prosody). Sample: 22 healthy adult participants (mean age 27.35), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task contrasts (CLEAR > AMBIGUOUS and AMBIGUOUS > CLEAR) submitted to random-effects one-sample t-tests with voxelwise and cluster-level FWE correction; results are presented in the text/figures and coordinates. The study also reports PPI analyses, but these are supplementary to the main whole-brain task activations. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, healthy adults reported separately). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This study reports task-based fMRI using a well-validated social exclusion paradigm (Cyberball) that directly probes social-related processing. It includes a healthy adult control group (n=28) reported separately from clinical groups. The paper presents whole-brain, group-level, univariate within-group results for healthy controls (ANOVA main effect of condition in left anterior insula/inferior frontal gyrus) with SPM whole-brain voxelwise FWE-corrected thresholds (voxel p-FWE < 0.05, k≥10), satisfying the requirement for a whole-brain task-evoked map generalizable to healthy adults. The sample comprises adult females within the target age range, and analyses are whole-brain rather than ROI- or connectivity-only. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI of social impression formation in a healthy adult sample (60 men, mean age 23.8) and reports detailed preprocessing/GLM steps, the manuscript presents multivariate behavioral PLS results rather than group-level univariate whole-brain task activation maps or voxelwise contrasts for the healthy group. The paper references a prior univariate analysis of the same dataset but does not provide univariate whole-brain statistical maps or contrasts in this report. Because the inclusion criteria require at least one group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked map, this study does not meet that criterion.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (self vs other understanding within romantic relationships) in healthy adults (N=42, ages 23–40). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., self positive > neutral; other negative > neutral), with voxelwise FWE correction and tables/figures of activations, and ANOVA results at the whole-brain level. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are reported independently. The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults (N=27, ages ~24–26). The task involved passive observation of ecologically valid social interactions (cooperative vs. affective), which directly addresses social perception/understanding of others. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (random-effects SPM8; contrasts vs. landscape; conjunctions; FWE-corrected and uncorrected maps) that are clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group and generalizable to healthy adults. ROI analyses are supplementary but do not replace the whole-brain results. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, participants within 17–65). Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

Participants are adolescents (aged 12–18), not healthy adults (17–65); the healthy/control group consists of typically developing adolescents, so the sample does not include a clear healthy adult group. The task is the Embedded Figures Task (a visual search/perceptual task), which is not a social-related task targeting affiliation, social communication, or perception/understanding of others. Although the paper reports whole-brain fMRI contrasts and control-group activation maps, it does not provide a whole-brain task activation map for a healthy adult sample. Therefore the study fails the sample-age inclusion criterion and the social-task relevance criterion, so it must be excluded.

Although the study uses task fMRI of face processing (a social-perception paradigm) and includes healthy adult participants, it does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. The primary whole-brain analyses were conducted on a combined sample of patients and controls, and the independent (healthy) replication focused on genotype–activation associations within an anatomical ROI (fusiform) with small-volume/FWE correction rather than reporting an unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task effect. Because the inclusion criteria require a separately reported whole-brain healthy-group activation map (or equivalent voxelwise healthy-group contrast), this study does not meet all inclusion requirements.

The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult samples (study 1: n=41, study 2: n=39; ages 18–24). Tasks probe social-related constructs (self-related processing and mentalizing/social cognition) and include explicit self- and social-processing ROIs. Crucially, the paper conducts and reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked analyses (exploratory whole-brain searches, voxelwise maps, corrected results described in main text and SI) rather than ROI-only results. The whole-brain contrasts are within the healthy/control groups and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-only, healthy adult group reported separately). Therefore the paper meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This study does not meet the review inclusion criteria. The task is a non-social visual attention task (not a social-related processing task), so it is outside the constructs specified. The sample comprises boys (children/adolescents) including ASD probands, unaffected siblings, and matched controls — not healthy adults aged 17–65; although a healthy control group is present, it consists of children/adolescents rather than adults. While whole-brain group-level fMRI results for controls are reported, the lack of a healthy adult sample and the non-social nature of the task violate key inclusion criteria. Therefore the study should be excluded.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (14 sighted, 8 blind; mean ages within 17–65) that investigates perception/understanding of others’ actions (mirror-system responses)—a social-related construct. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (t-contrasts, cluster-corrected and small-volume-corrected results), maps, and coordinates for the healthy groups separately (sighted and congenitally blind). Results are not limited to ROIs, connectivity, or resting-state analyses. Healthy-group effects are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of a social decision-making task (control aversion where another person restricts choice), conducted in healthy adult participants (n=51, mean age 22). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., controlled > free) with cluster-level FWE correction and peak MNI coordinates, described in the text and figures. Although it also includes PPI connectivity analyses, it additionally provides standard whole-brain activation maps and covariate analyses for the healthy group. It does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity-only analyses, nor does it involve clinical-only samples or age out of range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (mothers aged 22–37, final N=23) during a clearly social/attachment-related task (viewing own infant vs stranger infant). The paper presents group-level, voxelwise whole-brain GLM contrasts (own infant > stranger infant) with statistical maps and tables (Figure 3, Table 1) in the healthy sample, meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. While ROI and connectivity analyses are also reported, whole-brain univariate task-evoked results for the healthy adult group are explicitly described. Participants fall within the 17–65 age range and results are reported for the healthy group separately. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, or patient-only sample) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This study used task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (Experiment 1: 20 adults, mean age 25.3) investigating face perception/recognition — a social-related construct (Perception and Understanding of Others). The authors performed group-level univariate analyses (mixed-effects FLAME) and explicitly report an independent group-level localizer (n=83) comparing faces vs scrambled faces to define ROIs — i.e., a group-level voxelwise contrast derived from healthy participants. Behavioral tasks (Experiments 2–3) further probe social perception and link to neural data. The paper is empirical, includes healthy adults within the 17–65 range, and provides group-level task-evoked whole-brain analyses (localizer and higher-level group analyses) that are generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (judgments about self, friends, and strangers — constructs: perception/understanding of self and others, closeness/affiliation). Sample comprises healthy adults (n=98; mean age 20.7, range within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., self > Bush, friends > strangers) with statistical maps and figures (thresholded at p<0.001 uncorrected) and provides whole-brain analyses in experiments 1–4. Although ROI analyses are included, whole-brain univariate results are clearly reported for the healthy/control group. No exclusion criteria apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI task study of social-related processing (direct and reflected self-evaluations from peers across social/academic/physical domains). It includes a healthy adult group (N=19; ages 22–31) reported separately within analyses. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise analyses (2×4×3 ANOVA) with corrected thresholds (AlphaSim) and provides significant clusters/coordinates (e.g., bilateral ventral striatum coordinates reported), not only ROI results. The task and contrasts are task-evoked and relevant to perception/understanding of self and social evaluation. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-adult-only) are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for healthy adult whole-brain fMRI studies of social processing.

While this fMRI study uses a social-related task (trustworthiness/fear appraisal) and includes a healthy adult control group (ages 18–45), it does not present a group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. The reported whole-brain analyses appear to be across all participants or between-group contrasts, and the control-specific results are reported primarily via ROI analyses rather than an unmasked whole-brain healthy-group map. Therefore it fails the requirement for whole-brain healthy-group task-evoked evidence.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=21 males, age 21–39) using a social-related task (dynamic investigator thumbs-up/thumbs-down feedback) probing negative vs positive social evaluation. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain random-effects analyses (contrast: negative social feedback > positive social feedback) with corrected and uncorrected statistical maps and tables of peak coordinates for the healthy/control sample (placebo condition and drug comparisons). The task and results clearly target social processing and provide univariate whole-brain activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state only, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This study reports fMRI data collected during a task in healthy adult participants (N=21) involving repeated retrieval of autobiographical life events that were social in nature (oral examination with an actor) and explicitly probes bodily self-perception (out-of-body vs. in-body). The paper reports group-level, task-evoked whole-brain univariate activation results (e.g., retrosplenial cortex, medial prefrontal cortex, hippocampus; Table S1; voxelwise statistical maps reported with corrected thresholds), not only ROI or connectivity analyses. Participants are healthy adults within the eligible age range. The experimental manipulation addresses perception/understanding of self (bodily self) — a construct specified as relevant. Therefore the paper meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (perception/understanding of others via eye gaze). Sample comprises 18 healthy adult participants (ages 18–30) and is analyzed with random-effects second-level models allowing population inference. The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise second-level results: group-level univariate maps showing significant positive and negative correlations between AQ and the variable-versus-constant gaze contrast (coordinates, whole-brain FDR thresholding, and ROI SVC results are provided). Although the simple group main effect of variable vs. constant gaze was null, the AQ-related whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical paper) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women aged 19–29) using social/affiliative stimuli (infant cries and faces) relevant to social processing (attachment, perception of others). Group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts are reported (e.g., high- vs low-distress cries, cries vs pink noise, happy vs neutral faces) with multiple-comparison correction and cluster thresholds described, and results are presented as whole-brain activations. The sample is within the 17–65 age range and healthy; analyses are not ROI-only nor limited to connectivity or between-group comparisons. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

The paper does not report any original task-evoked whole-brain fMRI activation maps from healthy adult participants. It is primarily a resting-state fMRI parcellation study (N=20) and uses meta-analytic coactivation (MACM/BrainMap) and behavioral decoding to characterize subregions. Although it reports functional associations (including social cognition) via BrainMap meta-data, these are not group-level, within-study task activation maps from healthy subjects. This fails the inclusion criterion requiring task-based whole-brain healthy-group activation data; it also meets the exclusion criterion for studies reporting only resting-state or meta-analytic coactivation without a healthy-group whole-brain task effect.

This fMRI study examines social communication (pantomime/gesture planning and execution), a social-related task relevant to review constructs. It includes a healthy adult control group (n=25) reported separately and matched to patients. The paper reports whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (within-group and between-group contrasts), with thresholded whole-brain results and cluster coordinates/figures (supplementary materials referenced). Results for the healthy/control group are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and not limited to connectivity or resting-state analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (self-referential processing and perspective taking), meeting the review’s content scope. The task uses trait-judgments about self vs. close other and perspective-taking manipulations, clearly social-related. The paper reports group-level task-evoked activations in medial prefrontal cortex for contrasts (self vs other; perspective taking), indicating univariate whole-brain activation results (not ROI-only or connectivity-only). Participants are described as healthy (no clinical groups reported or required), and results are reported at the group level and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, and appears to be empirical fMRI data). Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

Although the study uses task fMRI of social-related processing and includes a healthy adult control group, it does not report a standalone, univariate whole-brain task activation map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. Reported whole-brain univariate results are either combined (ASD+TD) contrasts used to define seeds or between-group comparisons (ASD vs TD). The main reported findings focus on between-group contrasts, seed-based beta-series functional connectivity and ROI analyses in the control group rather than an unmasked, whole-brain within-group activation map for the healthy adults. Therefore it fails the requirement for whole-brain evidence from the healthy/control group and must be excluded per the review criteria.

Although the study used an fMRI cognitive-empathy (social) task and included a healthy adult control group (n=24; ages 18–50), the imaging results reported are based on whole-brain between-group contrasts (schizophrenia vs controls) and clusters derived from these group differences. The paper does not present an unmasked, whole-brain, group-level task activation map or within-group voxelwise statistical map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group (only between-group differential activation and extracted percent signal change by group are reported). Therefore it fails the requirement for healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked results and must be excluded per the review’s criteria.

The study uses fMRI during an implicit emotional face discrimination task (social communication/perception of others). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=19; ages 18–51) reported separately. Whole-brain, univariate SPM analyses were performed and group-level task-evoked activations for controls are described (within-group/control activations for specific emotions and contrasts versus baseline and patients are reported in text and tables). Thus all inclusion criteria are met (social-related fMRI task; healthy adult sample; reported whole-brain group-level univariate results attributable to the healthy group). Minor uncertainty arises because some control within-group maps are described in text rather than shown in full, but these satisfy the review’s allowance for results reported in text/tables/figures.

execution_stats.search_query: ( ('functional MRI'[Title/Abstract] OR 'functional magnetic resonance imaging'[Title/Abstract] OR 'fMRI'[Title/Abstract] ) AND ( 'social communication'[Title/Abstract] OR 'social processing'[Title/Abstract] OR 'social interaction'[Title/Abstract] OR 'affiliation'[Title/Abstract] OR 'social attachment'[Title/Abstract] OR 'social cognition'[Title/Abstract] OR 'understanding others'[Title/Abstract] ) AND 'Humans'[MeSH])
